column11: Ambassis commersonii Cuvier, 1828;  Ambassis klunzingeri Steindachner, 1881;  Ambassis productus Guichenot, 1866;  Centropomus ambassis Lacepède, 1802;  Chanda commersonii (Cuvier, 1828)
column12: Ambassis ambassis was originally described as Centropomus ambassis by Lacepède (1802) from Réunion, western Mascarenes, southwestern Indian Ocean. Günther (1859), Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1999) considered Ambassis ambassis as a synonym of Ambassis commersoni, which should be other way round (Anderson and Heemstra 2003).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Ambassis ambassis is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed and currently there is no known major threat to the species. Nevertheless, research is required on population trends, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Ambassis ambassis is found in the Indo-West Pacific from subtropical eastern South Africa to Kenya, Madagascar, Réunion and Mauritius (Anderson and Heemstra 2003, Harrison 2005), Seychelles  (Playfair 1868), Zanzibar (Playfair and Günther 1867), Borneo (Fowler 1905), India (Raj 1916, Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999, Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, Ramanujam and Anbarasan 2009) and north Australasia (Day 1875).
column31: Native: Australia; India; Indonesia; Kenya; Madagascar; Malaysia; Mauritius; Réunion; Seychelles; South Africa; Viet Nam
column35: No information is available on the global population status of Ambassis ambassis. The species is considered to be very rare in Madras (Raj 1916) and Bharathpuzha River in Kerala (Bijukumar and Sushama 2001). Percent abundance of this species in the estuary between Orange River and Kosi Bay of South Africa is 1.86% and its contribution to the total biomass of fishes is 0.01% (Harrison 2005).
column43: Ambassis ambassis prefers estuarine environments but it may enter into freshwater system. It is mainly found in the ascending rivers and brackish water lakes (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). The species is also known from volcanic crater lakes in Madagascar (Anderson and Heemstra 2003).  It attains a total length of around 6 inches (Day 1875).
column49: No information is available on threats to Ambassis ambassis.
column53: Currently there is no specific action plan directed towards Ambassis ambassis. Research on the population status, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species is essential.

column11: Ambassis bleekeri Maugé, 1984;  Ambassis denticulata Klunzinger, 1870
column12: Ambassis dussumieri Cuvier was described from Malabar, India (Cuvier and Valenciennes 1828).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Ambassis dussumieri is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed and currently there are no known major threats to the species. Nevertheless, research is required on population trends, ecology and threats to the species.
column26: Ambassis dussumieri is found in Indo-West Pacific from Algoa Bay, South Africa, north to the Red Sea, Zanzibar, Seychelles and eastward around India (in Kochi, Orissa and Andaman Islands) and Australasia to the Philippines and China in estuarine and coastal waters (Günther 1859, Day 1865a, 1869, 1871, Playfair and Günther 1867, Playfair 1868, Anderson and Heemstra 2003).
column31: Native: Australia; Bangladesh; China; India (Andaman Is., Kerala, Orissa); Indonesia; Japan; Madagascar; Malaysia; Myanmar; Philippines; Seychelles; South Africa; Sri Lanka
column35: No information is available on the global population status of Ambassis dussumieri. But the species is common in Thukela Estuary of South Africa with catch per unit effort (average number of fish samples per seine haul) of 32 and 44 for February 1997 and February 1999 respectively (Whitfield and Harrison 2003).
column43: Ambassis dussumieri inhabits seas and estuaries, but it is also found in rivers within tidal influence (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It attains a total length of around 4 inches (Day 1865b).
column49: Threats are poorly known, but currently there are believed to be no major threats to the species.
column53: Currently there is no specific action plan directed towards Ambassis dussumieri. Research on the population status, ecology and threats to the species is essential.

column11: Apogon roseus Fischer, 1885;  Chanda gymnochephalus (Lacepède, 1802);  Lutjanus gymnocephalus Lacepède, 1802
column12: Ambassis gymnocephalus was originally described as Lutjanus gymnocephalus by Lacepède (1802) from Indo-Pacific region. This species is considered as 'nomen dubium' by Anderson and Heemstra (2003) because of the considerable taxonomic confusion and on the basis of the lack of diagnostic features. However, the species has been considered as valid by Day (1875), Talwar and Jhingran (1991), Jayaram (1999) and Eschmeyer (2010).
column18: Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K., Abraham, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Ambassis gymnocephalus is assessed as Least Concern because it is a widespread species with no known major threats. However, the taxonomy of this species needs to be resolved. Furthermore, there is a need to study the population status, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Ambassis gymnocephalus is distributed in Indo-West Pacific (Day 1875, Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999): Red Sea and South Africa (Whitfield and Paterson 2003), Kenya to the Philippines, India (Bhimachar and Venkataraman 1952, Venkataraman 1960, Tilak 1972), Sri Lanka (Vinobaba 2007) north to China (Randall and Lim 2000), Hong Kong (Nip and Wong 2010), Thiland (Shinnaka et al. 2007), Hainan (Nichols and Pope 1927), Borneo (Inger 1955) and Taiwan (Hung and Chiu 1991), south to northern Australia (Russell et al. 2003).
column31: Native: Australia; China (Hainan); Hong Kong; India; Indonesia; Kenya; Madagascar; Malaysia; Philippines; South Africa; Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Viet Nam
column35: No information is available on the population trends of Ambassis gymnocephalus. However, the species is common in India (Bhimachar and Venkataraman 1952, Venkataraman 1960) and Hong Kong (Nip and Wong 2010) with 67.74 % of total abundance and 66.27% of percent biomass in Tolo Harbour. The species is rare in South Africa (Whitfield and Paterson 2003).
column43: Ambassis gymnocephalus is primarily marine fish but it enters estuaries and freshwaters (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It feeds on copepals (like Centropages, Pseudodiuptomus, Eucalanus, Acartia and Oithona), polychaetes (chiefly Prionospio pinnara), cladocerans, decapods, cirripede larva and diatoms and rarely on Sugitta, Hippa, amphipods, larval bivalves, fish post-larva and fish scales (Venkataraman 1960). This species attains a total length of 10 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column49: Threats to Ambassis gymnocephalus are poorly known, but currently there are believed to be no major threats to the species.
column53: Currently there is no specific action plan directed towards Ambassis gymnocephalus. Research is needed on the taxonomy, population status, harvest trends and threats to the species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

column11: Ambassis dalyensis Rendahl, 1922;  Ambassis elevatus Macleay, 1881;  Ambassis interruptus Bleeker, 1852
column12: Ambassis interrupta was described by Bleeker (1852) from Celebes, Indonesia.
column18: Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K., Abraham, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Ambassis interrupta is assessed as Least Concern because it is a widespread species with no known major threat to the species. Research is, however, essential on the population trends, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Ambassis interrupta is found in Indo-West Pacific from lower freshwaters of large rivers to mangrove stands; west coast of India (Goa, Kerala, Tamil Nadu) to Andaman Islands, Borneo, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Philippines, Australia, New Guinea, New Caledonia and Vanuatu (Günther 1859, Day 1875, Inger 1955, Tilak 1972, Ng et al. 1999, Randall and Lim 2000, Rao et al. 2000, Anderson and Heemstra 2003, Jaafar et al. 2004, Tan and Lim 2004, Baker and Sheaves 2005, Hui et al. 2010).
column31: Native: Australia; China; Hong Kong; India (Andaman Is., Goa, Kerala, Tamil Nadu); Indonesia; Madagascar; Malaysia; Myanmar; Singapore; South Africa; Sri Lanka; Thailand; Viet Nam
column35: No information is available on the global population status of Ambassis interrupta. The species forms 4.6% of the total abundance of fishes at Pasir Ris, in the eastern part of Singapore (Jaafar et al. 2004).
column43: Ambassis interrupta is found in shallow coastal waters and creeks (Rao et al. 2000). It feeds mainly on crustaceans followed by polychaeta and insects (Baker and Sheaves 2005).
column49: Threats to Ambassis interrupta are poorly known, but currently there are believed to be no major threats to the species.
column53: No conservation action plan is in place directed towards Ambassis interrupta. Research is needed on population status, harvest trends and threats to the species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.
column60: Dahanukar, N. 2010. Ambassis interrupta. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 19 October 2011.

column12: Ambassis nalua was originally described as Chanda nalua by Hamilton (1822) from fresh waters of lower Bengal.
column18: Basheer, V.S., Abraham, R., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Ambassis nalua is assessed as Least Concern because it is a widespread species with no known major threats. Nonetheless, research is essential on the population trends and threats to the species.
column26: Ambassis nalua is distributed in Indo-West Pacific in bays, estuaries and tidal creeks from the west coast of India (Kerala State) to Andaman Islands, Malaya Archipelago, Javanese seas, Sea of Pinang, China, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Philippines, Australia and New Guinea (Günther 1859; Day 1865, 1875; John 1936; Haywood et al. 1998; Randall and Lim 2000; Anderson and Heemstra 2003; Shinnaka et al. 2007; Hui et al. 2010).
column31: Native: Australia; Bangladesh; China; Hong Kong; India (Andaman Is., Kerala, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal); Indonesia; Malaysia; Myanmar; Philippines; Singapore; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand
column35: No information is available on the population trends in Ambassis nalua.
column43: Ambassis nalua inhabits fresh and brackish waters (Day 1865). It feeds on Annelida, Brachyura, Crustacea, Mollusca, Penaeidae and Teleostei (Haywood et al. 1998). It attains a total length of five inches (2.5 cm) (Day 1865).
column49: Threats to Ambassis nalua are poorly known, but currently there are believed to be no major threats to the global population.
column53: No conservation action plan is in place directed towards Ambassis nalua. Research is needed on the population trends and threats to the species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

column11: Ambassis dayi Bleeker, 1874;  Ambassis valenciennii Vaillant, 1877
column12: Parambassis dayi was originally described as Ambassis dayi by Bleeker (1874) from Cochin (Kochi), Kerala, India.
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K., Raghavan, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Parambassis dayi is assessed as Least Concern because the species is expected to be widely distributed along the west coast of southern Western Ghats. It is a common species and there are no known major threats to the species. The species is known from at least one protected site in Periyar Tiger Reserve. Research is, however, essential on the population status, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Parambassis dayi is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). The species is found in the coastal region of southern Western Ghats and till recently the species was known only from Kerala (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Roberts 1994, Menon 1999). Recently, Bhat (2004) reported the species from Bedti river in southern Karnataka extending the range of this species considerably northwards. In Kerala the species is known from Kochi (Roberts 1994), Chalakudy river (Ajithkumar et al. 1999), Travancore (John 1936), Vembanad Lake (Kurup and Samuel 1985) and Periyar Tiger Reserve (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010).  The expected EOO of the species is 64000 to 65000 km2 while the number of locations are more than 10.
column35: Exact population status of Parambassis dayi is not known but the species is very common in Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002).
column43: Parambassis dayi inhabits freshwaters and estuarine lakes (Talwar and Jhingran 1991) including upper reaches of rivers. It attains a total length of 17.5 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: There are not considered to be any significant threat to this species, however it can be threatened in parts of its range by the prevailing threats of habitat loss, pollution etc.
column53: Currently there is no conservation action plan directed towards Parambassis dayi. Research is essential on the population status, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species. The species is known from at least one protected site in Periyar Tiger Reserve (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010).

column12: Parambassis thomassi was originally described as Ambassis thomassi by Day (1870) from Calicut and Mangalore, India.
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Krishna , K.K., Abraham, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Parambassis thomassi is assessed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed in the west coast of the southern Western Ghats Goa to Kerala. Furthermore, there are no major threats to the species. It is from known from at least five protected areas at Chimmony Wildlife Sanctuary, Peechi-Vazhani Wildlife Sanctuary, Idukki Wildlife Sanctuary, Neyyar Wildlife Sanctuary and Periyar Tiger Reserve. Research is essential on population status, ecology and threats to the species.
column26: Parambassis thomassi is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is recorded from Kerala (John 1936, Shaji et al. 1995, Shaji and Easa 1996, Ajithkumar 1999, Thomas et al. 2000a, 2000b, Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, Beevi and Ramachandran 2009, Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010), Karnataka (Bhat 2004) and Goa (Tilak 1972). The species is found only in the western coast of southern India. It is record from the east flowing Tungabhadra river by Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu (2009) and Shahnawaz et al. (2010) is doubtful.
column35: Exact population structure of Parambassis thomassi is not known. Overall it is rare in Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002). It is rare in Chalakkudy River, Muvattupuzha River and Periyar River (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009). Its population is moderate in Periyar Tiger Reserve (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010), while it is abundant in Bharathapuzha river (Bijukumar and Sushama 2001).
column43: Parambassis thomassi inhabits streams and lakes (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It lives in coastal waters but enters inland even to elevated localities (Menon 1999). It attains a total length of 16.5 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: There are no direct threats to this species Parambassis thomassi. It parts of its range populations may be impacted by general habitat loss or pollution.
column53: Parambassis thomassi is known from at least five protected area at Chimmony and Peechi-Vazhani Wildlife Sanctuaries (Thomas et al. 2000a), Idukki and Neyyar Wildlife Sanctuaries (Thomas et al. 2000b) and Periyar Tiger Reserve (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010). Research is essential on population status, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Aplocheilus blockii was described by Arnold (1911) from Sri Lanka.
column18: Abraham, R., Krishna , K.K., Cox, N.A. & Madhusoodana Kurup, B.
column20: Aplocheilus blockii is assessed as Least Concern as this species enjoys a wide distribution in the Indian sub-continent from Sri Lanka to Pakistan, with no known threats.
column26: Known from the Indian subcontinent with records of its presence in India (Menon 1999), Sri Lanka (Arnold 1911) and Pakistan (Mirza 2003). In peninsular India, it has been recorded from southern Tamil Nadu (Indra 1993, Remadevi and Ilango 1993, Indra 1994, Remadevi et al. 1999), Valapatanam river in northern Kerala (Kurup et al. 2004) and Goa (Tilak 1972).
column31: Native: India (Goa, Kerala - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu); Pakistan; Sri Lanka
column35: There is no information on the population of A. blockii in the Western Ghats or peninsular India.
column43: Found under the surface in still waters, mainly coastal and often brackish, especially where there is surface vegetation or cover, such as mangrove swamps and rice fields (Anon 2010).
column49: Localized threats include sand mining, pollution, water abstraction, sedimentation and collection for the international pet trade.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to document the distribution of the species in the Western Ghats and confirm its taxonomic identity. Genetic characterization using molecular techniques has been undertaken. This species has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research on taxonomy, population, life history and threats is essential.

column12: Batasio sharavatiensis was first described by Bhatt and Jayaram (2004) from Joginmatha, 1 km upstream of the Jog Falls in the Sharavati River, Karnataka.
column18: Basheer, V.S., Arunachalam, M., Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Dahanukar, N., Abraham, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Batasio sharavatiensis is assessed as Endangered because of its restricted distribution in Joginmatha and Yennehole tributaries of Sharavati River and Vimalanathi tributary of Tunga River (extent of occurrence less than 3,000 km_ and area of occupancy less than 50 km_). The species is very rare and is restricted to small streams which are threatened by inconsistent waterflow due to dams. There is also a possible future threat to B. sharavatiensis from exotic species and habitat degradation.
column26: Batasio sharavatiensis is endemic to the Western Ghats in the state of Karnataka, India. It is known to occur in the rivers Sharavati (Bhatt and Jayaram 2004) and Munsar Stream of Tunga inside the Kudremukh National Park (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2007).
column35: There is no information on population of B. sharavatiensis. It is very rare and highly restricted in its distribution, mostly to small streams with low flow (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2007).
column43: Known from upper reaches of rivers, it occurs in pools (Bhatt and Jayaram 2004), with good canopy cover and mud as substrate (Arunachalam et al. 2004).
column49: The Sharavati River, from where B. sharavatiensis was first described, harbours exotic fish species, notably the Common Carp (Cyprinus carpio) (Sreekantha and Ramachandra 2005). This is possible future threat to the species through competition for food and space. Its habitats in Kudremukh National Park were threatened by iron ore mining operations (Krishnaswamy et al. 2006), but these have now completely ceased. Due to the dam, the smaller streams below dry up, which is a threat to the species (M. Arunachalam pers. obs. 2003).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the life history and population characters of this species.

column12: Batasio travancoria was described from Karnataka and Perunteraruvi, tributary of Pamba river, Kerala by Hora and Law (1941).
column18: Ali, A., Raghavan, R., Dahanukar, N. & Molur, S.
column20: This species is listed as Vulnerable because it has an Extent of Occurrence of roughly 17,000 km2, and an estimated Area of Occupancy of 1,000 km2, populations are severely fragmented and threatened by habitat loss and degradation.
column26: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. Since its first description from river Pampa in Kerala, several researchers including Kurup et al. (2004) reported the species from Pamba, Achenkoil, Periyar, Chalakudy, Manimala and Neyyar rivers. Silas (1951) reported this species from Anamalai Hills. Raghunathan collected this species from Coorg dist., Karnataka in 1989.
column35: B. travancoria is known to be fairly common in some locations whereas it is relatively rare in others (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.).
column43: Found in the clear head-water streams with boulders, preferring pools with cobble or a sandy substrate, and riffles (Kurup et al. 2005). It is mostly a nocturnal feeder.
column49: This species is threatened in parts of its range by destructive fishing practices, habitat loss and fragmentation, including dynamiting, drought, and sedimentation.
column53: There is a need for habitat restoration, including restoring riparian vegetation. An inland fishes bill that covers all species has been passed in the state of Kerala.

column12: Hemibagrus punctatus was known from three locations from which the species has not been recorded since late 1990s. Subsequent and recent surveys in the rivers have not recorded this species thereby suggesting a drastic decline of close to 100% due to habitat loss and other threats that are not yet clearly understood. The species' identity may need further scrutiny in some locations it has been reported from, and in addition the confirmed locations need to be surveyed thoroughly before its status can be assessed as Extinct. It is therefore presently assessed as Critically Endangered (possibly extinct).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20:
Brachirus orientalis is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide marine distribution as well as its occurrence in coastal brackish and freshwater streams and lakes, there are no major threats and because the population is unlikely to be declining.

[[This species has already been assessed by the FBU - but the account is incomplete]]
column26:
This is a marine species of the Indo-west Pacific that has been rarely recorded from freshwater systems. In the Western Ghats it has been recorded from the lowland reaches of Chalakudy (Raghavan et al. 2008), Chaliyar (Shaji and Easa 2003), Vembanad Lake (Kurup and Samuel 1985).

[[This species has already been assessed by the FBU - but the account is incomplete]]
column35: It is a common species
column43: It is primarily a marine species, that can be encountered in estuaries, coastal wetland habitats and freshwater streams and lakes.
column49: There are no major threats to this widespread species.
column53: It is not known from any protected areas.

column11: Mystus krishnensis Ramakrishniah, 1988,  Mystus maydelli Rössel, 1964
column12: Hemibagrus maydelli was originally described as Mystus maydelli by Roessel (1964) from Bhima river at Wadgaon, Maharashtra, India. Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Menon (1999) considered Hemibagrus maydelli as a synonym of Mystus malabaricus, while Jayaram (2003) considered the species valid but thought that it could be a juvenile of another species Mystus krishnensis described by Ramakrishniah (1988) from Nagarjunasagar reservoir, Andhra Pradesh, India. In a review on Hemibagrus, Ng and Ferraris (2000) changed the status of this fish to Hemibagrus maydelli and considered Mystus krishnensis as a synonym, which is now considered as valid (Ferraris 2007).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Raghavan, R., Abraham, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Hemibagrus maydelli is assessed as Least Concern because of its wide distribution which exceeds the threshold for any threatened category. However, it is essential to note that the species has not been recorded from upper reaches of Krishna river in Maharashtra and from its type locality after its first report. Furthermore, the areas from where Hemibagrus maydelli is recorded is threatened by urbanization, industrialization and mining activities and the species is also subject to overfishing and trade at national level.
column26: Hemibagrus maydelli is found in the middle and upper reaches of Krishna river system in Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. It is recorded from Bhima river (Roessel 1964), Tungabhadra river (Ng and Ferraris 2000, Shahnawaz et al. 2010) and Nagarjunasagar reservoir (Ramakrishniah 1988, Jayaram 1995).
column35: No detailed information is available on the population status of Hemibagrus maydelli. However, it is considered as a common fish in the catches of Nagarjungasagar reservaoir (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1995).
column43: Hemibagrus maydelli is found in rivers and reservoirs and it can attain a total length of 1650 mm and a total weight of 58.5 kg (Jayaram 1995).
column49: The areas from where Hemibagrus maydelli is recorded is threatened by urbanization, industrialization and mining activities. Furthermore, overfishing could be a threat to the species.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Hemibagrus maydelli. However, resource and habitat protection and trade and harvest management could be helpful. Research is needed on understanding the population status, life history, ecology, harvest, trade and threats to the species. It is not known from any protected areas.

column12: Hemibagrus punctatus was described by Jerdon (1849) from Cauvery River and its principal tributaries in southern India.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Abraham, R., Shaji, C.P. & Molur, S.
column20: Hemibagrus punctatus was known from three locations from which the species has not been recorded since late 1990s. Subsequent and recent surveys in the rivers have not recorded this species thereby suggesting a drastic decline of close to 100% due to habitat loss and other threats that are not yet clearly understood. The species' identity may need further scrutiny in some locations it has been reported from, and in addition the confirmed locations need to be surveyed thoroughly before its status can be assessed as Extinct. It is therefore presently assessed as Critically Endangered (possibly extinct).
column26: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is known from the Cauvery River and its principal tributaries (Jerdon 1849): Bhavani (Day 1877, Rajan 1955); Moyar (Rajan 1963); Hemavathy (Jayaram 1977); Bharathapuzha, Chaliyar and Kabini (Biju 2005); and Karuvannur (Thomas 2004). This fish was also recorded from the Kalladaippu tank near Tuticorin (Ramanathan et al. 1985); Tungabhadra reservoir (Singit et al. 1987) and the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary (Manimekalan 1998). The Karuvannurpuzha distribution may be erroneous (B.M. Kurup pers. comm.), and the population from Tuticorin and Mudumalai may also be misidentified (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). The identity of the species from Chaliyar and Bharathapuzha is also questionable as the species is found only in east flowing rivers (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column31: Possibly extinct: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu)
column35: In Wyanad, this species has declined drastically in the last 10 years (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.). It was last sighted in 1998 in Kabini River in Wyanad by C.P. Shaji. B.M. Kurup has been surveying the river since 2000 but has not recorded this species even once. It was last recorded in Tungabhadra in the 1980s (Singit et al. 1987) but the recent report of fishes of Bhadra River does not include this species in the checklist (Shahnawaz et al. 2010). It is likely that the species has disappeared from Kabini and Bhadra. The third location, which is Moyar River in Mudumalai was last surveyed in 1990-1992 when the species was collected (Manimekalan 1998). Subsequent surveys in Mudumalai by M. Arunachalam (pers. comm.) did not yield any specimens from 1996 to 2000. The identity of the species from Bhadra and Mudumalai is questionable (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). The population has declined close to 100% in the known locations since the late 1990s. Since it was last recorded in 1998, the species could be extinct.
column43: This fish inhabits rapid rivers and streams (Menon 1999). The species is also known to occur in midland areas with slow to moderate flow, poor vegetation cover, and with mud, sand and gravel as the major substrates (Biju 2005). It prefers pristine, clear water streams and is affected by siltation (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column49: In Wyanad, the species is subjected to habitat degradation and loss due to siltation (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.). Since H. punctatus is known to occur in middle stretches of rivers, it is reasonable to anticipate that they are subjected to ongoing threats from pollution, sand mining and construction of barrages. In Kabini River seasonal fishing in drier seasons in small pools has a major impact on species populations (B.M. Kurup pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the micro-level distribution patterns, population and life history of the species.

column10: English–Günther's Catfish, Bulls Eye Catfish, Golden Red Tail Catfish, Sun Catfish, Yellow Catfish
column11: Pseudobagrus brachysoma Günther, 1864,  Pseudobagrus chryseus Day, 1865
column12: Horabagrus brachysoma was described by Albert Gunther (1864) from Cochin under the name Pseudobagrus brachysoma.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Abraham, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Horabagrus brachysoma is assessed as Vulnerable as populations have undergone declines over the last decade. While the population has declined by more than 50% in most (80%) of its range, recent conservation action in Vembanad and Shastankota lakes in Kerala has increased the populations there by 25%. Overall there has been a 35% decline in the global population due to overexploitation and habitat loss.
column26: The distribution of H. brachysoma is restricted to rivers (and occasionally lakes and backwaters) in the southern region of the Indian subcontinent. This species is known to occur in the Chalakudy, Periyar, Meenachil, Manimala, Pampa, Moovatupuzha and Achenkovil rivers, Vembanad Lake (Ali et al. 2000), Shasthamkotta Lake, Muriyad and Kole wetlands, Chaliyar and Karuvannur River (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.), Kallada River (R. Abraham pers.obs.) in Kerala and the Nethravati River and estuary, Aghanashini and Kali rivers of Karnataka State (Ali et al. 2000). The species occurs commonly in freshwater canals of southern Kerala (V.S. Basheer pers. obs.).
column35: While Prasad (2008) reports that overfishing has resulted in population decline of H. brachysoma in Periyar and Pampa Rivers in Kerala, other reports suggest that the species is actually increasing in population size in Vembanad Lake, Pamba and Achenkovil rivers, Shastankotta Lake (Kurup et al. 2005, Kurup and Kumar 2009). However, the population data and trends in Karnataka are not known. The H. brachysoma population has been artificially increased in two locations in Kerala (Vembanad Lake and Shastankota Lake) where ranching was practised in 2000-2003 and 2006 respectively (V.S. Basheer pers. comm.). The estimated area of increasing populations across its entire range is approximately 20%. While this is the case, the overall population has been undergoing a decline due to overexploitation and habitat loss.
column43: H. brachysoma is a benthic form, primarily occupying lowland areas of rivers and backwaters with mud and sand as substrate, but has also been recorded from the deep pools in hill streams (Ali et al. 2007). This species is an omnivorous and euryphagous feeder (Sreeraj et al. 2006).
column49: Fishing is the major threat to H. brachysoma throughout its range. The unmanaged fishery may lead to a collapse of stocks in several rivers where overfishing has already been demonstrated. In addition, lowland areas of all rivers where the species is known to occur are threatened by pollution, sand mining and reclamation (Ali et al. 2007; Prasad 2008; Sreeraj et al. 2007).
column53: Captive breeding and seed production technology of the species being perfected by the Regional Agricultural Research Station (RARS) of the Kerala Agricultural University (Ali et al. 2007). As the species is known to be overexploited in two rivers of Kerala (Prasad 2008), there is an urgent need to devise management plans for regulating the harvests. Suitable sanctuaries need to be created in its most important habitats to protect spawning stock. Milt cryopreservation is done as part of ex-situ gene banking of this species (NBFGR 2000).

column12: Horabagrus nigricollaris was described by Pethiyagoda and Kottelatt (1994) from Vettilapara on the Chalakudy River, 26 km upstream of Chalakudy Town, Kerala, India.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Krishna , K.K., Basheer, V.S., Abraham, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Horabagrus nigricollaris is assessed as Endangered because of its restricted distribution to two locations in the Chalakudy and Periyar rivers. It has an area of occupancy (AOO) of approximately 40 km_ (based on the recommended AOO estimate method of overlaying a 4 km_ grid on the occupied river area; the actual river area itself is much less than 40 km_), and an extent of occurrence of 2,600 km_. There is also a continuing decline in quality of habitat and ongoing threats from pollution, destructive fishing practices and exotic fish species.
column26: This fish is endemic to Kerala State in Southern India. It is known from the Vettilapara region of  the River Chalakudy (Thomas et al. 2002, Raghavan 2008a, Ali and Prasad 2007, Ali et al. 2008) and the Pooyamkutty region of the River Periyar (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2006, A. Ali pers.obs.) in Kerala, India. The species is known from a river length of 17 km (300 m width) in the Chalakudy River and from 3 km length (300 m wide) in the Pooyankutty River. There is a dam restricting movement on Periyar River (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the current population status of H. nigricollaris. Catch per hour of the species from Vettilapara (Chalakudy River) was recorded to be between 0 and 0.24 (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: Horabagrus nigricollaris is a bottom inhabitant of the upper reaches of streams with rocky and sandy/gravelly bed, and are well adapted to the cold, free flowing waters  (Ali and Prasad 2007). They are also known from pool riffles (Kurup et al. 2004). It is a benthophagic omnivore, showing preference towards animal diet. Its breeding season coincides with the colder months of the year (Ali and Prasad 2007).
column49: In Chalakudy River, H. nigricollaris is threatened by the presence of exotic species, destructive fishing methods, increasing tourism and pollution (Raghavan et al. 2008a,b). There is a possible threat from a proposed hydroelectric power project. In Periyar River, the species is under threat from destructive fishing practices including dynamiting and poisoning (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the current population status and harvest trends in the two areas where they occur (Vettilapara and Pooyamkutty) to inform management plans. Milt cryopreservation studies have been conducted for this species and genetic characterization has been done using molecular markers at NBFGR, Kochi (V.S. Basheer pers. comm.).

column12: This species was originally described as Macronus armatus by Day (1865) from Cochin.
column18: Ali, A., Raghavan, R., Dahanukar, N. & Molur, S.
column20: Mystus armatus is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
column26: Mystus armatus is known from the Western Ghats of Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu (Kurup et al. 2004; Jayaram 2010). Its report from Manipur and Myanmar (Jayaram and Sanyal 2003) needs conformation.
column31: Native: Bangladesh; India (Kerala, Manipur, Nagaland); Myanmar
column35: This is a rare species.
column43: Pool-riffle habitats with a gravelly or sandy bottom (Kurup et al. 2005).
column49: It is generally threatened by the drying of streams, siltation, organic and other pollution and introduced species.
column53: It is known from Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary. No direct conservation measures are in place.

column12: Mystus keletius was originally described as Bagrus keletius by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1840) from Pondicherry, India. Ng (2002) suggested that M. keletius was a synonym of either M. armatus or M. vittatus, while Ferraris (2007) considered M. keletius as a synonym of M. vittatus. Since M. keletius is only known only from its lectotype the species is open to question (R. Pethiyagoda pers. comm. 2010).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Arunachalam, M., Basheer, V.S., Abraham, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Mystus keletius is assessed as Least Concern because of a very wide distribution in southern India, with no specific wide spread threats, although the species is found to be very rare. It is also important to note that the species is known only from its lectotype and thus the taxonomic validity of this species is open to question .
column26: Cuvier and Valenciennes (1840) described Mystus keletius from Pondicherry, India and Java. Recently, Ng (2002) suggested that M. keletius from Java was a synonym of M. nigriceps and restricted M. keletius to India. Record of M. keletius from Sri Lanka (Jayaram 1999, Jayaram and Sanyal 2003, Weliange and Amarasinghe 2007) was recently rejected by Pethiyagoda et al. (2008) who described the so called Sri Lankan M. keletius as a new species M. ankutta. In India M. keletius is known from Karnataka (Prasad et al. 2009, Martin et al. 2000, Rao and Shachar 1927, Sreekantha et al. 2007), Kerala (Raghavan et al. 2008) and Tamil Nadu (Daniels and Rajagopal 2004, Raj 1916). Record of the fish from Punjab (Johal and Tandon 1979) may be a misidentification (Jayaram 1999).
column35: Population status of Mystus keletius is not precisely known but the species is considered as rare (Prasad et al. 2009, Rao and Shachar 1927). Martin et al. (2000) estimated the relative abundance of the fish to be 0.93 to 1.41 % in Tamiraparani River, Tamil Nadu
column43: Mystus keletius is found in rivers (Raghavan et al. 2008), lakes/wetlands (Daniels and Rajagopal 2004, Prasad et al. 2009) and reservoirs (Sreekantha et al. 2007).
column49: No information is available on specific threats to Mystus keletius. General threats such as sand mining, habitat change, destructive fishing practices, pollution from sewage, effluents and solid waste may impact the species in certain areas.
column53: Currently there is no conservation action plan directed towards Mystus keletius. Research is needed on taxonomy, population status, life history, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Mystus montanus was originally described as Bagrus montanus by Jerdon (1849) from Manantoddy (Mananthavady) in Wynaad, Kerala, India. Day (1877) changed the generic status of the fish to Macrones and Hora (1942) changed it to Mystus.
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Arunachalam, M. & Molur, S.
column20: Mystus montanus is assessed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed in the peninsular India and it is also common in several areas. It is cultivated commercially in Tamil Nadu. Furthermore, there are no specific threats identified for this species.
column26: Mystus montanus is definitely found in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. In Kerala it is known from Manantoday in Wynaad (Jerdon 1849), Ponmni estuary (Bijukumar and Sushama 2000) and in Chalakkudy River, Muvattupuzha River and Periyar River (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009). In Tamil Nadu it is known from Thiroomurthi Dam, Parambikulam, Kallapuram and Amaravathi (Devi et al. 2007). The species is also reported from Eastern  Ghats (Devi and Indra 2003) and Anamalai Hill Ranges (Devi et al. 2005) but exact point localities are missing. This species is also recorded from the Kancheepuram and Kanyakumari districts in Tamil Nadu but the exact locations are missing (Rajagopal and Davidar 2008).  It is reported from the Nilgiris Bisophere, Travancroe, Achankovil, Periyar and Kabani rivers (Kurup et al. 2004). It has also been recorded from Pavna River (Chandanshive et al. 2007) and Bhima river (Suter 1944) in Maharashtra. Yadav (2003) has suggested that the species is found in Krishna river system and Cauvery river system, however, exact localities are missing. It is also reported from Madhya Pradesh (Sarkar and Lakra 2007). All these records need validation. Presence of Mystus montanus in northeastern India especially in Assam and Arunachal Pradesh (Tamang et al. 2007, Bagra et al. 2009) could be attributed to the synonymization of M. montanus dibrugarensis with this species. This needs taxonomic verification.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh - Presence Uncertain, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu)
column35: Exact population structure of Mystus montanus is unknown. However, it is very common in Chalakkudy River, Muvattupuzha River and Periyar River (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009). The species may be common in other parts of its distribution range.
column43: Mystus montanus is found in streams, rivers, lakes and reservoirs (Devi et al. 2005, 2007). It is also found in estuaries (Bijukumar and Sushama 2000). It attains a total length of 15 cm (Menon 1999). It is found in deep pools in higher altitudes with sandy or muddy substrate (Kurup et al. 2004). No information is available about habitat changes and its effects on this species.
column49: No specific information available on threats to Mystus montanus.
column53: Currently there is no conservation action plan directed towards Mystus montanus. Research is essential on taxonomic ambiguity, population status, distribution, life history, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species. Some population of the species is likely to be protected in the Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Devi et al. 2007).

column12: Mystus occulatus was described by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1840) from erstwhile Malabar (Kerala).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Arunachalam, M., Basheer, V.S. & Molur, S.
column20: Mystus occulatus has been listed as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution, occurring in the low land rivers, wetlands and estuaries of Kerala and river systems in Tamil Nadu. Although the species may be affected by general anthropogenic impacts on its habitats, there is no information to substantiate that this species may be threatened as a result.
column26: Mystus oculatus is endemic to Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known to occur in almost all river systems of Kerala (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000) including backwaters (Menon et al. 2000) and wetlands (Thomas et al. 2003). Also recorded from Bhavani River in Tamil Nadu (Arockiaraj et al. 2004).  It has been reported from 18 rivers by Kurup at al. (2004).
column35: Since it is a small fish with no fishery importance, the trends are unknown. The species is found in low abundance.
column43: Inhabits rivers in plains, estuaries (Menon 1999) and wetlands (Thomas et al. 2003). It occupies pool and riffle habitats with gravelly or sandy bottom (Kurup et al. 2005).
column49: There are no species specific threats. However, since this species is known from low land rivers, estuaries and backwaters, it is reasonable to state that threats including sand mining, pollution from domestic and industrial waste, eutrophication, destructive fishing practices and reclamation of wetlands would have some effect on their survival (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place for this species although conservation initiative are in place for all inland fishes in Kerala as per the Inland Fishery Bill, 2010.

column12: Mystus seengtee was originally described as Pimelodus seengtee by Sykes (1839, 1841) from Bhima river at Pairgaon, Maharashtra, India. It was previously included as a synonym of M. cavasius, however, recently M. seengtee was resurrected as a valid species (Chakrabarty and Ng 2005).
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Arunachalam, M., Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Mystus seengtee is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed in southern India and there are no known major threats to the species. Nevertheless, research is needed on population trends, harvesting trends and threats. Taxonomic status needs to be validated using molecular techniques.
column26: Mystus seengtee is known from the Krishna and Cauvery river drainages in southern India and it is very likely to be found in most other river drainages south of the Krishna River drainage (Chakrabarty and Ng 2005). Pethiyagoda et al. (2008) suspects the presence of some species closer to Mystus seengtee in Sri Lanka. Since M. seengtee was resurrected from its synonymy with M. cavasius only recently and because this taxonomic revision has not yet reached all the workers, records of M. cavasius from Maharashtra (Fraser 1942, Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, Chandanshive et al. 2007, Jadhav and Yadav 2009), Karnataka (Rao and Seshachar 1927, David 1956, Bhat 2004, Venkateshwarlu and Somashekar 2005, Sreekantha et al. 2007, Prasad et al. 2009, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Krishna river system of Andhra Pradesh (Chandrasekhar 2004), Tamil Nadu (Rajan 1955, Manimekalan 1998, Daniels and Rajagopal 2004) and Kerala (Silas 1949, 1951, Shaji et al. 1995, Ajithkumar et al. 1999, Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, Thomas et al. 2002, Raghavan et al. 2008) should be considered as M. seengtee. The species is probably present in Goa as well.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: Information on the population trends in Mystus seengtee is not available. However, it is common in Maharashtra (Kharat et al. 2000, Neelesh Dahanukar, pers. obs.) and Karnataka (Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009), while it is relatively rare in Andhra Pradesh (Chandrasekhar 2004), Tamil Nadu (Manimekalan 1998) and Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002).  Some reports indicate the species is common in Kerala (Kurup et al. 2005).
column43: Mystus seengtee is found in large streams, rivers and wetlands.
column49: No specific information is available on threats to Mystus seengtee.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place.  Research is essential on the population trends, harvesting trends and threats to the species.

column11: Arius pavimentatus Valenciennes, 1840; Gogrius sykesii Day, 1867; Phractocephalus gogra Sykes, 1839
column12: Rita gogra was originally described as Phractocephalus gogra by Sykes (1839) from Bhima and Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune, Maharashtra, India. Subsequently Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1840) described Arius pavimentatus and Day (1867) described Gogrius sykesii both of which are now synonymized with Rita gogra (Jayaram 1966, Ferraris 2007). Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Menon (1999) wrongly treated Phractocephalus gogra and Gogrius sykesii as synonyms of Rita pavimentatus.
column18: Cox, N.A. & Shrikant, J.
column20: Rita gogra is assessed as Least Concern solely based on the fact that the species is expected to be widely distributed in central India. Furthermore, there is no documentation on specific global threat to the species. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that in some areas the population of this species has declined drastically and it could be attributed to habitat alterations caused by urbanization and increasing organic and inorganic pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting. If such trends are also recorded from other areas, the species may qualify for some threatened category.
column26: Rita gogra is endemic to India and is found in Krishna, Godavari and Narmada river basins of five states, namely Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. In Maharashtra it is known from Indrayani River (Dahanukar et al, Unpublished), Mula-Mutha River (Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003), Bhima river (Sykes 1841), Neera River (Ghate and Pawar 1992), Panchaganga River (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956) and Nanded (Jayaram 1966). In Karnataka it is known from Tungabahdra River (David 1956, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahnawaz et al. 2010). In Andhra Pradesh it is known from Kurnool (Day 1867), Krishna-Tungabhadra Sangam (Chacko and Kuriyan 1948) and Nizamsagar road Bridge (Jayaram 1966). The species is also known from Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh (Chandra and Sharma 2007, Dubey 2007, Sarkar and Lakra 2007, Vyas et al. 2007), however, exact point localities are missing. Thus, the species is widespread in central India with an inferred extent of occurrence between 470000-490000 km2.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra)
column35: Rita gogra is suggested to be common in Krishna river system in Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh (Jayaram 1995, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009). However, the species has experienced rapid decline in the Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.), probably because of the pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting of the fish. The species is rare in Godavari river (S. Jadhav pers. comm.). Population trend for the fish form other areas is not known.
column43: Rita gogra is found in large rivers and attains a total length of 26 cm (Menon 1999). Gravid females of the fish are found during June and July indicating that the fish breeds during monsoon season (Dahanukar et al, Unpublished). The habitat of this fish is severely threatened by urbanization and organic and inorganic pollution in most of its range in northern Western Ghats (Kharat et al. 2000, 2003, N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column49: It is possible that the habitat alterations caused by urbanization and increasing organic and inorganic pollution of the rivers could affect the species adversely. The species is perhaps also threatened by heavy harvesting.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place directed towards Rita gogra. Research is needed on the population status, livelihood value, harvest levels and threats to the species. It is present in the Nathsagar Reservoir protected area, Aurangabad (Yadav 2005).

column11: Arius hastatus Valenciennes, 1840,  Phractocephalus kuturnee Sykes, 1839,  Rita hastata (Valenciennes, 1840)
column12: Rita kuturnee was originally described as Phractocephalus kuturnee by Sykes (1839) from Bhima river, Maharashtra. Subsequently, Valenciennes described Arius hastatus (Cuvier and Valenciennes 1840), which is now considered as a synonym of Rita kuturnee (Jayaram 1966, Ferraris 2007).
column18: Shrikant, J. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Rita kuturnee is expected to be widely distributed in central India and there is no information on population trends or wide spread threats to the species. The species is therefore assessed as Least Concern. However, the population of this species in upper reaches of Krishna river has declined drastically and the species is possible threatened by urbanization, pollution and heavy harvesting. If such population trends are reported from other parts of its distribution, the species may qualify for a threatened category.
column26: Rita kuturnee is endemic to India and it is found in Krishna and Godavari river basin in Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Chhattisgarh states. The species is recorded from Bhima river (Sykes 1841), Mula-Mutha River (Fraser 1942, Kharat et al. 2003), Godavari river (Rahimullah 1943, Jayaram 1966), Panchaganga River (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956), Purna river (Rahimullah 1943), Nizamsagar (Jayaram 1966), Kurnool (Jayaram 1966), Gadwal (Rahimullah 1943), Krishna-Tungabhadra Sangam (Chacko and Kuriyan 1948), Alampur (Rahimullah 1943), Badra river (David 1956), Tunga river (Rao and Seshachar 1927), Bhima-Krishna Sangam (Rahimullah 1943) and Chhattisgarh (Sarkar and Lakra 2007). Record of the fish from Myanmar (Jayaram 1966) is erroneous (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). Record of this species from Cauvery river drainage (Yadav 2003) is also doubtful.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Karnataka, Maharashtra)
column35: Rita kuturnee is considered to be a very common species by Jayaram (1995), while Yadav (2003) considers the fish as uncommon. Nevertheless, the population of this species has declined drastically in the Mula-Mutha and Bhima rivers and it is possible that the species is locally extinct in Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (N. Dahnaukar, pers. obs.). Increasing urbanization and pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting of fish resources, which are common in some of the areas where the fish is found (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2001, 2003), could be the driving force towards the population declines. However, since no information is available on population trends from other areas, the population decline cannot be generalized.
column43: Rita kuturnee is found in large rivers and is restricted to freshwater (Menon 1999). It attains a total length of 30 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). No specific information is available on the habitat decline for this fish, however, the area in which the fish is found is severely affected by pollution, urbanization and heavy harvesting of fish (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2001, 2003).
column49: Specific threats to Rita kuturnee are not known. However, the species could be threatened by habitat alterations caused by urbanization and pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting of the fish.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place directed towards Rita kuturnee. Research is needed on population trends, harvesting and threats to the species. It is present in the Nathsagar Reservoir, Aurangabad (Yadav 2005).

column12: Balitora mysorensis was first described by Hora (1941) from Sivasamudram, Cauvery drainage, Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Balitora mysorensis is assessed as Vulnerable because of its restricted distribution within the Western Ghats with an AOO of less than 200 km2, and in less than 10 severely fragmented locations, and an on-going decline in habitat quality at key localities where the species is found.
column26: Balitora mysorensis is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). In Kerala it is known from the rivers Kabini (Gopi 2000), Bhavani (Kurup et al. 2004; Shaji and Easa 2003), Bharathapuzha (Kurup et al. 2004), Periyar (Menon 1987) and Achenkovil (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2006) and in Karnataka from the Tungabhadra (Gopi 2000, Shahnawaz and Venkateswarlu 2009, Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2008) and Cauvery drainages (Gopi 2000). The record of B. mysorensis from the Kohlapur area of Maharashtra (Gopi 2000) needs to be confirmed.  Although the extent is slightly wide (<25000 km2), the area of occupancy is restricted to less than 200 km2.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain)
column35: There is no information on the population status of B. mysorensis. It is generally a rare species. This species is known to be more common in Karnataka (Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009) compared to Kerala where it is very rare (Thomas et al. 2002, Gopi 2000).
column43: B. mysorensis inhabits torrential streams (Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009) where they are observed attached to bedrock, cobbles and boulders (Shaji and Easa 2003).
column49: The habitats of B. mysorensis in many of the river systems where they occur are threatened by pollution from plantations, as well as destructive fishing practices including dynamiting and poisoning (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000, A. Ali pers. obs.). Taking into account the restricted distribution, unmanaged collections for the aquarium pet trade may be a potential future threat to this species in the Western Ghats.
column53: No known conservation actions are in place. It is present in Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary and Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary (Rahul Kumar pers. obs). There is a need to generate baseline information on the distribution, life history and population status of this species from the two southern Indian states where they occur - Karnataka and Kerala.
column60: Ali, A. & Raghavan, R. 2010. Balitora mysorensis. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 19 October 2011.

column12: Homaloptera menoni was described by Shaji and Easa (1995) from Indekkuthodu, a tributary of River Bhavani at Siruvani, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Homaloptera menoni is assessed as Least Concern as although it has a restricted distribution inside the Silent Valley National Park (Kerala, India) there are no current or plausible future threats to the species or its habitat.
column26: Homaloptera menoni is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the rivers Bhavani (Shaji and Easa 1995) and Kunthipuzha tributary of Bharatapuzha (Kurup et al. 2004).
column35: There is no information on the population status of Homaloptera menoni. It is known from only a few specimens.
column43: It inhabits high altitude torrential streams with riffles and cascades as microhabitats (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).
column49: There are no known threats to H. menoni in its native range. The entire range of the species falls within a highly protected area in the Western Ghats - the Silent Valley National Park.
column53: The entire range of the species is well protected as it falls within the Silent Valley National Park. There is however a need to generate baseline information on the population status and life history of the species.

column10: English–Anamalai Loach, Zig Zag Sucker Fish
column12: Homaloptera montana was first described by Herre (1941) from a brook flowing through the Puthuthottam estate in Valparai, Anamalai Hills, Tamil Nadu, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: H. montana is listed as Endangered, as the species has a restricted distribution with a continuing decline in its area of occupancy of less than 50 km2 and extent of occurrence of less than 2000 km2 and in the quality of habitat. The species is threatened by exotic species and pollution due to pesticide run-off from tea and coffee plantations.
column26: Homaloptera montana is endemic to the Anamalai landscapes in the Western Ghats. Known from streams passing through tea plantations in Valparai (Raghavan et al. 2008a; Kurup 2002), Chandanthodu, a small tributary of Chalakudy River near Malakkapara (Shaji and Easa 2005). Even after repeated surveys the species has not been caught from Silent Valley National Park indicating the current known presence only in the Anamalai Hills.
column35: There is no information on the population status of H. montana. This is a rare species (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs).
column43: It inhabits torrential streams (Menon 1999) with high gradient riffles and cascades as microhabitat (Kurup et al. 2005; Raghavan et al. 2008a).
column49: In part of its range (Valparai and Malakkapara), H.montana is under threat from the decline in the quality of its habitats which are under stress from run-off of pesticides and associated chemicals used in tea plantations, and also the proliferation of exotic species (Raghavan et al. 2008a, b).
column53: No conservation plans are in place. As the quality of habitat in areas where the species is known to occur is subject to on-going degradation, there is an urgent need for habitat restoration.

column12: Homaloptera pillaii was described from the Kunthi tributary of Bharatapuzha River inside the Silent Valley National Park by Indra and Remadevi (1981).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Homaloptera pillaii is assessed as Least Concern as although it occurs in a single location and has a highly restricted range of less than 1500 km2 and area of only 15 km2, the entire distribution range is within a highly protected area with no plausible threats to the species or the habitat.
column26: Endemic to the tributaries of Bharatapuzha River inside the Silent Valley National Park, and Bhavani River Kerala, India (Kurup et al. 2004; Indra and Remadevi 1981; Easa and Basha 1995)
column35: There is no information on the population status of H. pillaii. The species is rare as in spite of detailed sampling at its type localities, only 3 individuals could be recorded in one week (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers.obs.).
column43: Inhabits high altitude torrential streams with high gradient riffles and cascades as microhabitat (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs).
column49: There is no known current threat to Homoloptera pillaii in its native range. The species occurs within the Silent Valley National Park, which is a high priority protected area within the Western Ghats.
column53: No species specific conservation actions are in place. There is however a need to carry out research into the population status and life history of the species.

column12: Homaloptera santhamparaiensis was described by Arunachalam et al (2002) from Panniyar stream of River Periyar, Idukki District, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: H. santhamparaiensis is listed as Endangered since it is known only from two locations in the Santhamparai Hills, Idukki, Kerala with an area of occupancy and extent of occurrence less than 20 km2 and 3000km2, respectively, and where there is an on-going decline in quality of habitat due to pollution from plantations of tea and cardamom.
column26: Homaloptera santhamparaiensis is endemic to the Western Ghats, known only from the Panniyar stream (Periyar River) and the Mathikettan Solai stream in the Santhamparai Hills, Idukki District, Kerala, India (Arunachalam et al. 2002)
column35: There is no information on the population of H. santhamparaiensis.
column43: Known to occur in pool riffles in high altitude streams with boulders and bed rocks as major substrates (Arunachalam et al. 2002; Arunachalam 2000).
column49: The habitat of H. santhamparaiensis in the Panniyar stream is threatened by pollution from tea and cardamom plantations (Arunachalam et al. 2002).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. As the species is poorly studied, there is an urgent need to document its life history, population and ecology.
column59: Arunachalam, M. 2000. Assemblage structure of stream fishes in the Western Ghats (India). Hydrobiologia 430: 1-31.; Arunachalam, M., Johnson, J.A., and Rema Devi, K. 2002. column11: Longischistura striata (Day, 1867),  Nemacheilus striatus Day, 1867, Nemachilus bhimachari Hora, 1937
column12: This species was originally described under the genus Nemacheilus by Day (1867) from the Wayanad.
column18: Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Ali, A., Cox, N.A. & Krishna , K.K.
column20: The species is endemic to the Western Ghats, India where it has been recorded from Vythiri, Noolpuzha and Tholpetty in Wayanad (Kerala). It has also been recorded from Tamil Nadu and Karnataka (bordering this area) where it is threatened by pollution from sedimentation and pesticides, and loss of habitat due to the removal of tree canopy and harvest for trade. The species is found in only two catchments (interpreted as two locations) and, as it is a habitat specialist (only found in areas with more than 50% of canopy), it has an area of occupancy of less than 500 km_.
column26: The species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. It has been recorded from Vythiri, Noolpuzha and Tholpetty in Wayanad (Kerala), and has also been recorded from Tamil Nadu and Karnataka (bordering this area). Records of this species from Mula-Mutha River of Pune (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963) is doubtful (Kharat et al. 2003). Similarly, report of this species from Nira river at Veer Dam (Ghate and Pawar 1992) may refer to a yet undescribed species (N. Dahanukar et al., manuscript in review).
column35: This is a rare species.
column43: This species prefers streams with a sandy or pebbly bottom where the current is very slow. It is only found in areas with more than 50% of canopy.
column49: It is threatened by pollution from sedimentation and pesticides. Loss of habitat due to the removal of tree canopy, and harvest for trade also pose threats for this species.
column53: It has been recorded from Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary. Further studies are needed into the distribution, population trends and threats to this species.

column11: Nemacheilus pambarensis Rema Devi & Indra, 1994,  Noemacheilus pambarensis Rema Devi & Indra, 1994
column12: Mesonoemacheilus pamabarensis was described by Rema Devi and Indra (1994) from Pambar River in Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Mesonoemacheilus pambarensis is listed as Vulnerable as it has a restricted distribution in the Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary, Kerala, India with an area of occupancy less than 10km2, and is plausibly threatened by competition with alien invasive species.
column26: Mesonoemacheilus pamabarensis is endemic to the Western Ghats, known only from the Pambar river inside the Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary, Kerala, India (Kurup et al. 2004, Remadevi and Indra 1994).
column35: There is no information on the population status of M. pambarensis. It is an uncommon species.
column43: The species is seen in high gradient riffle habitats with cobbles and boulders as the major substrates (A. Ali  pers.obs.).
column49: The species is possibly threatened by introduced exotic Tilapia, Oreochromis mossambicus.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is found inside the Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary. There is a need to study the life history, population and ecology of the species and the possibility of competition with invasive species (e.g. Tilapia, Oreochromis mossambicus).

column12: Mesonoemacheilus remadevii was first described by Shaji (2002) from Poochippara, Kunthi tributary of Bharatapuzha River in Silent Valley, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Mesonoemacheilus remadevii is assessed as Least Concern as although it has a restricted distribution to a single location inside the Silent Valley National Park (Kerala, India) there are no current or plausible future threats to its habitat.
column26: Mesonoemacheilus remadevii is endemic to the Western Ghats, known only from the Kunthi tributary (Bharatapuzha River) inside Silent Valley National Park, Kerala, India (Shaji 2002).
column35: There is no information on the population status of M. remadevii.
column43: Known from torrential streams with cobbles and sand as the major substratum (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column49: There are no current threats to M. remadevii in the Silent Valley National Park as it is highly protected and free from any anthropogenic disturbances.
column53: No known conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the population and life history of this poorly known hill stream loach.

column11: Nemachilus anguilla Annandale, 1919,  Nemachilus poonaensis Menon, 1950
column12: Nemacheilus anguilla was described by Annandale (1919) from Yenna River at Medha, Satara District, Maharashtra (Bombay Mumbai Presidency), India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus anguilla is listed as Least Concern as although there are threats to parts of its range, it is very widespread and not considered to be threatened with extinction.
column26: Nemacheilus anguilla is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004), known from the Mula-Mutha River, Maharahstra (Wagh and Ghate 2003, Chandanshive et al. 2007); Sharavathi (Sreekantha et al. 2007, 2008); Bhadra and Kali rivers in Karnataka and Pampa river in Kerala (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2009). It has also been recorded (as N. hoonensis) from the Anshi and Gangawali drainage in northern Karnataka (Banarescu and Nalbant 1968).
column35: There is no information on the population of N. anguilla. It can be a locally common species.
column43: Occurs in streams with pebbles and sand as major substrate (Menon 1999).
column49: Streams from where N. anguilla have been recorded is being subjected to pollution from both domestic and industrial effluents (Chandanshive et al. 2007, Bhat 2004, Sreekantha and Ramachandra 2005, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), exotic species (Chandanshive et al. 2007) and sand mining (Padmalal et al. 2007). In Pamba River the species is threatened by organic pollution resulting from an influx of more than a million pilgrims over a three month time frame.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is present in some protected areas. There is a need to study population and life history of the species, with reference to the threats in various river systems from where they have been recorded.

column12: Nemacheilus denisoni is described by Day in 1867 from the Bhavani River at the base of the Nilgiris. Described under the genus Noemacheilus and now referred to as Schistura. Schistura denisoni have several subspecies like S.d.denisoni, S.d. dayi, S.d. mukambbikaensis and S.d. pambaensis (Menon 1987).
column18: Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Molur, S., Cox, N.A. & Ali, A.
column20: Schistura denisoni is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
column26: Schistura denisoni is found widely distributed throughout the Western Ghats and some rivers of Rajasthan in India (Menon 1987).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu)
column35: This is a common species throughout its range.
column43: It is usually associated with rivers and streams with a cobble, pebble or boulder substrate.
column49: It is threatened in parts of its range by pollution (siltation, domestic organic waste, pesiticides), dynamite and poison fishing and collection for the aquarium trade.
column53: It is present in many protected areas. There is a need to prevent illegal fishing (i.e. dynamiting) and to better regulate the aquarium trade in this species.
column59: IUCN. 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species (ver. 2011.1). Available at: http://www.iucnredlist.org. (Accessed: 16 June 2011).; Menon A.G.K. 1987. The Fauna of India and Adjacent Countries (Pisces - Teleostei - Cobitidea - Homalopteridae). Zoological Survey of India, Calcutta.

column12: Nemacheilus guentheri was described by Day (1867) from the rapids on the slopes of Neilgherry (Nilgiri) hills, South India. Listed as Mesonemacheilus guentheri.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus guentheri is assessed as Least Concern as it is a wide spread species in the three Western Ghats southern states, found in almost all river systems of the Kerala part of Western Ghats with no species specific threats.
column26: Nemacheilus guentheri is endemic to Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from almost all river systems of Kerala (Shaji and Easa 2003) including Chandragiri, Neeleswaram, Kuppam, Valapattanam, Mahe, Kuttiadi, Chaliyar, Kabini,  Bhavani, Bharatapuzha (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000), Karuvannur (Thomas 2004), Chalakudy (Raghavan et al. 2008), Periyar (Arun et al. 1996), Muvattupuzha, Manimala, Pamba, Achenkovil, Pambar, Kallada, Vamanapuram (Thomas 2004) and Cauvery river system in Nilgiris and Mysore (Menon 1999).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka - Presence Uncertain, Kerala, Tamil Nadu - Presence Uncertain)
column35: There is no information on the population status of N. guentheri. It is a fairly common species.
column43: It prefers hill streams with gravel, cobbles, bedrock and a little amount of sand as substrates. Also occurs in middle reaches with gravel and pebbles as the major substrates (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000). N. guentheri feeds on benthic macroinvertebrates, algal and plant matters, larvae of aquatic insects, chironomid larvae and detritus (Thomas 2004).
column49: Since the species is found in almost all river systems of Kerala, general threats to these river systems including pollution, sedimentation, exotic fish and destructive fishing may be applicable to N. guentheri also. Collection for the international aquarium pet trade may be a possible future threat unless the harvests are managed through quotas and catch limits (Ragahavan 2010).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is present in some protected areas. There is a need to generate baseline information on the life history and population status of this species.

column12: Nemacheilus keralensis was described by Rita and Nalbant (1978) from Pampadumpara, a tributary of River Periyar in Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus keralensis is listed as Vulnerable as it has a restricted distribution (microhabitat specialist) occurring in five fragmented locations, with an area of occupancy of less than 600 km2 and a extent of occurrence of less than 8,000 km2 with a continuing decline in quality of habitat. In addition there are on-going threats from exotic species and pollution.
column26: Nemacheilus keralensis is endemic to the southern part of the Western Ghats in the state of Kerala, India.Since its first description from Periyar drainage (Rita et al. 1978), the species has been subsequently recorded from Sabarigiri hills in Pampa drainage (Menon 1987), Eravikulam National Park (Thomas et al.1999), Kaitapara area of Kaliyar tributary in the Muvattupuzha river (Thomas et al. 2001, Remadevi et al. 2002), Santhamapara area of Periyar River (Arunachalam et al. 2000, Remadevi et al. 2002) and Vagamon area of River Meenachil (Kurup et al. 2004, Thomas 2004). It is also suspected that the reports of N. evezardi by Zacharias et al. (1996) from Periyar Lake may actually be that of N. keralensis (Remadevi et al. 2002). However, the reports of N. keralanesis in Phansad stream of River Nirar in Maharashtra by Arunachalam (2000) needs further verification.
column35: There is no information on the population of N. keralaensis. It is an uncommon species.
column43: It inhabits high altitude streams with bedrock, cobbles, gravel, as major substrates. It is mostly seen attached to the rocky bottom of the streams.  N. keralensis mainly feeds on algae followed by invertebrates, plants and detritus (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000).
column49: Local populations of N. keralensis inside Eravikulam National Park are threatened by exotic species (Thomas et al. 1999) and those in Muvattupuzha and Meenachil rivers by pollution from domestic and agricultural wastes (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers.obs.). If the records of N. keralensis inside Periyar National Park are confirmed, then the local populations may be under threat from exotic fish species that have already colonised Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006; Periyar Foundation 2006) and also pollution (Kurup 2004).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. This species has been recorded from some protected areas. There is a need to document the biology, demography and ecology of this species.

column12: Nemacheilus kodaguensis was described by Menon (1987) from Kootu Hole, near Madikeri, (Cauvery basin), Karnataka, India. Should also be listed as Schistura kodaguensis.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Schistura kodaguensis is currently known only from a single location in the Cauvery headwater stream in Kodagu. Although there is a possibility of the species found in other areas, information available indicate its restricted area of less than 20 km2 and the plausible threats of pesticide runoff from the surrounding cardamom and pepper plantations.  The species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Schistura kodaguensis is known to occur in a single stream in the Cauvery River basin in Coorg (Menon 1987, Sreekantha et al 2006). However, the species may be more widespread.
column35: There is no information on the population of N. kodaguensis.
column43: Known to occur in a shallow swift stream with a gravelly bottom (Menon 1999).
column49: No information is available on the threats to N. kodaguensis.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is not present in any protected areas. There is a need to generate population and biological information on this species.

column11: Mesonoemacheilus menoni (Zacharias & Minimol, 1999),  Noemacheilus menoni Zacharias & Minimol, 1999
column12: Nemacheilus menoni was described from Mlappara in the upper reaches of the Periyar River by Zacharias and Minimol (1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus menoni is assessed as Vulnerable as the species has a restricted distribution inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala, India occurring in less than 5 locations and with the potential threat from exotic fish such as O. mossambicus, C. gariepinus and C. carpio introduced into the streams.
column26: Nemacheilus menoni is endemic to the Western Ghats in the southern Indian state of Kerala, where it occurs in the upstream reaches of Periyar River (Zacharias and Minimol 1999).  It has a highly restricted distribution occurring in an area of less than 100 km2 and extent of 5000 km2 in the Mullayar and Periyar tributaries within the Tiger Reserve (A. Ali and R. Raghavan and Shaji pers. obs.).
column35: No information on population is available. It is common in the Periyar Tiger Reserve (C.P. Shaji pers.comm.).
column43: Occurs in fast flowing streams with cobbles, pebbles and sand as substrate (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).
column49: Alien invasive species such as O. mossambicus, C. gariepinus and C. carpio may be potential threats to the endemic fish.
column53: No conservation actions currently in place. It is present in Periyar Tiger Reserve. No information on biology, life history, demography are available and so the current status of the fish in wild is unknown.  The impacts of exotics on the species needs to be urgently studied with measures taken to remove and halt introduction of exotics into Periyar Tiger Reserve and other streams this species is in.
