column12: Nemacheilus monilis was described by Hora (1921) from Bhavani River, Mettupalayam (Nilgiris), Tamil Nadu.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus monilis is assessed as Least Concern as although it has a restricted distribution, there are no known current or plausible future threats.
column26: Nemacheilus monilis is endemic to the southern region of the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from Bhavani (Rajan 1955, Easa and Basha 1995), Moyar (Rajan 1963), Kabini (Kurup et al. 2004), Chinnar (Indra et al. 1998) Pambar Rivers (Thomas 2004, Kurup et al. 2004), and the Anamalai Hills (Devi et al. 2005).
column35: There is no information on the population status of N. monilis; although many researchers have treated it as a rare species (Menon 1999, Thomas et al. 2002).
column43: N. monilis prefers run, glide and cascade habitats in streams with gravel, pebbles and cobbles as the major substrates (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000). In River Kabini the species has been collected from rapid habitats (Kurup et al. 2004).
column49: There are no known threats to N. monilis.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is present in some protected areas including the Silent Valley National Park in Kerala. There is a need to generate baseline information on the life history and demography of this species.

column11: Cobitis mooreh Sykes, 1839, Nemacheilus sinuatus Day, 1870
column12: Nemacheilus mooreh was described by Sykes (1839) from Deccan, India. Nemacheilus sinuatus (Day 1870) and N. aureus (Day 1872) are considered junior synonyms of this species.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus mooreh has been assessed as Least Concern, as while there are threats to the species in parts of its range, it is widely distributed and not considered to be at risk of extinction.
column26: Endemic to Peninsular India and known from upper Godavary and upper Krishna drainages in Maharashtra, Arakku Valley (Andhra Pradesh) and Waynad, Nilgiris (Tamil Nadu/Kerala) (Menon 1999).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka - Presence Uncertain, Kerala - Presence Uncertain, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu - Presence Uncertain)
column35: There is no information on the population of N. mooreh from the Western Ghats. It is a fairly common species.
column43: Like other nemacheiline loaches, this species also inhabits fast flowing streams with sandy or pebbly substrates. Can be found in stands of aquatic vegetation (Cryptocoryne species). It breeds twice in a year, once during August-September and during February-March (Kharat et al. 2008).
column49: It is threatened in parts of its range by pollution, including siltation of streams resulting from deforestation of surrounding areas.
column53: There is a need to generate baseline information on the distribution, population status and threats to this poorly known species. It is presumed to be present in some protected areas.

column12: Described by Menon in 1987 from the Pykara Dam, Nilgiri District, Tamil Nadu, India.
column18: Ali, A., Raghavan, R., Cox, N.A. & Dahanukar, N.
column20: Nemacheilus nilgiriensis is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed with few threats.
column26: Nemacheilus nilgiriensis has been recorded from Wayanad in Kerala, from Karnataka and from Tamil Nadu.
column35: This is a common species in suitable habitat.
column43: This species is found in very slow flowing streams with a sandy and pebbly substrate. These areas need to be shaded by the canopy.
column49: The species is threatened by pollution from agriculture.
column53: It is in a number of protected areas.

column12: Nemacheilus periyarensis was first described from Thannikudy in the upper reaches of the Periyar River by Kurup and Radhakrishnan (2005). This species is known to show close resemblance to N. pulchellus in its colouration and body characteristics, but is distinguished from the latter by the presence of nine branched rays in the dorsal fin against 10.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus periyarensis has been assessed as Vulnerable because it occurs at a single location with an area of occupancy of less than 10 km_. Although it occurs in a protected area with no threats to the habitat, the probability of three exotic species threatening the species is very high in the near future.
column26: Nemacheilus periyarensis is endemic to the Western Ghats in the southern Indian state of Kerala, where it occurs in the upstream reaches of Periyar River (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2005). It has a highly restricted distribution occurring in an area of less than 10 km_ in the Thanikkudy region of Periyar Tiger Reserve (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.).
column35: There is no information on the population of N. periyarensis.
column43: Occurs in fast-flowing streams with cobbles, pebbles and sand as substrate (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).
column49: Three exotic species (Cyprinus carpio var. communis, Oreochromis mossambicus and Clarias gariepinus) occur in Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006, Periyar Foundation 2006), which is located downstream of Thanikkudy (the type locality of N. periyarensis). Hence, there is a potential future threat from the upstream migration of these exotic species, especially C. gariepinus.
column53: No conservation action is in place. There is also no information on life history, ecology and population status. The Department of Forest and Wildlife, Government of Kerala is promoting the fishery of exotic fish species in Periyar Lake as a means to control their proliferation (A. Ali pers.obs.)

column12: Nemacheilus pulchellus is described by Day 1873 from the Bhavani River at the base of the Nilgiris (India). In recent publications it has also placed in the genus Mesonemacheilus (e.g., Rema Devi and Indra 2002, Shaji 2002).
column18: Ali, A., Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Molur, S., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Nemacheilus pulchellus is assesed as Endangered because it occurs in less than five severely fragmented locations, its extent of occurrence is less than 5,000 km_, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
column26: Nemacheilus pulchellus is endemic to the Western Ghats of India where it is distributed in the Bhavani River in Tamil Nadu, and Periyar and Chalakudy Rivers in Kerala (Menon 1987, Shaji and Easa 2003). It is restricted to an extent of occurrence of less than 5,000 km_.
column35: This is an uncommon species throughout its known range.
column43: This species is associated with clear water streams running over boulders and bedrock.
column49: Several threats impact this species, including pollution from agriculture and plantations, destructive fishing practices and invasive alien species such as Tilapia.
column53: It does not appear to be present in any protected areas. Research on taxonomy needed.

column11: Cobitis rueppelli Sykes, 1839,  Nemachilichthys rueppelli (Sykes, 1839), Noemacheilus rueppelli (Sykes, 1839)
column12: Nemacheilus rueppelli was originally described as Cobitis rupelli (note that the species name is different but it could be a spelling mistake because the author has named this species after Rüppell) by Sykes (1839) from Bhima and Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune, Maharashtra, India. The generic status is often debated. Day (1878) considered the genus Nemachilichthys, which is followed by Jayaram (1999), while Banarescu and Nalbant (1968) considered the genus Noemacheilus, which is followed by Menon (1987, 1999). Talwar and Jhingran (1991) considered the genus Nemacheilus, which is currently valid. Nemachilichthys shimogensis (Rao 1920) was synonymized with Nemacheilus rueppelli by several workers (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999, Menon 1999). However, Banarescu and Nalbant (1968) have suggested that the two species are separate and while N. rueppelli is restricted to the tributaries of Krishna River in northern Western Ghats, N. shimogensis is restricted to Tungabhadra and its head waters. Currently, Froese and Pauly (2010) and Eschmeyer and Fricke (2010) consider the two species distinct.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus rueppelli is assessed as Least Concern based on the fact that its expected extent of occurrence and number of locations are more than the threshold for any threatened category and no wide spread threats have yet been identified for the species. However, it is essential to note that in Pune, the type locality of the species, the species has faced drastic declines due to increasing urbanization and pollution of these rivers. If such changes are reported from other areas the species may qualify for a threatened category.
column26: Nemacheilus rueppelli is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is mainly recorded from the Western Ghats of Maharashtra but it could be found in the northern Karnataka. Population in the southern Karnataka, mainly from the Tungabhadra river, is Nemachilichthys shimogensis. Therefore, the records of Nemacheilus rueppelli by Bhat (2004) and Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu (2009) should be verified as they could be Nemachilichthys shimogensis.In Maharashtra the species is known from Indrayani River (Mandar Paingankar, Rupesh Raut, S. S. Kharat and Neelesh Dahanukar, manuscript in preparation), Mula-Mutha River (Sykes 1841, Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003), Bhima river (Sykes 1841), Neera river (Neelesh Dahanukar, Mandar Paingankar, Rupesh Raut and S.S. Kharat, manuscript in review), Krishna river near Wai (S. S. Kharat, Mandar Paingankar and Neelesh Dahanukar, manuscript in preparation), Koyna river (Jadhav et al. 2011), Panchaganga river (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956) and Nirar river system (Arunachalam 2000). The expected extent of occurrence for this species is about 52,000km2 and the number of locations are about 8 to 15.
column35: Exact population status of Nemacheilus rueppelli is not known but it is found in good numbers in most of the rivers in northern Western Ghats. The population of the fish in Mula-Muth rivers of Pune, the type locality of the species, however, has declined drastically (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.), which could be attributed to increasing urbanization and pollution of these rivers (Kharat et al. 2000, 2003).
column43: Nemacheilus rueppelli is found mostly in Ghats areas. It is found in streams, rivers and lakes below the ghats with pebbly bed and it attains a standard length of 7.4 cm (Menon 1999). Deforestation leading to siltation and pollution of the rivers can modify the habitat of this species. Such changes are ongoing in several locations where the species is distributed (Kharat et al. 2003, N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column49: No information is available on wide spread threats to Nemacheilus rueppelli. Nonetheless, the population of the fish in Mula-Muth rivers of Pune, the type locality of the fish, has declined drastically (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.), which could be attributed to increasing urbanization and pollution of these rivers (Kharat et al. 2000, 2003).
column53: Currently there are no specific conservation action plans directed towards Nemacheilus rueppelli. Research is essential on the distribution, population status, life history, ecology and threats to this species. Some populations of this fish could be protected in Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary.

column12: Nemacheilus semiarmatus was described by Day (1867) from Bhavani River at the base of the Nilgiri hills, India. Also listed as Schistura.
column18: Ali, A., Raghavan, R., Dahanukar, N. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus semiarmatus is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, common and without many threats.
column26: Nemacheilus semiarmatus is endemic to southern Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004) and widely distributed. N. semiarmatus is known from the Cauvery, Chittar in Kothayar Wildlife Sanctuary (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009), Sharavati (Sreekantha et al. 2007), Kabini, Bhavani (Biju 2005), Pambar (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000), Periyar (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009), Pamba, Kallada (Kurup et al. 2004) rivers in the states of Kerala and Karnataka.
column35: There is no information on the population status of N. semiarmatus. This is a very common species.
column43: Inhabits high altitude streams with sand, gravel and cobble stones as the major substrates (Biju 2005).
column49: N. semiarmatus has no major threats. Some populations may be threatened by the anthropogenic impacts that affect the habitats where they frequent including pollution and destructive fishing practices like poisoning.
column53: No species specific conservation actions are in place. It is present in some protected areas. There is a need to generate information on the population and ecology of this species.

column12: Nemacheilus stigmofasciatus is a recently described species by Arunachalam and Muralidharan (2009) from Thuttinjet, Seethanathi river, Karnataka State, India.
column18: Ali, A. & Molur, S.
column20: Nemacheilus stigmofasciatus is assessed as Data Deficient as it is a recently described species and there is no information on its exact distribution, population status and threats. However, if it is observed that the species is restricted to the current distribution and there are threats to the species, then the species may qualify for a threatened category.
column26: This species is currently known only from its type locality in west flowing river Seethanathi at Thuttinjet, Karnataka State, India (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2009). The projected extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species, based on the current information, is 1,500 km_.
column35: There is no information on the population status of this species.
column43: The type locality of the species is a small west-flowing river at the elevation of 199 m above sea level with many cascades and waterfalls in the upstream portion. The habitat is dominated by the presence of pebbles and boulders, less gravels and sand constituting about 5% of the total substrate, with riparian cover about 20% and gradient of 3% and the banks highly stable, left bank with thick vegetation while right bank sparsely vegetated (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2009).
column49: No information is available on threats to this species.
column53: There is no conservation action plan currently directed towards this species. Research is needed on the distribution, population status, ecology and threats to this species.

column11: Nemacheilus denisoni /Hora, 1935, Nemachilus dayi Hora, 1935, Schistura denisoni (Hora, 1935)
column12: Schistura dayi was originally described by Hora (1935) as Nemachilus dayi, from Raniganj, Chota Nagpur, Jharkhand, India. Menon (1987) synonymised the species with Nemacheilus denisoni but considered it as a valid subspecies N. denisoni dayi. However, Banarescu and Nalbant (1995) considered this species valid as Schistura dayi. Nevertheless, Jayaram (2010) considers this species as Schistura denisoni dayi.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Carpenter, K.E., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column19: Raghavan, R., Ali, A. & Dahanukar, N.
column20: Schistura dayi is assessed as Least Concern based on the fact that it is widely distributed in the central India and there are no known major threats to the species. However, research is required on finding the exact distribution, population trends, ecology and threats to the species before a more accurate threat status can be assigned to it.
column26: Schistura dayi is endemic to central India and is found in Jharkhand (Hora 1935, Motwani and David 1957, Menon 1987, Rao et al. 1991), Madhya Pradesh (Hora and Niar 1941, Hora 1949) and Chittisgarh (Karamkar and Dutta 1988). It is likely to be present in Orissa as well based on the fact that the species has been recorded from the Eastern Ghats without mentioning the exact locality (Devi and Indra 2003). The record of this species from Mula-Mutha river at Pune from Krishna river system (Hora and Misra 1942) is likely to be wrong as later workers (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2001, Pawar and Ghate 2003) were not able to record it.
column31: Native: India (Chattisgarh, Jharkand, Madhya Pradesh, Orissa)
column35: There is no information on the population status of S. dayi.
column43: The species prefers small, shallow, swift streams with sandy or pebbly bottom (Menon 1999). It attains a total length of 5 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column49: No information on threats to the species.
column53: Research is needed on exact distribution, population trends, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Schistura nagodiensis was described by Sreekantha et al. (2006) from Nagodi tributary of Sharavathi river, Karnataka, southern India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Schistura nagodiensis is highly restricted, found in a single location in a few rivulets of Nagodihole and surrounding areas. The area of occupancy is less than 20 km_, and the species is threatened by pesticide run-off from plantations and siltation. It is assessed as Endangered.
column26: Schistura nagodiensis is endemic to the Western Ghats. It is known only from Nagodihole, a tributary of Sharavati River in Karnataka State, India (Sreekantha et al. 2006).
column35: It is a recently described species and 12 specimens were collected from the type locality (Sreekantha et al. 2006). No information is available on the population trends of S. nagodiensis.
column43: Known to inhabit torrential hill streams with good vegetation cover (Sreekantha et al. 2006).
column49: Pesticide run-off from plantations is a threat to this highly restricted species; the plantations also contribute to siltation (Rahul Kumar pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to study the life history, ecology and population of the species. Systematic survey of the area is required.

column12: Schistura sharavatienis was described by Sreekantha et al.(2006) from Kalkatte tributary of Sharavathi River, Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Schistura sharavathiensis is highly restricted, found in a single location of Kalkette tributary in Sharavathi River. It occupies an area of less than 0.5 km_ (area of occupancy = 4 km_, since its entire known range currently falls within one 4 km_ grid cell), and it is potentially threatened by pesticide run-off from plantations and siltation. It is categorized as Vulnerable D2, although further studies on distribution and threats are urgently required. If there are current threats to the species, it may be highly threatened and a revision of category is required.
column26: Schistura sharavatienis is endemic to central Western Ghats in Karnataka where it is known from a 100 m stretch of Kalkatte tributary, above Dabbe Falls of Sharavathi River (Sreekantha et al. 2006).
column35: This is a recently described species; four specimens were collected from the type locality (Sreekantha et al. 2006). No information is available on the population trends.
column43: The species is known to inhabit perennial torrential hill streams with good evergreen to semi-evergreen vegetation cover (Sreekantha et al. 2006).
column49: Pesticide runoff from plantations is a potential threat to this highly restricted species; the plantations also contribute to siltation (Sreekantha and R. Kumar pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is an urgent need to generate information on the biology, population and threats to this species.

J. and Ramachandra,T.V. 2006. Two new species of the genus Schistura McClelland (Cypriniformes: Balitoridae) from Western Ghats, India. Zoos? Print Journal 21(4): 2211-2216.

column12: Travancoria elongata was described by Pethiyagoda and Kottelat (1994) from Vettilapara, 26 km upstream of Chalakkudy town, Kerala, southern India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Travancoria elongata is assessed as Endangered as it has a very restricted distribution with an area of occupancy of 44 km_ and an extent of occurrence inferred to be 2,573 km_. The species, which is known to occur at only two locations, is threatened by a continuing decline in habitat quality, the presence of exotic species, and destructive fishing practices. There are also emerging threats from collection for the international aquarium pet trade and from proposed dam construction in the area.
column26: Travancoria elongata is endemic to the Western Ghats in Kerala, India. It is known from the Chalakudy (Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 1994, Raghavan et al. 2008a) and from Pooyankutty tributary of the Periyar River system (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2006, Arunjith pers. coll. maintained at MES College, Ponnani; C.P. Shaji pers. comm.). In Chalakkudy it is restricted to a stretch between Athirapally waterfall and Tumburmuzhi dam of approximately 17 km. In Pooyamkutty, the species is distributed in a stretch of about 5 km. It is not reported from any other river system (C.P. Shaji, A. Ali pers. comm.).
column35: This species is known to be rare (Biju et al. 1999) with extremely low catch per hour figures in Pooyamkutty area of river Periyar (Euphrasia et al. 2006). Some researchers have not collected the species from Chalakkudy river in spite of detailed sampling (Ajithkumar et al. 1999). It is very difficult to obtain the species.
column43: Known to occur in torrential streams where they are restricted to riffles, runs, cascades and rapids (Raghavan et al. 2008a, Kurup et al. 2004). The species attaches itself to major substrates such as boulders, cobbles and bedrock using its broadened pectoral and pelvic fins (A. Ali pers. obs.).
column49: Local populations of T. elongata in Chalakudy river are under threat from dynamite fishing, palm plantation, exotic species (Oreochromis mossambicus, Gambusia affinis), increasing tourism and a potential hydroelectric power plant (Raghavan et al. 2008a,b), while those in Periyar river are under threat from dynamiting (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to document life history and demography of this species to form the basis of future management plans. It is very difficult to breed in captivity (A. Mercy pers. comm.).

column12: Travancoria jonesi was first described by Hora (1941) from a mountain stream in Pampadumpara, Peeramedu, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Arunachalam, M., Johnson, J.A., Dahanukar, N. & Molur, S.
column20: Travancoria jonesi is assessed as Endangered as it has a very restricted distribution, found in only two locations, in an area of less than 100 km_ and a range of less than 5,000 km_. The species is also threatened by a continuing decline in quality of habitat and by introduced exotic species.
column26: Travancoria jonesi is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004) in the high ranges of Kerala. It is known from the rivers Chalakkudy (Kurup et al. 2004, Biju et al. 1999), Periyar (Arun et al. 1996, Zacharias et al. 1996, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009), Anamalai Hills (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000, Devi et al. 2005), Pamba and Achankovil (M. Arunachalam pers. comm. and C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column35: This fish is considered to be a very rare species (Zacharias et al. 1996, Thomas et al. 2002). Catch per hour from the Karappara tributary of Chalakudy River was recorded to be very low (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: It occurs in mountain streams, with cobbles, bed rock and boulders as the principal substrates (A. Ali and R. Raghavan. pers.obs.).
column49: Travancoria jonesi is possibly threatened by the presence and proliferation of the exotic species such as Tilapia, Oreochromis mossambicus in the Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary and the presence of three exotic species, O. mossambicus, Clarias gariepinus and Cyprinus carpio in Periyar Lake, located downstream of Thanikkudy in the Periyar Tiger Reserve. In addition, there is a continuing decline in habitat quality as a result of pesticide pollution in Karappara tributary (Nelliampathi region) of Chalakudy River (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column53: No conservation plans are in place. An urgent need exist to document the life history, ecology and demography of the species to inform management plans. Study on impacts of exotic fishes on the species is urgently required.

column12: Horaglanis alikunhii was described by Babu and Nayar (2004) from Parappukkara, Thrissur District, Kerala, India. It is currently known only from a single specimen.
column18: Shaji, C.P., Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Basheer, V.S., Anna Mercy, T.V., Dahanukar, N. & Cox, N.A.
column19: Raghavan, R., Ali, A. & Kakkasery, F.
column20: Horaglanis alikunhii, a poorly known species is categorized as Data Deficient as there is currently little information available on its distribution, ecology or threats.
column26: Horaglanis alikunhii is endemic to the subterranean wells in the village of Parappukara, Thrissur District, Kerala, India (Babu and Nayar 2004).
column35: There is no information on the population of H. alikunhii. It is known only from the holotype.
column43: Lives in subterranean channels (Babu and Nayar 2004).
column49: Threats to H. alikunhii are not known.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to document life history and population characteristics of this very rare and endemic blind catfish.
column59: Babu, K.K.S. and Nayar, C.K.G. 2004. column12: Dayella malabarica was originally described by Day (1873) from erstwhile Malabar.
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Dayella malabarica is widely distributed in Kerala and although it faces some threats leading to habitat declines, it is still assessed as Least Concern.  It is recommended that the species is studied and monitored to better understand the status.
column26: Dayella malabarica is endemic to southwestern India, where it is widely distributed and known from the upper reaches of Vembanad Lake in Kerala and many other rivers (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2006), including Chalakudy (Raghavan et al. 2008).
column35: Although it is distributed in the lowland areas of many rivers of Kerala, it is relatively rare (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2006).
column43: D. malabarica inhabits both lowland rivers and the area where rivers reach the backwaters.
column49: There is an on going decline in the area and quality of habitats frequented by D. malabarica where they occur due to increased ecological transformation, sedimentation, pollution from point sources and destructive fishing practices.
column53: There is a need to gather baseline information on the population and life history traits of this species to inform future conservation action. It is not present in any protected areas.

column12: Botia striata was described by Rao (1920) from Tunga river at Shimoga, Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Botia striata is assessed as Endangered because the species is a habitat specialist and is inferred to have an area of less than 400 km2. Further the species is known from only four fragmented locations. The habitat of the species is severely threatened because of deforestation leading to siltation, recreational activities on the mountain tops and pollution of the hill streams.
column26: Botia striata is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It has been recorded from Tunga and Bhadra rivers of Karnataka (Rao 1920, Shahanawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahanawaz et al. 2010) and Panchaganga river and Koyna river of Maharashtra (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Jadhav et al. 2011). Record of this species from Vamanapuram river basin in Kerala by Johnson and Arunachalam (2009) could either be a different species or an introduced population as there are no other records from this and adjoining areas.
column35: The species is relatively abundant in Koyna river (Jadhav et al. 2011). However, it is rare in Tungabhadra river (Shahanawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009).
column43: Botia striata prefers clear mountain streams (Menon 1999). It is a bottom feeder and prefers sandy and gravel bottom. The habitat of this species is getting severely altered because of recreational activities on the mountain tops, deforestation leading to siltation and pollution of the hill streams, especially in the Western Ghats of Maharashtra (Neelesh Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column49: Habitat alteration is the most severe threat to the species. Deforestation leading to siltation can disturb the stream bed of gravel and pebbles, which is preferred by the fish. Recreational activities on the mountain tops and pollution of the hill streams could also be threatening as the species prefers clear water.
column53: Currently there is no conservation measures enlisted for this species. Research is needed on the population trends, harvest trends and specific threats to the species.

column12: This species was described by Menon (1992) from Araku Valley, Andhra Pradesh, India.
column18: Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Ali, A., Cox, N.A., Rema Devi, K.R. & Molur, S.
column20: Lepidocephalus coromandelensis is known only from a few locations but is considered widely distributed although not many studies have been conducted in the area to establish its actual distribution.  Although there are some threats identified, it is recommended that more studies are conducted to understand the actual status of the species.  It is currently assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Lepidocephalus coromandelensis is known from Araku Valley in the Godavari River drainage and Baeputta and Vijayawada in the Krishna River drainage in Andhra Pradesh, India.
column35: It is known only from the type collection.
column43: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species. But based on members of the same genus it may be found in hill streams with a gravel and pebble substrate.
column49: Araku Valley is threatened by habitat degradation, due to bauxite mining, deforestation and soil erosion (Kumar et al. 2010). No information is available on potential threats at Baeputta and Vijayawada.
column53: It is not known if the species occurs in any protected areas. More surveys are needed to better establish the range of this species.

column11: Cobitis carnaticus Jerdon, 1849,  Cobitis mysorensis Jerdon, 1849,  Cobitis rubripinnis Jerdon, 1849, Cobitis thermalis Valenciennes, 1846,  Lepidocephalichthys thermalis (Valenciennes, 1846), Platacanthus agrensis Day, 1865
column12: Described as Cobitis thermalis by Valenciennes 1846 from the hot waters of Cania, Sri Lanka.
column18: Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Ali, A., Molur, S. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Lepidocephalus thermalis is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, there are no major threats and because the population is unlikely to be declining.
column26: Lepidocephalus guntea is present in Sri Lanka and throughout much of the Western Ghats of India.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu); Sri Lanka
column35: It is a very common species.
column43: Lowland rivers and wetlands with a sandy or gravelly substrate. It is also common in reservoirs.
column49: There are no major threats to this widespread fish.
column53: It has been collected from some wildlife sanctuaries.
column59: IUCN. 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species (ver. 2011.1). Available at: http://www.iucnredlist.org. (Accessed: 16 June 2011).

column12: Pangio goaensis was described by Tilak (1972) from the Colem River, Goa, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Pangio goaensis is assessed as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution, although the species has been recorded from only a few localities within the range.  The species is difficult to catch due to its size and habits and therefore is not well represented in collections.  Although some threats to the species have been documented in Kerala, the Karnataka populations are in remote areas with little or no threats.  New information for the Goa population is unknown.
column26: Pangio goaensis is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Apart from its type locality in Goa, P. goaensis is known from the rivers Chaliyar (Remadevi et al. 1996, 2000) and Manimala (Thomas et al. 1999, Kurup et al. 2004) in Kerala.  It is also known from Kumaradhara and Sita rivers in Karnataka (Rahul Kumar pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the population of Pangio goaensis, but the species is known to be rare in Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002).  Rare in collections due to small size and habits.
column43: Prefers shallow, slow flowing waters of low land areas with detritus, mud, sand and gravel as the dominant substrates. Known to be more abundant in the river banks, where they are seen as groups among the interstitial spaces of sand or mud (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000).
column49: The habitats of Pangio goaensis in Manimala River (Kerala) are threatened by pollution from rubber plantations and human settlements (Thomas et al. 1999, R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).  In Chalayar, it is threatened by siltation, fish poisoning and dynamite fishing (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the eco-biology and demography of the species.

column12: Day (1878) described Barbodes bovanicus from Bhavani river at the base of Nilgiri hills.
column18: Abraham, R., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column19: Manimekalan, A., Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R. & Ali, A.
column20: Barbodes bovanicus is assessed as Critically Endangered Possibly Extinct. It has undergone a drastic population decline, the causes of which are unclear and the last individual was recorded in 1998. Only the population in the Mettur reservoir (2 km_) is thought  to still be extant, however, surveys conducted over the last decade at Mettur reservoir have not yielded any specimens (M. Arunachalam pers. comm. 2010). More surveys are needed to see if the species is still extant or has become extinct.
column26: Barbodes bovanicus has been recorded from the Bhavani river system and the Cauvery river system at the base of the Nilgiri hills, Tamil Nadu. Apparently only the population in the Mettur reservoir survives today (Menon 1999). However, surveys conducted over the last decade at Mettur reservoir have not yielded any specimens (M. Arunachalam pers. comm. 2010). The last individual collected was in 1998 from Mudumalai (Manimekalan 1998).
column35: The population status is unknown. The last individual collected was in 1998 (Manimekalan 1998).
column43: Collected from Mudumalai in a larger (fourth order) stream. The water was turbid with boulders and good riparian cover (A. Manimekalan pers. obs.)
column49: The threats to this species are not known.
column53: It has been recorded from the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary. Urgent surveys are needed to relocate this species.

column11: Barbus carnaticus Jerdon, 1849,  Puntius carnaticus (Jerdon, 1849),  Systomus carnaticus Jerdon, 1849
column12: Barbodes carnaticus was described by Jerdon (1849) from Bhavani river, Nilgiris. The placement of this species in the genus Barbodes must be examined. It is closer to Puntius and needs a new generic name (M. Arunachalam  pers. comm.).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Although the southern Kerala population of Barbodes carnaticus is thought to be a different species, the overall distribution of Barbodes carnaticus is very wide and with no perceived population declines in spite of some specific threats identified. The species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Barbodes carnaticus is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from rivers in the states of Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka including Cauvery, Krishna (Jayaram 1999), Moyar (Rajan 1963, Arunachalam et al. 2000), Kabini, Bhavani, Bharathapuzha, Chalakudy, Periyar, Pambar, Muvattupuzha, Manimala, Pamba, Achenkovil, Karamana, Neyyar (Shaji and Easa 2003, Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000, Kurup et al. 2004), Chaliyar (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).Ooty Lake (Jayaram 1999). Besides it has also been reported from the water bodies inside the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary (Manimekalan 1998), from the drainages in the Dharmapuri district of Tamil Nadu (Rema Devi and Raghunathan 1999) and from Kolli Hills of Eastern Ghats (Arunachalam and Johnson 1998). The record from Tambraparini (Johnsingh and Vickram 1987) is erroneous (Johnson and Arunachalam pers. comm.). The report from southern Kerala is also doubtful (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the population of this endemic barb. Reports from southern Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002) consider B. carnaticus to be a rare species. There are also reports of past decline in the catches of B. carnaticus (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). A recent study from Chalakudy River (Manojkumar and Kurup 2010) indicated that the growth coefficient K of this species is between 0.5-0.65.
column43: Barbodes carnaticus prefers large pools in rivers and streams (Daniels 2002), where the adults have a tendency to hide under bedrock, boulders and within caves although M. Arunachalam (pers. comm.) indicates the species to be a 'sporty' fish. They feed on the fruits and seeds that fall from the canopy above. The adults migrate upstream for spawning and breeds in the flood waters along rivers during the monsoons. The fry can be found in these waters during September to December (Daniels 2002). The young of B. carnaticus are seen in groups along the banks of rivers and reservoirs, while the mature carps are rarely seen along the banks (Biju 2005). Longevity of the species which was estimated as 4-5 years (Manojkumar and Kurup 2010) is doubtful (M. Arunachalam, R. Kumar pers. comm.).
column49: B. carnaticus is threatened by a wide range of factors including decline in habitat quality due to destructive fishing practices such as poisoning and dynamiting, altered river flow due to construction of dams, competition with exotic and transplanted carps and pollution from point sources.
column53: No conservation efforts are in place. The demography and threats to B. carnaticus at key habitats need to be determined to devise appropriate conservation plans. Milt cryopreservation and captive breeding protocol have been developed at NBFGR (V.S. Basheer pers. comm.).
column60: Ali, A. & Raghavan, R. 2010. Barbodes carnaticus. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 19 October 2011.

column11: Opsarius canarensis Jerdon, 1849, Opsarius malabaricus Jerdon, 1849
column12: Barilius canarensis was described by Jerdon (1849) from erstwhile Canara, southern India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Barilius canarensis is restricted in distribution, found only in four fragmented locations of less than 500 km2 area and 5000 km2 in extent. The species is under threat from habitat loss and harvest for aquarium trade and hence is categorized as Endangered.
column26: Barilius canarensis is endemic to Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Recorded from the rivers Sharavathi (Sreekantha et al. 2007, 2008); Bhadra (Shahnawaz et al. 2010); Tunga and Netravathi (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2008).  It is restricted to the Karnataka Western Ghats in the districts of Chikkamagalur and Shimoga. The reports of this species from Kerala, viz., Periyar (Kurup et al. 2004); Chalakudy, Muvattupuzha (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009); Bharatapuzha, Manimala (Thomas 2004), Kabini and Valapatanam (Shaji and Easa 2003), need to be verified.  The species from Kerala is probably B. bakeri (K. Remadevi, M. Arunachalam and A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the population status of B. canarensis. Since 1996 the collections have declined in the upper reaches of Netravathi as the collections in 2006 revealed very few numbers (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).  The population estimates based on underwater surveys carried out for a period of 10 years in River Netravathi reveal a reduction (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column43: Inhabits low to moderately gradient streams with boulders, cobbles and gravel as the major substrates (Thomas 2004).
column49: Unmanaged collection for the international aquarium pet trade is a potential threat given the restricted distribution of the species (Raghavan 2010). Similar to other hill stream fishes, B. canarensis could also be under threat from pollution.
column53: No known conservation action is in place. There is a need to regulate the unmanaged collection of B. canarensis for the international aquarium pet trade. Captive breeding and ranching efforts can also help in enhancing wild stock and maintaining stable population levels.

column8: Promod, Fang, Rema Devi, Liao, Indra, Jameela Beevi & Kullander, 2010
column12: Betadevario ramachandrani is a recently described species by Pramod et al. (2010) from in the upper Sita River drainage in Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Betadevario ramachandrani is a newly described species with very little information on its distribution, threats and trends. More surveys are required to establish its range and further studies to understand ecology and threats. Hence it is assigned to the Data Deficient category.
column26: Betadevario ramachandrani is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is currently known only from the west flowing river in the upper Sita River drainage above the Onakkeabbi falls in Karnataka, India (Pramod et al. 2010). There are only two species of fish in the stream, the other one being a currently undescribed species of Schistura.
column35: No information is available on the population trends, but the species is quite abundant at the type locality.
column43: The type locality for this species (at 558 m above sea level) is a small, high-altitude stream with a cascade and riffle-pool habitat. The width of the stream is 2-2.7 m, the depth at most about 30 cm in the dry season. This area has a notably high precipitation, Agumbe receives an average annual rainfall of 7,640 mm. Substrate is mostly boulders and cobbles (Rahul Kumar pers. comm.). This fish attains 61 cm standard length (Pramod et al. 2010).
column49: While it is known from only one location, over-collection for the aquarium trade is a potential threat to this species.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place. However, the type locality for this fish is near a protected area in Agumbe. Further research is required to understand its population status, life history, ecology and threats.

column12: Cirrhinus fulungee was originally described as Chondrostoma fulungee by Sykes (1839) from Deccan plateau of India (exact location is missing). Generic status of the fish was changed to Gymnostomus by Günther (1868) and to Cirrhina by Day (1872). Currently the species is valid as Cirrhinus fulungee (Roberts 1997).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Cirrhinus fulungee is assessed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed in peninsular India. Further, it is a common species in most of its range and currently there is no information on threats to this species. However, studies on the population trends, harvest trends and threats to the species could be helpful.
column26: Cirrhinus fulungee is widely distributed in the Deccan plateau. It is recorded from Krishna and Godavari river system from Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. Record of this species from Cauvery river system (Menon 1999) is doubtful. In Maharashtra, the species is known from Mula-Mutha river of Pune (Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003), Pashan lake in Pune (Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963), Pavana River near Pune (Chandanshive et al. 2007), Ujni Wetland (Yazdani and Singh 1990), Neera river near Bhor (Neelesh Dahanukar, Mandar Paingankar, Rupesh Raut and S.S. Kharat, manuscript submitted), Krishna river near Wai (S.S. Kharat, Mandar Paingankar and Neelesh Dahanukar, manuscript in preparation), Koyna river at Patan (Jadhav et al. 2011), Panchaganga river in Kolhapur (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956), Solapur district (Jadhav and Yadav 2009), Kinwat near Nanded (Hiware 2006) and Adan river (Heda 2009). In Andhra Pradesh, the species is known from Nagarjunasagar (Venkateshwarlu et al. 2006). In Karnataka, the species is reported from Tungabhadra river (Chacko and Kuriyan 1948, David 1956, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Linganamakki Reservoir on Sharavati River (Shreekantha and Ramachandra  2005), Biligiri Ranganathswamy Temple Wildlife Sanctuary (Devi et al. 2009), and Jannapura pond (Venkateshwarlu and Somashekar 2005). The species is also reported from Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh (Chandra and Sharma 2007, Dubey 2009, Sarkar and Lakra 2007) but the exact localities are missing. however, it is possible that the species is reported from the tributaries of Godavari river system in these two states. This is a wide spread species with an inferred EOO of 520000 to 530000 km2.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra)
column35: Exact population status of Cirrhinus fulungee is not known but it is common in most of its distribution (Kharat et al. 2000, Yadav 2003, Jayaram 1995, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Jadhav et al. 2011).
column43: Cirrhinus fulungee is found in rivers, lakes and reservoirs (Menon 1999, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Sreekantha and Ramachandra 2005). The species attains a total length of 30 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: Currently there are no known threats to Cirrhinus fulungee. Sarkar and Lakra (2007) have considered the species vulnerable but no rationale is provided.
column53: Currently there is no conservation action plan in place directed towards Cirrhinus fulungee. Research on the population trends, harvest level and threats to the species could be helpful.

column11: Chondrostoma gangeticum Valenciennes, 1844,  Cirrhina bengalensis Bleeker, 1854,  Cirrhina dussumieri Valenciennes, 1842,  Cyprinus reba Hamilton, 1822,  Gobio isurus McClelland, 1839,  Gobio limnophilus McClelland, 1839
column12: Cirrhinus reba was originally described as Cyprinus reba by Hamilton (1822) from Bengal and Behar (Bihar), India. Roberts (1997) considered this species as a synonym of Bangana ariza, however, this synonymy is not considered valid (Jayaram 1999, Menon 1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Cirrhinus reba is assessed as Least Concern because it has a large extent of occurrence as it is found throughout India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Nepal. It is also common in most of its range. Nevertheless, the wild populations in some of its range could be subject to heavy harvest, however, no quantitative data are available. Research on its population trends, harvest trends and threats is essential. Taxonomic clarification required.
column26: Cirrhinus reba is present throughout India (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999), Bangladesh (Hossain and Haque 2005), Nepal (Jha et al. 2006) and Pakistan (Mirza and Alam 2002). Its presence in Myanmar, as suggested by Menon (1999), is not valid.
column35: Exact population trends in Cirrhinus reba are not known. However, the species is common in most of its range. Wild population of the species could be declining due to heavy harvest (Sarkar et al. 2008).
column43: Cirrhinus reba is found in large streams, rivers, tanks, lakes and reservoirs (Menon 1999, Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It attains a total length of 30 cm (Menon 1999). It breeds only once in flooded shallows during June to early September (Gupta 1975). The fish feeds on plankton and detritus matter (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). No information is available on habitat trends of this fish.
column49: Detailed studies on the treats to Cirrhinus reba are not available. However, this is a preferred food fish and even though in some areas it is cultivated in ponds, the wild populations are still heavily harvested.
column53: Research is essential on the population status, harvest trends and threats to Cirrhinus reba. Since commercial aquaculture of this species is possible (Sarkar et al. 2004), heavy harvesting of the wild populations could be controlled by commercial production.

column12: Crossocheilus periyarensis was described by Menon and Jacob (1996) from the upper reaches of the Periyar River at Thanikkudy, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Crossocheilus periyarensis has been assessed as Endangered because of its restricted area of occupancy, in the upper reaches of Periyar River in the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala. Although the location where this species is found is inside a protected area the species is currently threatened by two exotic species (Tilapia and Common Carp), which exhibit major dietary overlap and therefore interspecific competition.  The impact of the exotics to the habitat needs further study.  In addition, the introduction of the African Catfish is a potential threat to the species.  Urgent detailed studies are recommended to understand the impacts of exotics as the species may be in a higher degree of threat and may need to be assessed soon again.  Monitoring of population recommended.
column26: Crossocheilus periyarensis is endemic to the Western Ghats in Kerala, India. Known only from the upper reaches of the Periyar River inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve (Euphrasia et al. 2006, Kurup et al. 2004, Zacharias et al. 1996).  It is also found in upper reaches of Manimala (B.M. Kurup pers. obs.)
column35: No information on population. Catch per hour of C. periyarensis in Thanikkudy is very low (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: A rheophilic species preferring fast and deep waters of streams with boulders, cobbles, pebbles and sand as major substrates (Arun 1999). Also known to occur in stagnant portions of streams (Shaji and Easa 2001). Feeds on algae (Arun 1999).
column49: Three exotic species - Cyprinus carpio var. communis, Oreochromis mossambicus and Clarias gariepinus occur in Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006, Periyar Foundation 2006) located below the regions where C. periyarensis is known to occur. Arun (1999) suggested that a high degree of dietary overlap (0.56) exist between O. mossambicus and C. periyarensis.
column53: No direct conservation action is in place. However, the Department of Forest and Wildlife, Government of Kerala is promoting the fishery of exotic species in Periyar Lake as a means to control their proliferation (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.). However, this practice must be examined for its success as a conservation measure.

column12: Devario fraseri was first desribed by Hora and Mukerji (1935) from the Waldevi and Darna rivers, Deolali, Nasik District in Maharashtra, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Devario fraseri is restricted in its range to less than 20,000 km2 with major threats from human encroachments and agricultural runoffs in three severely fragmented locations.  Hence it is assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Devario fraseri is endemic to northern Western Ghats in the state of Maharashtra (Dahanukar et al. 2004).  The species is found in the upper reaches of Godavari and Yazdani and Singh (1993) have recorded the species from Raigad and Ratnagiri. Although this species (3 specimens) was recently reported from the River Periyar in Kerala (Beevi and Ramachandran 2003), this needs to be verified, as there are no other reports of this species anywhere through Goa, Karnataka and Kerala.
column35: It is very rare and occasionally comes in as by-catch (S. Jadhav and N. Dahanukar pers. comm.). There is no information on the population of D. fraseri.
column43: No information about its habitat except for the fact that they occur in rivers and streams (Talwar and Jhingaran 1991)
column49: In the Nirar river, Raigad, and Darna River, Maharashtra, D. fraseri is threatened by exotic fish species especially O. mossambicus (Bleher 2010; S. Jadhav pers. obs.).  Habitat loss is a major threat in the type locality because of human encroachment (Yadav 2003) and agricultural runoffs from surrounding areas (S. Jadhav pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the life history and population characters of the species as well as determine its micro-level distribution in the Western Ghats.  Impacts of exotic species on D. fraseri needs urgent studies.

column12: Day described Paradanio neilgherriensis from Neilgherry hills in 1867 and he placed in the genus Paradanio. Later in 1878 he placed this species in the genus Danio. The scientific name was recently changed from Danio neilgherriensis to Devario neilgherriensis by Fang Fang Kullander in the doctoral dissertation "Phylogeny and Species Diversity of the South and Southeast Asian Cyprinid Genus Danio Hamilton (Teleostei, Cyprinidae)." in 2001.
column18: Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Cox, N.A., Ali, A. & Krishna , K.K.
column20: Devario neilgherriensis is assessed as Endangered because its Extent of Occurrence is less than 5,000 km_ (in two locations) as it is only known from Ooty Lake and Pykara, Avalanche and Kaity streams in the Nilgiri Hills of Tamil Nadu; and from Wayanad in Kerala where it is threatened by poisoning and dynamite fishing and drought.
column26: Devario neigherriensis is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. It has been reported from Ooty Lake and Pykara, Avalanche and Kaity streams in the Nilgiri Hills of Tamil Nadu; and from Wayanad in Kerala. The report of this species from Madhya Pradesh and Arunachal Pradesh needs further confirmation (Menon 1999).
column31: Native: India (Arunachal Pradesh - Presence Uncertain, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu)
column35: This species has a very restricted population.
column43: This species prefers fast flowing clear headwater streams.
column49: Habitat destruction, poisoning and dynamite fishing and drought are the major threats to this species. Introduced species also present a threat (e.g. Tilapia).
column53: It is known from Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary. Habitat restoration, removal of exotic species from this habitat will help the conservation of this species.
column59: IUCN. 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species (ver. 2011.1). Available at: http://www.iucnredlist.org. (Accessed: 16 June 2011).; Menon, A.G.K. 1999. column11: Esomus maderaspatensis Day, 1867,  Leuciscus barbatus Jerdon, 1849
column12: This species was described by Jerdon 1839. According to Menon (1999) this is a synonym of E. thermoicos. However, Jayaram (1999; 2010) treated it as a distinct species.
column18: Ali, A., Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R., Cox, N.A. & Krishna , K.K.
column20: Esomus barbatus is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
column26: Esomus barbatus is endemic to India, where it ranges in  the Western Ghats of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. It has also been recorded from the Eastern Ghats, Krishna and Godavari Rivers (Misra 1938, Menon 1951, Davids 1963, Devi and Indra 2003).
column35: It is a very common species in wetlands and small ponds and canals.
column43: This species is common in wetlands, ponds, and canals.
column49: Pollution from pesticides, inorganic and organic pollution, quarrying and mining the Eastern Ghats is a threat.
column53: This species is known from any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the threats of this species.
column59: David, A. 1963. Studies on fish and fisheries of the Godavari and the Krishna river systems. Part 2. column60: Shaji, C.P. 2010. Esomus barbatus. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 19 October 2011.

column12: Esomus thermoicos was described by Valenciennes (1842) from the Hot springs at Kanniya, Sri Lanka.  This species was later recorded from India (Rema Devi 1992).  However, the species in India needs to be re-examined for its taxonomic identity and status.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Esomus thermoicos is widespread in southern India and Sri Lanka. It is not a species of primary fishery interest and the threats to its habitats and populations are not high, therefore it is categorized as Least Concern.
column26: Since its first description from Sri Lanka, E. thermoicos was subsequently recorded from the southern Indian states of Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Kerala. The first record from India was from inside the Kalakad Wildlife Sanctuary, Tirunelveli district, Tamil Nadu, India (Rema Devi 1992). The species was later collected from Bharathapuzha (Thomas et al 1999) and Pambar (Kurup et al. 2004) rivers in Kerala. There are also reports of the species from Eastern Ghats (without specifying the water bodies where it inhabits in Javadi Hills) by Rema Devi and Indra (2005), Bhavani (Kurup et al. 2004) and from the Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary in the Anamalai hill ranges (Rema Devi et al 2005). The species is known from Kanyakumari Wildlife Sanctaury (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009) and in Chembarampakkam Lake and a few channels downstream, Chennai (V. Atkore pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu); Sri Lanka
column35: There is no information on the population of E. thermoicos.
column43: The species was originally described from hot springs (Valenciennes 1842). Previous records of its collection from Kerala were from ponds connected to the main river through channels (Thomas et al.1999). It is a pelagic insectivore (Rahul Kumar pers.obs.) found in mid and low stream, canals and wetlands.
column49: E. thermoicos is threatened by habitat alteration at key areas as a result of pollution, flow alteration due to construction of dams and barrages and exotic species invasion (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to understand the micro level distribution and threats to this species, in addition to generating baseline information on its population.  Taxonomic validation of the species from southern India is recommended.

column12: Garra bicornuta was described by Rao (1920) from Tunga River at Shimoga, Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Garra bicornuta is assessed as Near Threatened because even though the expected extent of occurrence of the fish is 70,000-75,000 km_, it is restricted to the headwaters of the rivers it occurs in; the estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is a little more than 2,000 km_. The number of locations estimated for this species is 6-10 and the population is severely fragmented. Although this fish is found in at least one protected site at Kudremukh National Park, the areas where it generally occurs are threatened by deforestation, urbanization and urban and industrial pollution. Furthermore, this species is very rare. If further research finds that its AOO is actually less than the inferred AOO used for this assessment, then a reassessment may result in this species being moved into a threatened category.
column26: Garra bicornuta is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is found in the Tunga River at Shimoga (Rao 1920), Korkanhalla River (a tributary of Thunga River inside the Khudremukh National Park), below Tunga dam (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2008, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009), the Bhadra River at Bhadravati (David 1956), Tungabhadra River sangam (Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Panchaganga River in Kolhapur (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956), and Koyna River at Patan (Jadhav et al. 2011). Jayaram (1995) has suggested that the species is also found in the Krishna River stretch between Wai and Bagalkot. This species is also recorded from Wadgaon on Bhima River by Suter (1944) and Nira River at Veer dam (Ghate and Pawar 1992) and Bhor (Dahanukar et al, submitted). The record of this species from Cauvery River by Yadav (2003) may be erroneous.
column35: The population structure of Garra bicornuta is not known. However, the species is considered to be rare (Menon 1999, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009). In Koyna River the species was observed and collected only during May to July when the water levels are low (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column43: Garra bicornuta is found in mountain streams and rivers (David 1956, Jayaram 1995, Menon 1999, Shahnawaz et al. 2010). It attains a total length of 15 cm (Menon 1999, N. Dahanukar and R. Kumar pers. comm.).
column49: Most of the areas where Garra bicornuta occur are threatened by deforestation, mining, urbanization and urban and industrial pollution (David 1956, N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Garra bicornuta. Research is essential to understand population status, distribution, life history, ecology, harvesting and threats to the species.

column12: Garra kalakadensis was described by Rema Devi (1993) from Pachaiyar, east of Sengaltheri, Kalakad Wildlife Sanctuary, Tirunelveli District, Tamil Nadu.
column18: Ali, A., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column19: Manimekalan, A., Raghavan, R. & Dahanukar, N.
column20: Garra kalakadensis is listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is less than 5,000 km_, its area of occupancy is less than 500 km_, and it is known from only two locations. In one of these locations (within a protected area) the species has not been recorded despite several surveys in the last 10 years, representing an estimated 50% population decline. There is continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat due to destructive fishing practices (poison and dynamite) and agricultural pollution. Urgent surveys and population monitoring are recommended.
column26: Garra kalakadensis is endemic to the Western Ghats. Known from the Pachyar stream inside the Kalakkad Mundanthurai Wildlife Sanctuary, and the Nambiar River in Tamil Nadu (Remadevi 1993, Arunachalam pers. comm. 2010). Since its initial description, this species has not been recorded from the Pachyar area despite several detailed studies (Arunachalam 2000; Johnson and Arunachalam 2009).
column35: This is an uncommon species. Seems to have disappeared from the type locality within a protected area as several surveys have revealed its absence (Arunachalam 2000; Johnson and Arunachalam 2009).
column43: This is a hill stream species, adapted to torrential conditions.
column49: Populations outside of protected areas are severely threatened due to destructive fishing methods (including dynamite and poison fishing) and agricultural pollution. Also, the only known population from within a protected area has disappeared completely and the reasons are not known.
column53: Part of the population is present within the Kalakkad Mundanthurai Wildlife Sanctuary. But there are no conservation actions in place. There is a need to understand its micro-level distribution as the species has not been recorded from in and around its type locality after its initial description in 1993 despite several studies in the region. In addition, information should be generated on the population and life history of this species.

column11: Discognathus elegans Annandale, 1919,  Garra jerdoni Day, 1867,  Garra platycephala Narayan Rao, 1920, Gonorhynchus mclellandi Jerdon, 1849
column12: Garra mcclellandi was originally described as Gonorhynchus mclellandi by Jerdon (1849) from Bhavani River, at the foot of the Nilgiri hills, Manantavaddy River and Cauvery River in southern India. Subsequently, Garra jerdoni (Day 1867), Discognathus elegans (Annandale 1919) and Garra platycephala (Rao 1920) were described from Seegoor River and Bhavani River, Nierolay stream at the base of Nilgiris and Cauvery River at Srirangapattana in Karnataka respectively. Menon (1964) considered the later three species as synonyms of Garra mcclellandi.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Garra mcclellandi is assessed as Least Concern based on the fact that the expected extent of occurrence for this species is more than the threshold for any threatened category and some part of the population of this species is conserved as it is found in a few protected areas. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that the species is very rare in Kerala. If more information becomes available on the precise population trends, habitat modifications and threats to the species, the species may qualify for a threatened category.
column26: Garra mcclellandi is endemic to the southern Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004) and is found mainly in the Cauvery drainage (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Menon 1999). It is known from Kerala (Silas 1951, Shaji and Easa 1995, 2003, Arun et al. 1996, Ajith kumar et al. 1999, 2001), Tamil Nadu (Rajan 1955, Arunachalam 2000, Devi et al. 2007, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009) and Karnataka (Rao 1920). Record of this species from Bhadra river at Bhadravati (David 1956) is doubtful. Record of this species from Arunachal Pradesh (Nath and Dey 2000, Tamang et al. 2007) is erroneous (Nebeshwar 2009).
column35: No precise information is available on the population status of Garra mcclellandi, however, Thomas et al. (2002) have considered the species to be rare in Kerala.
column43: Garra mcclellandi is found in mountain streams and it attains a length of 17.4 cm (Menon 1999) and up to 25 cm (J. A. Johnson and C. P. Shaji pers. obs.)
column49: No information is available on threats to Garra mcclellandi. Thomas et al. (2002) considered this species to be threatened but no rationale is provided except for the fact that the species is rare.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Garra mcclellandi. Research is essential on population status, distribution, life history, ecology and threats to the species. Some part of the population of this species is conserved as it is found in protected areas in Periyar Tiger reserve (Arun et al. 1996) and Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Devi et al. 2007).

column10: English–Silent Valley Stone Sucker, Silent Valley Algae Eater
column12: Garra menoni was first described by Remadevi and Indra (1981) from Walakkad in the upper reaches of Bharatapuzha River (Kunthi tributary) inside the Silent Valley National Park (Easa and Basha 1995).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: G. menoni is listed as Vulnerable because it has a very restricted distribution with an area of occupancy less than 20 km_ inside the Silent Valley National Park and Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala State, India. There are no current threats to the species as its entire range falls within protected areas, but the threat from exotic species inside Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary is likely to have an impact in the future. Urgent studies to understand the impact of exotics on native fish is required as well as taking concrete measures to eliminate these exotics from the area.
column26: Garra menoni is endemic to the Kerala part of Western Ghats (Remadevi and Indra 1981, Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the Rivers Bharatapuzha (inside Silent Valley National Park, Remadevi and Indra 1981, 1986) and Pambar (inside Chinnar Wild Life Sanctuary) (Easa and Basha 1995, Easa and Shaji 1996).
column35: There is no information on the population of G. menoni. Recent surveys conducted in the Silent Valley indicate that the species is rare (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column43: It prefers flowing waters with cobble, boulder and bed rock as substrates (Biju 2005). It occurs in high altitude areas with riparian vegetation (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column49: There are no current threats for this species as their habitats are located entirely inside protected areas. However, the potential threat from exotic species such as Oreochromis mossambicus in Chinnar has to be studied.
column53: As G. menoni is poorly known, there is an urgent need to determine its population status, life history, threats and ecology.

column11: Chondrostoma mullya Sykes, 1839,  Discognathus fusiformis Heckel, 1844, Garra alta Day, 1867,  Garra jenkinsonianum Hora, 1921,  Garra malabarica Day, 1865
column12: Garra mullya was originally described as Chondrostoma mullya by Sykes (1839, 1841) from Downde (perhaps Daund) on Bhima river, Maharashtra, India.
column18: Ali, A., Raghavan, R., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Garra mullya is a widespread species present throughout peninsular India. The species is abundant in most of its known range and there are no reports of widespread threats to the species. The species is, therefore, assessed as Least Concern. However, it is suggested that some more research on its population status, harvest levels and threats is essential.
column26: Garra mullya is endemic to Peninsular India. It is present in Tapti, Narmada, Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna, Cauvery and other river systems of southern India. Thus, Garra mullya is found in Gujrat (Ranade 1953), Madhya Pradesh (Dubey 2007, Sarkar and Lakra 2007), Chhattisgarh (Prakash et al. 2007), Orissa (Hora 1921), Jharkhand (Hora 1921, through synonymy of Garra jenkinsonianum), West Bengal (Barman 2007), Maharashtra (Sykes 1841, Hora and Misra 1937, Fraser 1942, Kulkarni 1947, Silas 1953, Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Singh and Yazdani 1988, Yazdani and Singh 1990, Arunachalam et al. 2002, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, Chandanshive et al. 2007, Heda 2009, Jadhav and Yadav 2009), Andhra Pradesh (Venkateswarlu and Bakde 1986, Chandrasekhar 2004), Goa (Tilak 1972), Karnataka (David 1956, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Tamil Nadu (Manimekalan 1998, Arunachalam and Sankaranarayanan 1999, Balasundaram et al. 1999, Arunachalam et al. 2000, Arunachalam et al. 2001) and Kerala (Silas 1949, 1951, Rajan 1955, Shaji and Easa 1995, Shaji et al. 1995, Ajithkumar et al. 1999, Thomas et al. 2000, Ajithkumar et al. 2001, Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, Narayanan et al. 2005, Raghavan et al. 2008). Record of this species from Nepal (Shrestha 1999) needs validation.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Goa, Gujarat, Jharkand, Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal)
column35: No systematic data is available on the population status of Garra mullya. However, the species is common throughout its distributional range.
column43: Garra mulla is found in mountain streams and lowland rivers (Fraser 1942, Yazdani and Singh 1990, Menon 1999, Kharat et al. 2003). It attains a standard length of 17 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It seems to be resistant to pollution as it is found abundantly even in polluted stretches (Neelesh Dahanukar, pers. obs.) and it is recorded from polluted rivers such as Badra river (David 1956) and Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003). The species breeds during December and January and show upstream migration for spawning (Joseph and Job 1983). The fish mainly feeds on detritus matter, algae and diatoms (Neelesh Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column49: No information is available on specific threats to Garra mullya.
column53: No conservation action plan is in place directed towards Garra mullya. Research on population trends, harvest levels and threats to the species is required. It is present in many protected areas. This species has been captive-bred.

column12: Garra periyarensis was first described by Gopi (2001) from the headwaters of Periyar River inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Garra periyarensis is endemic to the upper reaches of Periyar River in the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala and it has been assessed as Vulnerable because of its very restricted area of occupancy (<20 km_). Although the entire range of the species is inside a protected area with no threats to the habitat, there is a very high probability of three exotic species threatening G. periyarensis. Anecdotal data suggest that the fish is very rare and that the species was encountered only four times in as many as seventeen surveys conducted in and around its type locality, probably a reflection of the negative impact of the exotics. It is recommended that study of impacts of exotic species must be urgently taken up as this may change the status of the species.
column26: Garra periyarensis is endemic to the Western Ghats in the southern Indian state of Kerala, where it occurs in the upstream reaches of Periyar River (Gopi 2001). So far it is known only from Thanikkudy and Mlappara regions inside the Periyar National Park and Tiger Reserve (Euphrasia et al. 2006, Gopi 2001, Kurup et al. 2004). It is seen only in one location with the stream length of 10 km and the width of about 100 m.
column35: No information is available on the population of Garra periyarensis. Anecdotal data suggest that the fish is very rare (Kurup and Radhakrishnan 2006). Catch per hour of G. periyarensis in its type locality was very low; the species was encountered only four times in as many as seventeen surveys conducted in and around its type locality (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: Inhabits fast flowing streams with boulders, cobbles, pebbles and sand as substrate (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).
column49: Although no current threats exist for this species, there is a potential future threat from three exotic species (Cyprinus carpio var. communis, Oreochromis mossambicus and Clarias gariepinus). These species occur in Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006, Periyar Foundation 2006), which is located downstream of Thanikkudy (the type locality of G. periyarensis).
column53: No conservation action is in place. There is also no information on life history, ecology and population status. The Department of Forest and Wildlife, Government of Kerala is promoting the fishery of exotic fish species in Periyar Lake as a means to control their proliferation (A. Ali pers.obs.)

column12: Garra gotyla stenorhynchus was described by Jerdon (1849) from the Bhavani River at the foot of Nilgiris. It is currently being revised to the level of a full species, Garra stenorhynchus.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Garra stenorhynchus is assessed as Least Concern due to its wide distribution and few threats to the species in its entire range.
column26: Garra stenorhynchus has been recorded from Cauvery and Krishna drainages in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and parts of Andhra Pradesh (Coimbatore, Coorg and Kurnool) (Menon 1999), Bavalipuzha tributary of Cauvery and in Tunga River (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009); Chaliyar, Kabini, Pambar, Bhavani (Shaji and Easa 2003, Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000) rivers in Kerala; Moyar river and other water bodies inside the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary, Tamil Nadu (Rajan 1963,Manimekalan 1998, Arunachalam et al. 2000); and the rivers of Uttara Kannada including the Sharavati drainage in Karnataka  (Bhat 2004, Sreekantha et al. 2007) and Gundia in Hassan District in Karnataka (Atkore 2009). It has also been recorded from the Myristica swamps of Karnataka (Ali et al. 2008). The report from Periyar (Zacharias et al. 1996) needs verification (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu)
column35: There is no information on the population status of G. gotyla stenorhynhcus. However this species is known to be abundant in the east flowing rivers of Kerala - Bhavani, Kabini and Pambar (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000, R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.) and in the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary area (Manimekalan 1998).
column43: Inhabits hill streams (Menon 1999) and is even reported from higher elevations of over 1000 m  (Daniels 2002). The species has an affinity towards habitats with cobbles as the major substrate (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). It spawns in shallow water, moving upstream during summer. The eggs are heavy and adhere to the rocks (Daniels 2002).
column49: It is mainly threatened by destructive fishing practices prevalent in the upstream areas of major rivers where they are found including poisoning and dynamiting. In addition, they may also be under the threat of pollution from plantations as well as presence and proliferation of exotic species.
column53: No known conservation actions are in place. Studies should be directed at gathering information on the current population size of this species in its major habitats. There is a need to strictly enforce local legislations to curb the illegal fishing practices including dynamiting and poisoning that are prevalent in the upper reaches of the rivers where this species occurs. In addition, the collection and export of this species for the international aquarium pet trade need to be regulated (Raghavan 2010). Captive breeding protocols have been developed (Mercy et al. 2007).
