column12: Garra surendranathanii was first described by Shaji et al. (1996) from the Orukomban tributary of Chalakudy River, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Garra surendranathanii is listed as Endangered due to its restricted distribution (with an area of occupancy less than 500km2) with a continuing decline in habitat quality due to pollution, destructive fishing practices and potential threats from exotics. One of the prime habitats of this species in Chalakudy River (Kerala, India) is also threatened by a proposed hydroelectric power project.
column26: Garra surendranathanii is known from four major river systems of Kerala. viz., Periyar (Shaji et al. 1996, Kurup et al. 2004), Chalakudy (Shaji et al. 1996, Raghavan et al. 2008), Pamba (Shaji et al. 1996) and Achenkovil (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. obs.).
column35: There is no precise information on the population status of G. surendranathanii. Recent studies have indicated that the species is exploited beyond its optimum levels in river Periyar (Thampy 2010).
column43: G. surendranthanii prefers fast flowing streams with pool riffles and cascades (Raghavan et al. 2008) and with varying levels of substrates including sand, pebbles, boulders and bed rock (Shaji et al. 1996). Known to breed during October to December (Thampy 2010).
column49: G. surendranathanii is threatened in the wild as a result of pollution from agricultural and domestic waste, dynamite fishing, poisoning, collection for the aquarium trade and a proposed hydroelectric power project (Raghavan et al. 2008; Kurup et al. 2004) and also from exotic species.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. Captive breeding technology has been developed using artificial hormones (Thampy 2010) but have not been used for either ranching or for stock enhancement.

column12: Horalabiosa arunachalami was described by Johnson and Sornam (2001) from Panniyar stream in Santhamparai, Iddukki district, Kerala.
column18: Krishna , K.K., Ali, A., Cox, N.A. & Abraham, R.
column20: Horalabiosa arunachalami is listed as Critically Endangered as this species is known only from a single location in the Panniyar stream of Periyar River at Santhampara, Kerala where there is an ongoing threat from agro-based pollution originating from tea and cardamom plantations. The species is restricted to less than 5 km_ area of occupancy and less than 10 km_ extent of occurrence. It is known from a single location where recent surveys have indicated a near disappearance of the species from the stream (suspected more than 80% decline in 10 years).
column26: Horalabiosa arunachalami is endemic to the southern Western Ghats, India. Known only from the Panniyar stream of Periyar River at Santhampara, Kerala (Johnson and Soranam 2001).
column35: No information on the population status of H. arunachalami is available. This is a rare species. Recent studies have indicated the species to have decreased to the extent of near complete disappearance indicating an extremely high rate of decline of more than 80% in the last 10 years.
column43: Occurs in fast flowing streams where the species is restricted to rapids and cascades (A. Manimekalan pers.comm.).
column49: The type locality of H. arunachalami is dominated by cardamom and tea plantations. In a recent survey it was found that the species had almost disappared from the type locality. The riparian cover of the stream is known to be severely altered (Arunachalam et al. 2002; Arunachalam 2000).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the life history and population status of the species to inform conservation plans.

column12: Horalabiosa joshuai was first described by Silas (1953) from the rainforest streams of Tambraparni River, Singampatti, Tirunelveli, Tamil Nadu, India. Talwar and Jhingran (1991) placed it under Garra lamta. The taxonomic identity was in question until it was revalidated by Devi (1992).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Horalabiosa joshuai is endemic to the Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve of the Western Ghats where it has been recorded from the upstream of Pachayar in Kalakkad and Tambaraparani (Pambar, Ullar and Chittar tributaries) in Mundanthurai. Reports of the species from other areas need to be verified. Its area of occupancy is very small, possibly less than 10 km_, however based on the major threats of habitat loss and degradation due to water abstraction, encroachment, plantation run-off and the drying up of streams, the species is currently found in four locations (it has already been extirpated from one location). It is therefore listed as Endangered.
column26: Horalabiosa joshuai is endemic to the Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve of the Western Ghats (Silas 1953, Devi 1992, Johnson and Arunachalam 2010). It has been recorded from the upstream of Pachayar in Kalakkad and Tambaraparani (Pambar, Ullar and Chittar tributaries) in Mundanthurai (Johnson and Arunachalam 2010). Reports of the species from the Kunthipuzha tributary of Bharatapuzha River inside the Silent Valley National Park (Kurup et al. 2004), Pambar River inside the Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary (Thomas et al. 1999a), and Periyar River inside Eravikulam National Park (Thomas et al. 1999b) need to be verified (Arunachalam pers. comm). The extension of the species' range to the Nokrek Biosphere Reserve, Garo Hills, Meghalaya (Sen 2009) needs further verification (K. Rema Devi pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Kerala - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu)
column35: There is no information on the population, but one of the locations where this species was recorded from has become locally extinct (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column43: Horalabiosa joshuai occurs in narrow high altitude streams with low depths, moderately high canopy cover and moderate flow. It prefers riffles, pools and run habitats (Johnson and Arunachalam 2010).
column49: The species is threatened from habitat destruction and degradation due to tea plantations, tourism, water abstraction, run-off from plantations, encroachment, and possible effects of climate change. Future threats to the species are impacts of reduced rainfall, which could affect the perennial streams in which the species is distributed. In addition, alien invasive species of fish could be a potential threat if and when they reach the species' distribution (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need for documenting the life history, demography and ecology of the species to inform management decisions.

column12: Horalabiosa palaniensisis was described by Rema Devi and Menon (1994) from Palani Hills, Tamil Nadu, India.
column18: Ali, A., Krishna , K.K., Cox, N.A. & Abraham, R.
column20: Horalabiosa palaniensis is known from only one location since its initial description from the Palani Hills. It is presumed to have a localized distribution restricted to a small area as surveys have not revealed the presence of this species in other streams. Although there is no information about threats affecting the species, activities promoting development and tourism are plausible threats to this fish, hence it is assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Horalabiosa palaniensisis is endemic to the southern Western Ghats in the state of Tamil Nadu where it is known from the type locality of the Palani hills (Menon 1999).
column35: There is no information on the population status of H. palaniensis.
column43: Prefers fast flowing stream with rapid and riffle habitats (A. Manimekalan pers.comm.).
column49: Currently there is no information on the threats. However, given the state of development activities in the Palni hills and the promotion of tourism, these could be potential threats to the species.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the life history, population status and threats to this species in and around its type locality to inform management plans.

column11: Barbus dobsoni Day, 1876, Barbus jerdoni Annandale, 1919
column12: Hypselobarbus dobsoni was described by Day (1876) from Deccan.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: This species is assessed as Data Deficient because it is poorly known to science. Its taxonomy needs clarification, as there is confusion between this species and Puntius jerdoni.
column26: Hypselobarbus dobsoni is endemic to the Western Ghats (Remadevi et al. 2005). The known 'H. dobsoni' distribution in river basins of Krishna (Kalawar and Kelkar 1955, Menon 1992), Kali River (Arunachalam 2004), Tambraparini (Arunachalam 2000), Kabini (Arunachalam et al. 2000), Chalakkudy (V.S. Basheer pers. obs.) as well as the drainages in the Anamalai Hills and Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Remadevi et al. 2005) have to be re-examined as there is confusion in the species' identity.The report of this species in Gadana (Arunachalam and Sankaranarayanan 1999) has now been placed under the genus Neolissochilus (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka - Presence Uncertain, Kerala - Presence Uncertain, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu - Presence Uncertain)
column35: There is no information on the population status of H. dobsoni from its native range. There is only one confirmed population in Chalakkudy as documented in an ongoing study by NBFGR (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.). The species is not very common in Chalakkudy.
column43: The species is known to occur in rocky pools. Adult fish mainly hide under boulders while juveniles prefer riffles and shallower waters. H. dobsoni is known to feed on allochthonous plant materials and detritus (Arunachalam et al. 2000).
column49: The species has disappeared from most of its range due to destructive fishing, overexploitation, sandmining, siltation and other anthropogenic effects. The species is not as threatened in Chalakkudy (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to study the taxonomy (given its ambiguity with Puntius/Hypselobarbus jerdoni), life history and demography of this species.

column12: Hypselobarbus dubius was described by Day (1867) from Bhavani River at the base of Nilgiri hills, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Hypselobarbus dubius is listed as Endangered as the natural wild population is restricted to less than 100 km2 area in four streams of the Cauvery River basin.  This species is one of the most preferred food fish and are harvested from the rivers and reservoirs where it occurs. The species is under threat from an on-going decline in habitat quality as a result of pollution, destructive fishing and exotic species in its natural range. The species has been introduced to several different reservoirs and river systems where the populations are not viable due to similar threats. However, this assessment is only of the natural wild population.
column26: Hypselobarbus dubius is endemic to the Cauvery River basin in southern Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004, Devi et al. 2005). Known from the rivers Khal (Arunachalam et al. 2000a), Bhavani (Day 1867, Rajan 1955), Cauvery/Kaveri (Rajan 1955), Moyar (Rajan 1963), Tambraparini and Servalar (Johnsingh and Vikram 1988), Manimuthar (Johnson and Arunachalam, 2009), Kabini (Euphrasia and Kurup 2005, Kurup et al. 2004, Arunachalam et al. 2000b, Euphrasia et al. 2006), Achenkovil (Arunachalam 2000), and drainages inside the Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Devi et al. 2005).  Apart from the distribution records of the wild population in the Cauvery River basin, all the other records are most likely the result of introductions from Bhavani Sagar reservoir (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). The species recorded from Kali and upstream of Krishna River in Satara District, Maharashtra (Arunachalam et al. 2002) and Kali, Aghanashini, Bedthi and Sharavathi in Karnataka (Bhat 2000) is doubtful (M. Arunachalam and Johnson pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu)
column35: There is no information on the current population status of H. dubius. Known to be abundant in Bhavani and Tambraparini Rivers (Arunachalam et al. 2000b). There are reports that H. dubius which ranked first (55%) in the landings from Amaravathy reservoir (Tamil Nadu) during 1965-1966 dwindled to less than 2% a decade later and finally disappeared from the catches (Sreenivasan 1976, 1995).  While the catch of this species was about 75% and Tilapia, O. mossambicus was 25% in the 1970s, the state fisheries department statistics of 2010 indicate that Tilapia catch is 75% and the rest is H. dubius (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). The catch per hour of H. dubius in Kabini river system is recorded to be low at Baveli, Noolpuzha and Vythiri (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: Known from both rivers and reservoirs. In rivers, it inhabits deep pools (Arunachalam et al. 2000a, Menon 1999) as well as pools and riffles (Euphrasia and Kurup 2002). H. dubius is an allochthonous plant materials, seeds and terrestrial insects (Arunachalam et al. 2000a).
column49: Apart from it being overfished, the rivers from where H. dubius has been recorded are impacted by various stressors including pollution from domestic, agricultural and industrial sources, exotic species, destructive fishing and dams.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. Generating baseline data on demography, exploitation levels and life history is a major priority.

column12: Hypselobarbus kolus was described by Sykes (1839) as Barbus kolus. Menon and Remadevi (1995) synonimised this species with H. curmuca. Later Vairavel et al (1998) recorded this species for the first time from Kerala and treated it as a separate species.  It is a valid species based on mitochondrial genome, meristic, morphometric and osteological characterization (Arunachalam pers.comm.).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Hypselobarbus kolus is assessed as Vulnerable as wild populations have undergone a population decline of 30-40% in the last ten years due to overexploitation, destructive fishing practices and decline in quality of habitat.
column26: Hypselobarbus kolus is endemic to Western Ghats (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It has been recorded from the states of Kerala, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra. Known from the rivers Chalakudy (Raghavan et al. 2008, Kurup et al. 2004), Periyar, Muvattupuzha and Karamana (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000),  Linganamakki Reservoir in Sharavathi River (Sreekantha and Ramachandra 2005); Krishna River (Chandrasekhariah et al. 2000), Tambraparini (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009); Bhima-Sina-Man  (Jadhav and Yadav 2009),  Godavari (Heda 2009) and  Bhadra (Shahnawaz et al. 2010).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: There is no published information on the population status of H. kolus.  However, surveys since 1996 in all the river systems indicate a perceptible decline in population of the species of greater than 30% (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column43: Known to inhabit fast flowing streams and reservoirs in the middle and upper stretches of rivers (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.). H. kolus is known to breed after the monsoon when the adults are known to develop bright colours (Daniels 2002)
column49: Destructive fishing practices, sandmining, siltation, urbanization and deforestation are the major threats to the species in its range. Over fishing in some parts is also a threat.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the population, life history, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Hypselobarbus lithopidos was described by Day (1874) from south Canara, India.
column18: Molur, S. & Dahanukar, N.
column20: Hypselobarbus lithopidos is assessed as Data Deficient as it was last recorded in 1941. The species has not been recorded since then although several comprehensive surveys in different drainages have been made. There has been a reported collection of this species (30 from the type locality in Dakshina Kannada) in recent times, however these specimens need confirmation as when compared with the type housed at ZSI, Kolkata they were found to be different (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). There is an urgent need to do a complete taxonomic reassessment of this species and those reported in the same genera by several recent workers. This species may already be extinct.
column26: Hypselobarbus lithopidos is endemic to the southern Western Ghats (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). The distribution of this species is entirely based on reports made in the early half of the last century (1929-1941): drainages in Trivandrum District (Pillai 1929, John, 1936); Periyar National Park and Tiger Reserve as well as River Chaliyar at Nilambur (Raj 1941). It was not recorded throughout 1950-2010 from Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu parts of Western Ghats, although this area has been comprehensively explored (Easa and Basha 1995, Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000, Chandrashekhariah et al. 2000, Gopi 2000, Thomas 2004, Biju 2005, Kurup et al. 2004). The species is known only from the type collection and one specimen housed in the Madras Museum. Arunachalam et al. (2000) reported a collection of the species from Khal River, Maharashtra, which require verification.
column35: This fish was previously recorded only before the 1950s and since then confirmed records have not been collected. The species may be extinct in its original range.
column43: It was known to occur in fast flowing streams in forested areas (Menon 1999).
column49: No information on threats to H. lithopidos is available. The areas from where the species was recorded prior to 1950s have been altered and currently there is no information on its occurrence.
column53: Extensive microgeographic surveys have to be undertaken in and around its type locality and throughout its once-known range to conclude whether the species has gone extinct. Also, there is a need for carrying out taxonomic studies by comparing types available at museums or in personal collections to ascertain the taxonomic identity, especially of the collection made by Arunachalam (2000).

column11: Barbus conirostris Günther, 1868,  Barbus gracilis Jerdon, 1849, Barbus micropogon Valenciennes, 1842,  Barbus mysorensis Jerdon, 1849, Gonoproktopterus micropogon (Valenciennes, 1842)
column12: Hypselobarbus micropogon was described by Valenciennes (1842) from Mysore, Karnataka, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Hypselobarbus micropogon is restricted to four locations within the Cauvery drainage with an area of occupancy less than 100 km_ and extent of occurrence less than 5,000 km_. There has also been a population decline of 40-50% in the last 10 years which is expected to continue into the foreseeable future; it is predicted to decline by more than 50% over the next ten years. This fish is also under severe threat from habitat loss due to dams and thermal power projects and from introduced exotic species. It is therefore assessed as Endangered.
column26: Hypselobarbus micropogon is endemic to the Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004), where it is restricted to the headwaters of Cauvery River. It is known from the rivers Bhavani (Rajan 1955, Menon 1999) and Kabani (Arunachalam et al. 2000, Shaji and Easa 2003). There is a recent report of the species from Gugalthurai and Thalipuzha (tributaries of east flowing Cauvery River) (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka - Presence Uncertain, Kerala, Tamil Nadu)
column35: The species has been declining in its range for the last 10 years. Surveys between 1996 and 2010 within the range of the species have found decreasing abundance (M. Arunachalam and C.P. Shaji pers. comm.). Current surveys have found only a few specimens (one in Pilloor and four in Noolpuzha).
column43: Known to occur in fast flowing streams where they are seen in riffles and rocky pools (Arunachalam et al. 2000).
column49: Overexploitation, destructive fishing practices using dynamite and poisoning, and pollution are the major threats to H. micropogon in the Kabini river system (Arunachalam et al. 2000). It is also reasonable to believe that the same threats exist for this species in the other river systems from where it has been recorded.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on distribution, population, life history and threats to this species.

column12: Sykes (1839) described Barbus mussullah from Ghod river, Sirur, Pune District. Maharashtra, India. There has been considerable debate on the generic status of the species. This species has been treated as Tor mussullah by Talwar and Jhingran (1991), Jayaram (1997, 2005, 2010) following the discussions given in Hora (1943). Menon (1992, 1999), however suggested that the species considered as Tor mussullah by Hora (1943) is same as Tor khudree and he placed T. mussullah under genus Hypselobarbus following Rainboth (1989). However, both the original suggestion of the genus Hypselobarbus by Bleeker (1860), with Barbus mussullah as its type species, and resurrection of the resurrection of genus Hypselobarbus by Rainboth (1989) is based on the illustration by Sykes (1839) and not by examining specimens. Suggestions made by Hora (1943) that the species should be called Tor mussullah seems more valid as the species called as 'musunda' in the type locality of Barbus mussullah and neighboring areas is indeed a Tor species (Neelesh Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column18: Arunachalam, M., Ali, A. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Hypselobarbus mussullah is assessed as Endangered because, although the species is widely distributed in the Western Ghats, it is severely fragmented with the area of occupancy (AOO) probably less than 500 km_. Furthermore, the population size is declining severely in most parts of its distribution because of habitat alterations caused by pollution, heavy harvest of the species and competition created by the introduced alien species.
column26: Hypselobarbus mussullah is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. It has been described from Maharashtra (Sykes 1839, Annandale 1919, Hora 1943, Sutur 1944, Silas 1953, Jayaram 2005, Dahanukar pers. obs.), Karnataka (David 1963, Jayaram 2005, Sreekantha et al. 2007,  Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009), Tamil Nadu (Chacko 1952, Manimekalan 1998) and Kerala (Shaji and Easa 2003, Jayaram 2005, R. Raghavan and M. Arunachalam pers. comm. 2010). The record of this species from the northeastern Godawari River at low altitudes by Heda (2009) needs verification. Even though this species is widely distributed the populations are severely fragmented and the AOO of the species is likely to be less then 500 km_.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: This is a very rare species throughout its range (Jayaram 1995, Menon 2004, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, N. Dahanukar pers. obs.). The population of this species seems to be declining.
column43: The species prefers deeper portions of clear fast flowing large jungle streams and rivers in the upland areas and it attains a total length of 100 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: Overfishing (including dynamite fishing), habitat loss due to pollution and introduced exotic species are the major threats to the species.
column53: There is no specific conservation action plan directed towards this species. Research is needed on the population trends, harvest trends and specific threats to the species.

column12: Hypselobarbus periyarensis was first described by Raj (1941) from the upstreams of Periyar River, near Peeramade, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Johnson, J.A., Shrikant, J., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Hypselobarbus periyarensis is restricted to Periyar River-Lake system and the records of this speceis from other areas need taxonomic verification. The species is confined to an area of less than 30 km2 in Periyar with several threats impacting its habitat and population. It is therefore listed as Endangered.
column26: Hypselobarbus periyarensis is endemic to the Western Ghats in Kerala, India, where it is known from the Periyar River-Lake system. The species has been collected from the waters inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve (Raj 1941, Chacko 1948, Silas 1951, Arun 1999, Shaji and Easa 2003, Euphrasia et al. 2006). The record of this species from Pooyamkutty Reserve forest (Ajithkumar et al. 2001; Kurup 2005), and Idukki Wildlife Sanctuary (Thomas et al. 2000) needs verification (C.P. Shaji pers. comm.).
column35: There are no reliable estimates of the population status of H. periyarensis. However, the size of fish caught from Periyar Lake is known to have decreased compared to those caught from the upstream regions (Minimol 2000). Abundance index of H. periyarensis in Periyar Lake is less compared to the upstream reaches (Arun 1999).
column43: Prefers deep water bodies especially streams flowing into large pools (Minimol 2000) as well as cascades with moderate water velocity (Euphrasia and Kurup 2002). Rock, boulders and cobbles are the favoured substrates (Euphrasia and Kurup 2002). H. periyarensis is known to be an omnivore feeding predominantly on leaves, fruits, algae and worms (Minimol 2000).
column49: Exotic species, pollution and presence of a dam are the major threats to H. periyarensis in the Periyar Lake-River system. Three exotic species - Cyprinus carpio var. communis, Oreochromis mossambicus and Clarias gariepinus occur in Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006, Periyar Foundation 2006). The township of Thekkady on the banks of the Periyar Lake attracts approximately 4.5 lakhs tourists annually. Around 6-7 diesel and 2-speed boats ply for sight seeing in the lake on a daily basis, discharging oil into the lake. Also the sewage waste from in and around Kumily town is being decanted directly into the Periyar lake. Levels of nitrate and nitrite, phosphate, feacal coliforms, hydrocarbon and lead in the Lake are higher than permissible limits (Kurup 2004).
column53: There is no specific conservation action in place. There is an immediate need to carry out research on population size, life history and ecology to inform management plans. The Department of Forest and Wildlife, Government of Kerala is promoting the fishery of exotic fish species in Periyar Lake as a means to control their proliferation (Anvar Ali pers.obs.)

column11: Chondrostoma boggut Sykes, 1839,  Tylognathus striolatus Günther, 1868
column12: Labeo boggut was originally described as Chondrostoma boggut by Sykes (1839) from Deccan plateau of India (probably near Pune but the type locality is not given). Günther (1868) described Tylognathus striolatus from Pune. Day (1878) synonymized Tylognathus striolatus with Chondrostoma boggut and changed the generic status of the fish to Labeo.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Labeo boggut is assessed as Least Concern because the species is widely distributed and there are no known wide spread threats to the species. However, the population of this species is declining in some areas in the northern Western Ghats, which could be attributed to heavy harvesting of the fish, pollution of the river and competition created by introduced carps.
column26: Labeo boggut is found in India except Kerala, Bangladesh and Pakistan (Jayaram and Dhas 2000). The species is perhaps absent in the extreme north India and north-east India as currently no records are available. In India it is known from Maharashtra (Hora and Misra 1937, Fraser 1942, Setna and Kulkarni 1946, Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Yazdani and Singh 1990, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, Hiware 2006, Chandanshive et al. 2007), Karnataka (Rao and Seshachar 1927, David 1956), Andhra Pradesh (Jayaram and Dhas 2000, Chandrasekhar 2004), Gujrat (Acharya 1939, Ranade 1953), Madhya Pradesh (Sarkar and Lakra 2007), Uttar Pradesh (Sarkar et al. 2010). It is also suspected to be present in other states including Goa, Tamil Nadu, Bihar, Rajastan, Chhattisgarh, Orissa, Jharkhand and West Bangal. It is also known from Pakistan (Mirza and Alam 2002) and Bangladesh.
column31: Native: Bangladesh; India (Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Chattisgarh, Goa, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Jharkand, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal); Pakistan
column35: Exact population structure of Labeo boggut is not available but in several parts of its distribution the species seems to be declining. In Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune and other rivers in the northern Western Ghats the population is decreasing mainly because of heavy harvesting and competition created by introduced commercially important carps (Kharat et al. 2000, N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). But such reports are not available from other areas. So the trends cannot be generalized.
column43: Labeo boggut is found in rivers and reservoirs (Menon 1999, Yazdani and Singh 1990). It attains a total length of 29 cm (Menon 1999). In some areas of its distribution there is habitat degradation caused by organic and inorganic pollution (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2003).
column49: Specific threats to Labeo boggut are not known. However, heavy harvesting, organic and inorganic pollution of the rivers and  competition created by introduced carps could be possible threats to the species.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place directed towards Labeo boggut. Research is essential on the population status, harvest trends and threats to this species.

column11: Rohita dussumieri Valenciennes, 1842,  Rohita rouxii Valenciennes, 1842
column12: Labeo dussumieri was originally described by Valenciennes (1842) from Alleppey (Kerala, India).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Labeo dussumieri was a threatened species in the past but the populations have increased in the recent past due to ranching.  Hence the species is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Labeo dussumieri is endemic to southern Kerala and Sri Lanka. In Kerala, it is known from four rivers, Pampa, Achenkovil, Manimala and Meenachil (Kurup 2000), the southern tip of Vembanad Lake (Narayanan et al. 2005; Kurup 2000), and Periyar (Gopalakrishnan et al. 2009). In Sri Lanka they have been recorded from various rivers (Smith 1991) and reservoirs (Amarasinghe and Pitcher 1986, De Silva 1998). Labeo rajasthanicus from Jaisamand Lake in Udaipur has been found to be the same as L. dussumieri and therefore needs to be synonymised (Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).  The record from Alibagh, Maharastra by Jayram (2010) needs verification.  The Sri Lankan population needs taxonomic verification as it may be a different species. The populations from different rivers in Kerala were found to be genetically homogeneous (Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.) but the morpho-meristics analysis of populations from different river systems, showed that the populations are different (Kurup and Kuriakose 1996).
column31: Native: India (Kerala)- Present - origin uncertain: Sri Lanka
column35: L. dussumieri has shown considerable decline in their population in southern Kerala (Kurup 2000), largely due to exploitation (Kurup 1998). Similarly, Pethiyagoda (1994) recorded decline of this species in Sri Lanka because of competition with the exotic tilapia. There is no recent estimate of the population of L. dussumieri but local knowledge of fishers in Kerala indicate that the species has shown a decline in the recent past. The species has now revived in Pampa with a total annual landing of 30 tonnes in 2009 compared to 3 tonnes in 1988-89 (B.M. Kurup pers. obs.).  This is due to ranching in Pampa in 1988-90.
column43: Known to inhabit streams above the tidal reach (Kurup 2000), flood plain areas (Smith 1991), backwaters (Kurup 2000) and reservoirs (De Silva 1998). On the basis of the feeding ecology and diurnal migrations L. dussumieri has been identified as litoral aufwuchs (periphyton) feeder (De Silva 1998). In Kerala, L. dussumieri migrates massively during the monsoon - a phenomenon known as the 'Thooliyilakkam' in vernacular (Shaji and Easa 2003). Spawning season extends from June to August with peak activity during June and July (Kurup 2000).
column49: In Kerala, L. dussumieri was under threat from indiscriminate fishing often with illegal gears and poor habitat quality as a result of pollution from point sources. L. dussumieri is known to be threatened by exotic species in Sri Lanka (Pethiyagoda 1994).
column53: Milt cryopreservation protocol has been standardized at NBFGR, Kochi, India (A. Gopalakrishnan pers.comm.) and captive breeding and ranching has been undertaken in the rivers of Central Kerala (B.M. Kurup pers.comm.).

column12: Labeo fimbriatus was originally described as Cyprinus fimbriatus by Bloch (1795) from the Madras coast of India.
column18: Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Labeo fimbriatus is assessed as Least Concern solely based on the fact that it has a very large expected distribution. However, the wild population of the species are declining and have gone locally extinct from some parts of its known distribution owing to the threats like over harvesting and pollution of the rivers, though this is not thought to cause a population decline high enough to qualify the species for a threatened category. There is a need to understand the species' present distribution, population status and harvest trends.
column26: Labeo fimbriatus is found throughout India (except its western coast), Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan and Myanmar (Menon 1999, Jayaram and Dhas 2000).
column31: Native: Bangladesh; India (Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Chattisgarh, Dadra-Nagar-Haveli, Daman, Delhi, Gujarat, Haryana, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Manipur, Orissa, Pondicherry, Punjab, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal); Myanmar; Nepal; Pakistan
column35: This fish is the commonest major carp in Tamil Nadu. However, it is not that common in Maharashtra. The population in Maharashtra is declining and the species was not recorded recently from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Wagh and Ghate 2003, Kharat et al. 2003) owing to the fact that the the species is over exploited and there is habitat alterations due to pollution of the rivers.
column43: Found in rivers above tidal reaches and in culture ponds (Menon 1999). It is a bottom feeder and it feeds on diatoms, Myxophyceae, Bacillariophyceae, Chlorophyceae especially Spirogyra, plant tissue, Copepods, insects and lower crustacean eggs (David and Rajgopal 1974). Fecundity of the fish ranged from 64800 to 526000, in a length range of 336-740 mm and the maturation and breeding is confined to the upper part of the river (Rao 1976).
column49: Wild population of the species are threatened by over harvesting and pollution of the rivers (Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003).
column53: There is no specific conservation action plan directed towards the wild populations of Labeo fimbriatus. Research is essential on the current distribution, population status and harvest trends of the species.

column12: Labeo kawrus was originally described as Chondrostoma kawrus by Sykes (1839) from Bhima river, Maharashtra, India. Generic status of the fish was changed to Cirrhina (Day 1876) and later changed to Labeo (Day 1877), which is now considered as valid (Jayaram and Dhas 2000).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Labeo kawrus is assessed as Least Concern based solely on the fact that the inferred extent of occurrence of the fish is 100,000 km2. However, it is essential to note that the population of the fish in the northern tributaries of the Krishna river system are facing rapid declines, which can be attributed to threats such as organic and inorganic pollution of the rivers, heavy harvesting of the fish and competition created by introduced fishes. If such population declines are also reported from other localities in its range, the species can qualify for threatened category.
column26: Labeo kawrus is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is found only in the Krishna river system and in west flowing rivers of northern Western Ghats (Yadav 2003). It is currently known from Maharashtra and Karnataka state. In Maharashtra it is recorded from Mutha river (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Neelesh Dahanukar, pers. obs.), Pashan lake (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963), Ujni wetland (Yazdani and Singh 1990) and Bhima river (Sykes 1841, Suter 1944). In Karnataka it is known from Linganamakki Reservoir on Sharavati River (Shreekantha and Ramachandra 2005), Aghanashini river (Bhat 2004) and Bhadra river (David 1956). It is suspected to be found in other tributaries of Krishna river as well but no such reports are currently available. Currently the species is known from 8 to 10 locations and inferred extent of occurrence of this species is 100,000 km2.
column35: Population of Labeo kawrus is steadily declining especially in the northern tributaries of Krishna river near Pune where it is now found very rarely. Kharat et al. (2000) suspected that the species is locally extinct from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune, however, only one specimen was collected from Mutha river after an agitated search (Neelesh Dahanukar, unpublished) indicating that some population of the species may still be extant. A discussion with the local fisherman from Mula-Mutha rivers and Bhima river suggests that the population of this species has drastically declined in last ten years (Neelesh Dahanukar, unpublished). Unfortunately, no such information is available on this fish from other areas.
column43: Labeo kawrus is found in upper reaches of the rivers (Menon 1999) and in lakes (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963) and reservoirs (Yazdani and Singh 1990, Shreekantha and Ramachandra 2005). The species grows up to 60 cm in total length (Menon 1999). The species breeds during the onset of south-west monsoon (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). The habitat of this species is severely threatened by organic and inorganic pollution (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2001, 2003).
column49: No specific information is available on the threats to Labeo kawrus, however, the habitat of this species is severely threatened by organic and inorganic pollution (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2001, 2003). The rivers in northern Western Ghats are also subject to heavy harvesting of fishes and since the species has a good food value, heavy harvesting might have played a major role in its decline. Furthermore, population of the species may have been affected by introduced exotic fishes and economically important carps, which is a threat in northern Western Ghats (Kharat et al. 2001, 2003).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place directed towards Labeo kawrus. Research is required on the population status, distribution, life history, ecology, harvesting and threats to the species.

column11: Cirrhinus rubropunctatus Jerdon, 1849,  Cyprinus kontius Jerdon, 1849,  Labeo kontius
column12: Jerdon 1839 described Labeo kontius from river Cauvery and its tributaries. He later placed this species in the genus Cyprinus.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Abraham, R., Ali, A., Raghavan, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Labeo kontius is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, there are no major threats and because the population is unlikely to be declining.
column26: Labeo kontius is endemic to India. Jerdon described this species from river Cauvery and its tributaries. Rajan (1956) and Manimekalan (1998) reported this species from Bhavani and Moyar rivers and some of their tributaries. Jayaram (1982) and Jayaram and Dhas (2000) report this species from the Cauvery river.
column35: This is a common species.
column43: Mostly it prefers fast flowing hill streams and rivers.
column49: There appear to be no major threats to this species. It parts of its range it may be locally threatened by overharvesting, and habitat loss.
column53: This species is present in a number of protected areas.

column12: Labeo porcellus was originally described as Tylognathus porcellus by Heckel (1844) from Bombay presidency (this should not be treated as Bombay, now Mumbai, since at that time even Pune and Nashik were also in Bombay presidency). Beavan (1877) changed the generic status of the fish to Labeo. Synonymy of Labeo porcellus lankae with Labeo porcellus needs to be confirmed (Menon 1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Even though the expected extent of occurrence of Labeo porcellus is large the species is rare in some of its known range. It is currently known only from 6 to 10 locations. The population of this species is declining and it could be attributed to introduced carps, pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting of fish resources. However, since there is no quantitative estimate on the decline the species is assessed as Least Concern. If, however, some more information on the population status of this species become available, the species could qualify for some threatened category.
column26: Labeo porcellus is known only from the Krishna and Godavari river systems of Western Ghats (Menon 1999, 2004, Jayaram and Dhas 2000). Presence of this fish in Sri Lanka is due to synonymy of Labeo porcellus lankae with Labeo porcellus. Since this synonymy is doubtful (Menon 1999) the presence of this species in Sri Lanka is also doubtful. In India the species is known from Western Ghats of Maharashtra (Hora and Misra 1937, Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Jayaram and Dhas 2000, Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003) and Karnataka (David 1956, Jayaram and Dhas 2000, Shahnawaz et al. 2010, Jadhav et al. 2011). It is mainly confined to east flowing rivers but Bhat (2004) recorded it from a west flowing river in Karnataka, however, exact locality is not mentioned. Occurrence of this species in Badoda (now Vadodara) in Gujrat (Ranade 1953) and central India (Sarkar and Lakra 2007) is doubtful.
column35: Exact population status of Labeo porcellus is not known, but the species is relatively rare (Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Jadhav et al. 2011). Discussions with the fisherman from Pune and Satara suggests that the population of this species is declining (Dahanukar, unpublished). Menon (2004) has suspected that the decline of the population could be attributed to introduction of Gangetic carps in the peninsular India.
column43: Labeo porcellus is found in rivers and large streams of moderate current and it attains a total length of 30 cm (Menon 2004). The habitat where the species is found is affected by domestic and industrial pollution (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2003).
column49: Population of Labeo porcellus is declining (Menon 2004, N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.) and it could attributed to introduced carps, pollution of the rivers and heavy harvesting of fish resources (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2003, Menon 2004).
column53: Currently there is no specific conservation action plan directed towards Labeo porcellus. Research is essential on the population status, distribution, life history, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species.

column12: Laubuca dadiburjori was described by Menon (1952) from Cochin, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Laubuca dadiburjori is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed in the Western Ghats and although not much information is available on the population trends and threats, it is in cultivation in a few places and has been bred in captivity.  Further studies on population trends and threats are required.
column26: Although the species is known to occur throughout the Western Ghats from Nagarcoil to Goa (Menon 1999, Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000), there are only very few actual collection reports of this species. In Kerala, L. dadiburjori has been collected from drainages in Thiruvananthapuram, (Silas 1958), Meenachil River (John 1988-1989), Bharatapuzha (Kurup et al. 2004; Bijukumar and Sushama 2001), Chalakkudy River (Shaji and Easa 2003). There are no reports of this species from anywhere in Maharashtra although the areas have been intensively surveyed (Chandrasekhariah et al. 2000, Acharya and Iftekhar 2000).  It has been recorded in Sita River in Karnataka (Rahul Kumar pers. comm.).
column31: Native: India (Goa - Presence Uncertain, Karnataka - Present - Origin Uncertain, Kerala)
column35: There is no information on the population status of this species. However several authors including Bijukumar and Sushama (2001) and Kurup et al (2004) have noted that the species is rare in Bharatapuzha river in Kerala.
column43: Known to inhabit clear freshwater ponds and small streams in the plains (Menon 1999).
column49: In River Bharatapuzha, L. dadiburjori is currently threatened by habitat alteration due to construction of check-dams, pollution, sand and clay mining, destruction of natural pools, exotic fish species and unscientific fishing methods (Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).  The threats to the species in its entire distribution is not known.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the population status, threats and life history details of this rare species.

column12: Laubuca fasciata was described by Silas (1958) from Anamalai river at Vannanthurai in Chittur taluk, erstwhile Cochin state (Kerala) India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Laubuca fasciata has been assessed as Vulnerable because of its restricted distribution, area of occupancy less than 30 km2 and less than 10 fragmented locations.  The locations are under severe threat from various factors.
column26: Laubuca fasciata is endemic to Kerala, India. Known from the rivers Bharathapuzha (Biju 2005, Kurup et al. 2004) Chalakudy, Muvattupuzha, Periyar (Shaji and Easa 2003, Beevi and Ramachandran 2009), Meenachil, Achenkovil and Chaliyar (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers.obs.), Manimala (Krishnakumar pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the population of L. fasciata. Catch per hour of the species from the Bharatapuzha river was low (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2006).
column43: Occurs in the mid and lowland areas of rivers with bedrock, cobbles and gravel as the major substrates. It is a surface feeder and prefers areas close to the banks in low flow shallow area (alcove) (M. Arunachalam and C.P. Shaji pers. obs.).
column49: Since L. fasciata occurs in habitats connected with mid and low land regions of major rivers, they are subjected to a wide range of threats including sand mining, pollution from domestic sources, exotic fish species and destructive fishing practices.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to generate baseline information on the population, life history and ecology of the species to inform conservation action.  Captive breeding technology has been developed (TVA Mercy pers. comm.).

column12: Lepidopygopsis typus was first described by Raj (1941) from Periyar Lake, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Lepidopygopsis typus is assessed as Endangered as it has a highly restricted distribution; known only from a four locations within the Periyar Lake-Stream system in the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala, India having an area of occupancy of less than 30 km2 and extent of occurrence of less than 1000 km2, and subjected to an on-going decline in the quality of habitat and in competition with exotic alien fishes.
column26: Lepidopygopsis typus is endemic to the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala, India where it occurs at Mlappara, Thanikkudy, Mullayar and Thekkady in the Periyar lake-stream system (Arun 1999, Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Kurup et al. 2004, Euphrasia et al. 2006, Raj 1941).
column35: No estimates of population status of L. typus are available, although the species is considered to be rare (Kurup et al. 2006, Zacharias et al. 1996). Catch per hour of L. typus from Thanikkudy is very low (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: Found in fast flowing torrential streams (Raj 1941, Arun 1999) with boulders, cobbles (Shaji and Easa 2001) and bed rock (Manojkumar and Kurup 2002) as substrates. Known to be a habitat specialist with affinity towards cascades and riffles (Manojkumar and Kurup 2002). Also occurs in confluence zone of  lakes and feeder streams (Arun 1999). L. typus feeds mainly on aquatic insects and detritus (Arun 1999).
column49: Exotic species, pollution and presence of a dam are the major threats to L. typus in the Periyar lake-stream system. Three exotic species - Cyprinus carpio var. communis, Oreochromis mossambicus and Clarias gariepinus occur in Periyar Lake (Kurup et al. 2006, Periyar Foundation 2006). High level of competition exist between L. typus and O. mossambicus (0.68) and between L. typus and C. carpio (0.49) (Arun 1999).
column53: No conservation action is in place. Species level management efforts have been largely hampered by absence of baseline data on life history and population.

column12: Osteobrama bakeri was first described by Day (1873) from Mundakayam, Kottayam, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Osteobrama bakeri is widely distributed in the west flowing rivers within Kerala part of the Western Ghats. However, the species is rare as per catch data.  Although the threats to the species range from habitat destruction, exotic species and pollution, the information available currently does not fit the species into any of the threatened or near threatened categories. Hence it is Least Concern.
column26: Osteobrama bakeri is endemic to the southern Western Ghats (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000; Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the rivers Chaliyar (Easa and Basha 1995); Periyar (Euphrasia et al. 2006), Chalakudy (Raghavan et al. 2008), Karuvannur, Muvattupuzha, Meenachil, Manimala, Chandragiri, Bharathapuzha (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000); Pamba, Kallada, Achenkovil (Kurup et al. 2004) in Kerala. The distribution of this species in east flowing river, Talipuzha in Wyanad (Johnson and Arunkumar 2009) and Aganashini  in Karnataka (Bhat 2004) needs verification (J. Johnson pers. comm.).
column35: No information on population is available. The species is considered to be rare ( Menon, 1999; Thomas et al. 2002). Catch per hour recorded from different rivers in Kerala is low (Euphrasia et al. 2006). Local fishers in many rivers of Kerala have reported that the species is very rarely seen (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column43: Inhabits low land areas of major rivers with sand, mud and detritus as major substrates (Biju 2005, Thomas 2004). It is an omnivore feeding mainly on microinvertebrates and algae (Biju 2005).
column49: The habitats of O. bakeri in the major rivers of Kerala are threatened by sand mining, destructive fishing, alteration of river flow as a result of the construction of barrages and dams, exotic fish species invasion and pollution (Raghavan et al. 2008a, b, Kurup et al. 2004, Kurup 2002, Padmalal et al. 2007, Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to regulate destructive fishing practices especially the use of dynamiting in the mid and low land reaches of the rivers in Kerala where O. bakeri is known to occur. Research needs to address current population sizes.

column12: Osteobrama bhimensis was described by Singh and Yazdani (1992) from Ujani wetland on Bhima River in Maharashtra, India. The species is considered as valid by Jayaram (1999) and Yadav (2003). However, the species is remarkably similar to Osteobrama vigorsii, a common species found in this area.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Osteobrama bhimensis is currently known only from its type locality in Ujani wetland on Bhima River in Maharashtra. The area of this wetland is 260 km2 and is subject to increasing urbanization and agricultural pollution. Further, several invasive exotic fishes have also been recorded from this area. There is a need to review the taxonomic validity of the species. However, with the available information it fits the Endangered category.
column26: Osteobrama bhimensis is endemic to the northern Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). Currently it is known only from its type locality in the Ujani wetland on Bhima River in northern Western Ghats of India (Singh and Yazdani 1992).
column35: No information is available on the population status of Osteobrama bhimensis. Nagulu et al. (2000) considered this species as uncommon. This species was recently reported by Sarwade and Khillare (2010) from Ujani Wetland, the type locality of the species, and it is suggested that the species is rare.
column43: No information is available on the ecology of Osteobrama bhimensis. It was described from a reservoir. Maximum recorded standard length of the fish is 210 mm (Singh and Yazdani 1992).
column49: Ujani wetland, the type locality of Osteobrama bhimensis, is subject to increasing urbanization and agricultural pollution. Further, several invasive exotic fishes have also been recorded from this area (Yazdani and Singh 1990).  Water abstraction in the downstream is also a threat. Overexploitation of fish resources from the lake is a potential threat.
column53: No particular conservation action plans are in place however site protection could be helpful to protect this species. Research on the population status of this species, ecology and threats can aid help in designing and implementing conservation strategies. There is a need to review the taxonomy of this species as it is remarkably similar to a common species Osteobrama vigorsii found in this area.

column11: Cyprinion brevidorsalis (Day, 1873),  Osteochilus brevidorsalis (Day, 1873),  Scaphiodon brevidorsalis,  Semiplotus brevidorsalis Day, 1873
column12: Osteochilichthys brevidorsalis was originally described as Semiplotus brevidorsalis by Day (1873) from rivers below Neilgherry (Nilgiri) Hills, Western Ghats, India.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Abraham, R., Ali, A., Raghavan, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Osteochilichthys brevidorsalis is known only from two records and despite it being restricted in its extent and the threats not known it is assessed as Least Concern.  However, urgent surveys to establish its distribution as well as population and habitat monitoring are recommended.
column26: Osteochilichthys brevidorsalis is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004) and it is known from Bhavani River at the base of the Nilgiris, Tamil Nadu (Day 1873) and Nulpuzha in Wyanad, Kerala (Shaji and Easa 1995).
column35: There is no information on the population status of this species. The species has been recorded rarely since its first description.
column43: Osteochilichthys brevidorsalis inhabits large streams (Menon 1999).
column49: Threats to this species are unknown.
column53: There is no conservation action plan directed towards this species. Research is required to understand the population trends, life history and threats to the species.

column12: Osteochilus longidorsalis was first described from Vettilapara in Chalakudy River, Kerala, India (Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 1994).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Osteochilus longidorsalis is listed as Endangered as it is only known from the Chalakudy and Periyar River basins in Kerala where the area of occupancy is restricted to less than 60 km2 and extent is less than 3000 km2. The two locations are threatened by the presence of exotic species, continuing decline in the quality of habitat, destructive fishing, tourism and a proposed hydroelectric power project.
column26: Osteochilus longidorsalis is endemic to the Western Ghats in the state of Kerala, India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the Chalakudy (including Parambikulam Tiger Reserve) and Periyar Rivers (Ajithkumar et al. 1999, Biju et al. 1999, Devi et al. 2005, Euphrasia et al. 2006, Kurup et al. 2004, Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 1994, Raghavan et al. 2008a).
column35: No information on population is available. O. longidorsalis is known to be  rare (Ajithkumar et al. 1999) or very rare (Thomas et al. 2002) in Chalakudy River. Catch per hour at various sites in Chalakudy River is very low (Euphrasia et al. 2006).
column43: Inhabits torrential streams with clear water and moderate canopy cover (Shaji and Easa 2003) with boulders, cobbles and bed rock as the major substrates (A. Ali and R. Raghavan per. obs.). Known to be a habitat specialist with affinity towards pool, riffles and cascades (Manojkumar and Kurup 2002). It is a herbivorous feeder subsisting on plants, seeds and algae (Thomas 2004).
column49: In Chalakudy River, O. longidorsalis is threatened by the presence of exotic species, destructive fishing methods, increasing tourism and pollution (Raghavan et al. 2008a, b). There is also a threat from a proposed hydroelectric power project. In Periyar River, the species is under threat from destructive fishing practices including dynamiting and poisoning (A. Ali and R.Raghavan pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is an urgent need to carry out research to generate baseline data on population, life history traits, ecology and exploitation. Captive breeding and milt cryopreservation techniques have developed at NBFGR (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).

column10: English–Nash Barb, Black Border Tail Orange, Chandkas Barb
column11: Barbus nashii Day, 1869,  Cyprinion nashii (Day, 1869), Osteochilichthys godavariensis Babu Rao, 1977,  Osteochilichthys nashii (Day, 1869),  Osteochilus malabaricus Day, 1873
column12: Osteochilus nashii was described by Day (1869) from Fraserpet River, at the base of Coorg hills, Karnataka, India as Barbus nashii. The generic status of this species has often been debated. In later years Day (1877) himself consider this species as Scaphiodon nashii while Hora (1942), and subsequently Talwar and Jhingran (1991), treated this species as Osteochilus (Osteochilichthys) nashii. Jayaram (1999) considered this species as Osteochilichthys nashii and the species appears as Cyprinion nashii in Menon (1999). Currently the species is valid as Osteochilus nashii. Menon (1999) considered another species Osteochilus godavarensis as a synonym of Osteochilus nashii without giving any reason and currently this synonymy is considered as valid. However, the two species are remarkably different as the former has two pairs of barbels while the later is completely devoid of barbels (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999) and there are several other major differences as well (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column19: Ali, A., Raghavan, R. & Dahanukar, N.
column20: Osteochilus nashii is widely distributed.  Several localized threats have been identified and the species has declined in the rivers of Maharashtra.  However, due to its wide distribution and no major threat to the species, it is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: This species is endemic to Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is known from the rivers Tungabhadra (Bhimachar and Rao1941, David 1956, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Sharavathi (Sreekantha et al. 2007), Bedti (Bhat 2004), Bhavani and Moyar  (Mukerji 1931, Rajan 1955, 1963), Chandragiri, Chaliyar, Kabini, Valapatnam (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000, Easa and Basha 1995, Kurup et al. 2004, Shaji and Easa 1995), Uruttipuzha and Cheenkannipuzha (Shaji et al. 1995),  Pavana (Patil et al. 2007), Mula-Mutha (Kharat et al. 2003, Suter 1944, Wagh and Ghate 2003) and Koyana river (Jadhav et al. 2011). Thomas et al. (2002) collected O. nashii from River Periyar, the first (and only) record from south of the Palakkad gap. However, subsequent surveys in the same river and its tributaries, and also other rivers south of Palakkad gap by various researchers (Kurup et al. 2004, Kurup et al. 2006) did not result in the collection of this species. It is therefore reasonable to suspect that Thomas et al. (2002) record of O. nashii from Periyar was a misidentification. David (1963) suggested that O. nashii is present in Krishna river but not in Godavari river. Menon (1999) synonymized Osteocheilus godavarensis (Rao 1977) with O. nashii extending the range of O. nashii to Godavari river. However, these two species are remarkably different (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999, Neelesh Dahanukar pers. obs.). Thus, as the synonymy is doubtful, presence of O. nashii in Godavari river is also doubtful.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: The species is known to have declined in the rivers of Maharashtra as per fisher folk (N. Dahanukar pers. comm.).  There is no information on population trends in other parts of its distribution.
column43: Known to occur  in the upper and middle reaches of rivers. It prefers riffles and pools. Attains a total length of 18 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column49: Local populations of O. nashii are threatened by habitat alterations in the river systems as a result of pollution from domestic and agricultural sources (Wagh and Ghate 2003, Bhat 2004) and destructive fishing practices (Easa and Basha 1995).  Mining and sedimentation in lower reaches of Bhadra, Kudremukh National Park is also a threat to the local populations.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to determine the life history and demography of the species to inform management decisions. Research is required to understand the population size, distributions, population trends, life history, ecology, harvest and threats to the species. Monitorying the population trends, harvest levels trends, trade trends and habitat trends could help in designing and implementing conservation strategies. A species level action and recovery plan can be helpful to save wild populations of the species.

column60: Ali, A., Raghavan, R. & Dahanukar, N. 2010. Osteochilus nashii. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 20 October 2011.

column12: Parapsilorhynchus discophorus was described by Hora (1921) from Pophli in the Vashishti valley, Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra. Menon (1999) considered this species as a synonym of Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus following Hora (1925). However, this synonymy is invalid because P. discophorus is distinctly different from P. tentaculatus (Yazdani and Rao 1977, Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Parapsilorhynchus discophorus is endemic to the northern Western Ghats. Its extent of occurrence is around 7,500 km_, and it is found in 3-5 locations. The population is threatened by habitat modification due to recreational activities especially on the mountain tops.
column26: Parapsilorhynchus discophorus is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). The species is found in both east and west flowing rivers of northern Western Ghats (Yadav 2003). It is found in the Koyna River east of Mahabaleshwar and further southwest in Vasisthi Valley in Ratnagiri district (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). The estimated extent of occurrence for this fish is around 7,500 km_ based on the area of the hydro-basins in which it is found.
column35: Quantitative estimate of population trends of Parapsilorhynchus discophorus are not available. However, the species is relatively common in the Koyana River and associated streams (Jadhav et al. 2011).
column43: Parapsilorhynchus discophorus is found in first, second and third order seasonal streams during monsoon season and it prefers rapid moving shallow clear water with the bottom made up of sand or pebbles (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). As the streams start drying, the species migrates downstream in the associated river; it shows altitudinal migration for breeding. It mainly feeds on diatoms and algae (Dahanukar et al, Unpublished). Deforestation leading to siltation and recreational activities on the mountains can destroy the habitat of this fish and such changes are common in the area where the fish is found.
column49: Deforestation and recreational activities on the mountain lead to siltation and degrade the habitat required by Parapsilorhynchus discophorus for reproduction. Such changes are common in the areas where the species is found (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column53: Currently there is no specific conservation action plan directed towards Parapsilorhynchus discophorus. However, some part of the population is expected to be conserved in Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary. Further research and monitoring is essential to understand population status and threats to this species. Habitat and resource protection could help in conserving this endemic species.

column12: Parapsilorhynchus elongatus was described by Singh (1994) from Ghod River, Khondwal village, Ambegaon taluka, Pune District, Maharashtra, India.
column18: Arunachalam, M., Ali, A., Krishna , K.K. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Parapsilorhynchus elongatus is assessed as Endangered as it has a restricted distribution in the northern Western Ghats with a range of less than 5,000 km_ and occurring in only two severely fragmented locations. The species is threatened by ongoing decline in quality of critical habitats caused by increased tourism and deforestation.
column26: Parapsilorhynchus elongatus is endemic to the northern Western Ghats in the state of Maharashtra (Yadav 2003). Its extent of occurrence is restricted to less than 5,000 km_.
column35: No information is available on the population status of this species. However it is commonly seen in the upper tributaries during the monsoon season (N. Dahanukar pers.obs.).
column43: This species is found in first to third order seasonal streams during monsoon season and prefers rapid moving shallow clear water with a sandy and pebbly bottom (N. Dahanukar pers.obs). As the streams start drying, the species migrates downstream to the main river; this fish undergoes altitudinal migration for breeding. Deforestation leading to siltation and recreational activities on the mountains can destroy the breeding habitat for this fish and such changes are common in this area. This species is also threatened by tourism in the Bhimasankar area (N. Dahanukar pers.obs.).
column49: Increasing tourism and other recreational activities as well as deforestation (resulting in siltation) has led to the decline in quality of critical habitats of this species, especially on the mountain tops where the first to third order streams originate (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. It is not present in any protected areas.

column12: Parapsilorhynchus prateri was first described from Darna River in the upper Godavari River basin, Deolali, Nasik District, Maharashtra State, India (Hora and Misra 1938).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Parapsilorhynchus prateri is assessed as Critically Engendered (Possibly Extinct). Despite the fact that its inferred extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,500–3,000 km_, its area of occupancy (AOO) is less than 10 km_ and it is estimated as occurring in just one location as deforestation and invasive species are impacting all of the four streams as well as the main river. The information is based on historic records as no specimens have been caught even after several surveys in the area.
column26: Parapsilorhynchus prateri is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is currently known only from Darna River in upper Godavari River basin, Deolali, Nasik District, Maharashtra State, India (Hora and Misra 1937, 1940, Jayaram 1999, Menon 1999). The type locality and surrounding areas have been surveyed repeatedly since 2004, but the species has not been recorded (S. Jadhav and N. Dahanukar pers. comm.).
column35: Exact population trends are not available for Parapsilorhynchus prateri, however, the species has never been found in the type locality or adjacent basins since its description even after recent extensive sampling in the areas (S. Jadhav and N. Dahanukar, pers. comm.).
column43: Parapsilorhynchus prateri is recorded from hill streams with rocky gradients and it attains a maximum length of 5.9 cm standard length (Menon 1999).
column49: The habitat of this species (hill streams with clear water and pebbles as substrate) is highly degraded because of deforestation in the area leading to siltation. There is also organic and agricultural pollution, and introduced fishes, in particular Oreochromis mossambicus which has remarkably increased in population in the last few decades and has threatened populations of most of the species in this area (Neelesh Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Parapsilorhynchus prateri, however, site protection is suggested for conservation of this threatened species. Research is needed to understand presence/absence, population trends, life history, ecology and threats to this species.

column12: Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus was originally described as Psilorhynchus tentaculatus by Annandale (1919) from Khandala near Pune and Yenna River at Medha in the Satara district, Maharashtra. Hora (1921) changed the generic status of the fish to Parapsilorhynchus. This species is also recorded from Godavari river in Satpura hill ranges and Eastern Ghats. This wide distribution and isolated records suggests that there is a need to evaluate the taxonomic identity of this species. It is possible that the species known as Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus is in fact a species complex. Further taxonomic studies aided with molecular phylogeny are essential to resolve this problem.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus is assessed as Least Concern because of its wide spread distribution in Krishna and Godavari river basins. The species is also very common and ubiquitously present in primary and secondary streams of northern Western Ghats during monsoon season. Nevertheless, deforestation and recreational activities on the mountain tops are threatening the preferred habitat of the fish. Furthermore, if the taxonomic research on the species reveals that the populations in Krishna and Godavari are different, the species should be reassessed for its proper threat status.
column26: Unlike other Parapsilorhynchus species, which show relatively restricted distribution range, Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus has been recorded from a wide geographical range from west flowing rivers in northern Maharashtra (Annandale 1919, Singh and Yazdani 1988, Arunachalam et al. 2002, Yadav 2003), Krishna river system (Fraser 1942, Silas 1953, Wagh and Ghate 2003) and Godavari river system (Hora 1938, Hora and Nair 1941, Menon 1951, Devi and Menon 1995, Yadav 2003). Report of this species from Narmada river (Vyas et al. 2007) needs conformation. Thus, the species has been recorded from Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Andhra Pradesh. Since the species is reported from wide geographical range with isolated records from areas beyond Western Ghats, it is difficult to predict the EOO of the species and number of locations.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra)
column35: There is no information on the population trends in Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus. However, the species is fairly common in the northern Western Ghats of India and in the monsoon season it is abundant in the first and second order streams (N. Dahanukar pers. comm.).  It is very rare in Arakku Valley (K.R. Devi pers. comm.).
column43: Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus is found in primary, secondary and tertiary seasonal streams during monsoon season and it prefers rapid moving shallow clear water with the bottom made up of sand or pebbles (Menon 1999). As the streams start drying, the species migrates downstream in the associated river. Species show altitudinal migration for breeding and breeds between June and July when the monsoon is active (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). Deforestation leading to siltation and recreational activities on the mountains can destroy the habitat of this fish and such changes are common in the area where the fish is found (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). The species attains a total length of 4.5 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: The hill stream habitats of Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus are affected by deforestation and recreational activities, especially on the mountain tops, in the northern Western Ghats (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs), and deforestation and tourism in the Eastern Ghats (K.R. Devi pers. comm.).
column53: Research is essential on taxonomy, population trends, distribution and threats to Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus.

column12: Puntius arenatus was originally described as Barbus arenatus by Day (1878) from Madras Presidency, India. While the species is considered valid by Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1991, 1999) the species was synonymized to Puntius melanostigma by Menon (1999).  Jayaram (2010) treats this as a separate species.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Shaji, C.P., Shrikant, J., Arunachalam, M., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius arenatus is a very rare fish with extent of occurrence, including inferred range is between 15000 and 17000 km2 and restricted to only three locations. Even though some part of its distribution is protected under Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve other areas are threatened mainly by organic and inorganic pollution. The species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Puntius arenatus is endemic to southern Western Ghats. It is found in Madras (Day 1878), Tambaraparani River (Devi et al. 1997), Ramanadhi river (Arunachalam et al. 2001) and Nambiyar river (Arunachalam et al. 2000) in Kalakad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu. Recently the species was also recorded from Achankovil river basin in Kerala (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009). Record of Puntius arenatus from Pune (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963) seems to be erroneous as the species has not been recorded from Pune and adjoining areas despite thorough search for the last ten years (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). Subsequent reports of this species from Pune by Tilak and Tiwari (1976) and Kharat et al. (2003) and from northern Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004) are based on the literature survey and thus could also be erroneous. Record of the species from Ahmedabad (Setna and Kulkarni 1946) needs confirmation.
column35: No information is available on the exact population status of Puntius arenatus. However, the species is suggested to be very rare (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column43: No precise information is available on the habitat and ecology of Puntius arenatus. However, based on the point localities it is possible that the fish prefers moderately flowing streams, canals and outlets of wetlands (J. A. Johnson pers. obs.). According to Talwar and Jhingran (1991) the species attains a standard length of 10 cm.
column49: The area in which Puntius arenatus is found is threatened by organic and industrial pollution. However, some part of its range is protected under Kalakkad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for protecting Puntius arenatus. However, some part of its range is protected under Kalakkad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve. Research is essential on the population status, life history, ecology and threats to the species.

column10: English–Red Side Barb, Two Spot Barb
column11: Gnathopogon bimaculatus Bleeker, 1863,  Puntius (Capoeta) puckelli Day, 1868
column12: Puntius bimaculatus was described by Bleeker (1844) from Sri Lanka. Puntius puckelli Day, 1868 described from Bangalore was considered a synonym of P. dorsalis Jerdon, by Hora (   ) who considered this as a juvenile of the latter. Subsequently Menon and Devi (1992) observed that P. puckelli was distinct from P. dorsalis and placed it under P. bimaculatus of Sri Lanka. The currently valid P. bimaculatus population in India if found to be distinct from the Sri Lankan P. bimaculatus, will assume the original name P. puckelli.
column18: Shaji, C.P., Gopalakrishnan, A., Rema Devi, K.R., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius bimaculatus has a wide distribution in all the southern peninsular states in India and Sri Lanka.  Although some threats have been identified locally, these are not major threats to the species, hence it is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Puntius bimaculatus is endemic to India and Sri Lanka. It is widely distributed in Sri Lanka and in India in Kerala, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra. In Tamil Nadu, P. bimaculatus has been recorded from the rivers Cauvery (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009), Tambraparini (Devi et al. 1997, Arunachalam 2000), Moyar (Arunachalam et al. 2000); In Karnataka from the Hemavathi, Ekatchi, Tunga (Arunachalam et al. 2000) as well as the Bedti River (Bhat 2004) ; In Maharashtra from the Phansad River (Arunachalam 2000); In Kerala from Chalakudy River (Raghavan et al. 2008). The species has also been collected from water bodies inside the Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Remadevi et al.2005).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu); Sri Lanka
column35: There is no information on the population status of P. bimaculatus.
column43: It occurs in middle and upper stretches of rivers.
column49: P. bimaculatus may be threatened as a result of on-going decline in quality of habitat due to pollution from domestic sources as well as plantations, exotic fish species and destructive fishing practices.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to document information on population, ecology and life history of this species.
