column12: Puntius cauveriensis was described by Hora 1937 from the Cauvery River at Coorg.
column18: Ali, A., Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius cauveriensis is assessed as Endangered, in view of its restricted extent of occurrence of less than 5,000 km2 and area of occupancy of less than 15 km2, with all individuals in two locations, and a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat due to expanding plantations, pesticide runoff and sedimentation.
column26: Puntius cauveriensis is endemic to the Western Ghats. It has been recorded from the Kannige River at Bhagamandala, Cauvery River at Chunchanaktte, Chitturpuzha at Palaghat and Malampuzha (Jayaram 1999; Arunachalam et al. 2004).
column35: This is a rare species with little information available on the population size or trends.
column43: This species is mostly found in shallow pools with a pebble and gravel substrate. It can be common in pools below waterfalls.
column49: It is threatened at the type locality by the impacts of a nearby coffee plantation (pesticides, sedimentation, conversion of forest to plantation use). The threats in other locations include expansion of plantations and pollution (organic and inorganic).
column53: It has not been recorded from any protected areas.
column59: IUCN. 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species (ver. 2011.1). Available at: http://www.iucnredlist.org. (Accessed: 16 June 2011).
column60: Shaji, C.P. 2010. Puntius cauveriensis. In: IUCN 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2011.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 20 October 2011.

column12: Puntius chalakkudiensis was described by Menon, Remadevi and Thobias (1999) from the Chalakudy River, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Shaji, C.P., Johnson, J.A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Rahul, K., Krishna , K.K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius chalakkudiensis has been categorised as Endangered due to severely declining populations (50-70%) due to collections for the aquarium pet trade in addition to other threats that has resulted in the decline in the quality of habitat and also from exotic species introductions.
column26: Previously thought to be endemic to River Chalakudy (Menon et al. 1999), Puntius chalakkudiensis has recently been recorded from Periyar (R. Raghavan and A. Ali pers. obs.).  The populations of (which were once called) P. denisonii south of Palghat gap is now considered P. chalakkudiensis based on genetic analysis (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).  Its distribution is restricted to the upper and middle reaches of Chalakkudy, Periyar, Pamba and Achankovil rivers.
column35: On-going studies of Conservation Research Group (CRG), St. Albert's College, Kochi indicate that the species is more abundant in remote habitats (often inside protected areas) in Periyar, Pampa and Achenkovil rivers compared to those outside it (R. Raghavan pers. comm.). In a study by NBFGR, Kochi, the populations of Periyar and Chalakkudy were found to be genetically homogeneous (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.). In a study by Kurup and Radhakrishnan (2006), the populations of P. denisonii in the various rivers of Kerala declined by 55-70% in five years (2000-2005) based on catch per unit effort.  The P. denisonii populations south of Palghat gap are currently known as P. chalakkudiensis.  Hence the decline rates in the populations are applicable to P. chalakkudiensis.  In another study the species declined by 25% from 2004-2007 based on secondary data from fish collectors (Mercy 2010).
column43: Known from mid stream (and rarely in upstreams) reaches of rivers where they inhabit rocky pools with vegetation on its banks. Substrates vary from sand to bed rock (R.Raghavan and A. Ali pers.obs.).
column49: Apart from the general threats to riverine habitats in Periyar, Chalakudy and Pampa like pollution from domestic sources and plantations, habitat alteration due to dams and barrages and destructive fishing practices (Kurup et al. 2004, Kurup 2002, Raghavan et al. 2008), P. chalakkudiensis is also threatened by the un-managed collection for the international trade in aquarium fish.  In addition, exotic invasive fishes like O. mossambicus  pose a potential threat to the species in all rivers.  The proposed Athirapally hydro-electric project in the type locality might also have an adverse impact on the species.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. Although the Government of Kerala has brought in legislation to regulate the fishery and trade of P. denisonii, P. chalakkudiensis has not been included in the plan (Mittal 2009). There is a need to understand the actual distribution range of P. chalakkudiensis as on-going studies have recorded individuals (which were thought to be P. denisonii) from various locations in South Kerala, having exact morphological characters of P. chalakkudiensis (A.Ali and R. Raghavan pers.obs.). Baseline information need to be generated on the life history and population of this endemic species.  Experimental captive breeding have been attempted with some success (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).

column12: Puntius crescentus was described by Yazdani and Singh (1994) from Kali Nadi at Sunkeri, Karnataka, India. There is a need to establish the precise taxonomic status of the species as is has several characters similar to another species P. vittatus.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Shaji, C.P., Johnson, J.A., Arunachalam, M., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius crescentus is known only from its type locality in the Kali Nadi of Karnataka as its report from Kerala (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009) needs validation. The EOO is inferred to be between 3000-5000 based on the area of the hydrobasins where it is projected to occur. As there are 4 major dams on this river (Bhat 2004) the projected population might be fragmented. Further, since this river is known to be heavily polluted by industrial effluents (Bhat 2004) it is likely that the habitat quality is declining. Therefore, based on the presence information this species is assessed as Endangered. Nevertheless, there is little information on the species and there seems to be some doubt regarding its placement vis-a-vis P. vittatus, it is recommended that more surveys are conducted in the type area to establish the presence of this species and also compare it with the known P. vittatus.
column26: Puntius crescentus is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is found only in the west flowing river (Yadav 2003). Until recently this species was known only from its type locality in Kali River at Sunkeri, Karnataka, India (Yazdani and Singh 1994). Recently, however, this species was reported from Chalakkudy and Muvattupuzha rivers in Ernakulam District, Kerala, India (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009). This report is not backed up with any taxonomic or range extension note and thus it needs verification.
column35: No information is available on the population status of Puntius crescentus. Nevertheless, recent study on the Kali Nadi, the type locality of the fish, has not reported this fish (Bhat 2004). Beevi and Ramachandran (2009) suggest this species as common in both Chalakkudy and Muvattupuzha rivers in Ernakulam District, Kerala. However, as the presence of this species in Kerala is doubtful its status in Kerala cannot be considered as valid.
column43: The species is recorded from perennial river (Yazdani and Singh 1994). No information is available on the ecology of this species. Holotype of this species is 29 mm in length (Yazdani and Singh 1994).
column49: No specific information is available on the threats to this species but untreated industrial effluents released directly into the river are causing habitat alterations in the area from where the fish is reported (Bhat 2004).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for this species. There is a need to generate baseline information on the population trends, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Puntius deccanensis was described by Yazdani and Rao (1976) from Nalla near Katraj Tank, Poona, Maharashtra, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Rahul, K., Arunachalam, M. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius deccanensis is restricted to only two lakes of less than 4 km_ area. It is threatened by anthropogenic activities and the species has not been recorded since the first description although several surveys have been conducted in and around the type locality. The species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct). Detailed surveys are recommended to establish the presence/absence of the species as well as to make a more detailed taxonomic study vis-a-vis P. fraseri.
column26: Puntius deccanensis is endemic to the northern Western Ghats (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). However, there is no information on the distribution of this species other than from its type locality. Surveys in the type locality have not found the species (N. Dahanukar pers. comm.). Recent surveys conducted in areas around the type locality have also not recorded this species (Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, Chandanshive et al. 2007).
column35: There is no information on the population of P. deccanensis.
column43: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
column49: The upper lake is affected by domestic waste and detergents, and organic pollution. The lower lake is inside a snake park, but the run-off from the upper lake may have some impact on the lower lake.
column53: There is a need to determine the taxonomic validity of the species as well as its distribution and population status.

column12: Puntius fraseri was originally described as Barbus fraseri by Hora and Misra (1939) from Darna river, Deolali, Nashik, Maharashtra.
column18: Gopalakrishnan, A., Rema Devi, K.R., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K., Shrikant, J. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius fraseri is assessed as Endangered as its distribution range is only 2500-3000 km2 and the number of fragmented locations are 5. The habitat from where Puntius fraseri is recorded is threatened by organic pollution, agricultural pollution, introduced fishes and heavy harvesting. Further, it seems that the populations of this species are decreasing. The last known collection of this species was in 1956 although a collection from 1978 has been recently tentatively identified as P. fraseri.  Several surveys in and around the type locality has not revealed the presence of this species.  It is likely that the species may be more threatened than what is assessed presently.  The taxonomic identity of the collections from Sholapur and Krishna drainage have to be thoroughly examined to establish the species' distribution range.
column26: Puntius fraseri is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is found in Darna river, an upper tributary of the Godavari river system, in Deolali, Nashik (Hora and Misra 1939). Kalawar and Kelkar (1956) reported the species from Panchaganga river, an upper tributary of the Krishna river system, in Kolhapur. Even though, Kalawar and Kelkar (1956) have given detailed taxonomic comment in support of their report, presence of this species in Krishna river system is highly unlikely. An extensive survey of the Krishna river system by Jayaram (1995) could not report this species. Furthermore, the species has not been recorded by any other study in Krishna river system. A more detailed investigation is required to conform the presence of the species in the Krishna river system. Both Jayaram (1991) and Talwar and Jhingran (1991) have restricted the species only to the Darna river. Recently, a collection from Sholapur district done in 1978 by A.S. Mahabal, was identified as P. fraseri (S. Jadhav pers. comm.), however, this report needs confirmation. Report of the species from Pune by Menon (1999) is a result of synonymization of Puntius deccanensis with P. fraseri. However, this synonymy is not considered valid. Therefore, Puntius fraseri is restricted only to the Darna river in Nashik and the expected extent of occurrence of 2500-3000 km2 and 5 number of locations.
column35: Exact population trends are not available for Puntius fraseri, however, the population seems to be declining and it is rarely found in its type locality (S. Jadhav, pers. comm.).  There is no record of this species since it was last recorded in 1956.  Several surveys in the river Darna and other areas close to the type locality have not yielded this species (S. Jadhav pers. comm.)
column43: Puntius fraseri inhabits hill streams and it attains a total length of 4.6 cm (Menon 1999). The habitat of this fish is threatened by organic pollution, agricultural pollution and introduced fishes (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.), human settlements and agricultural pollution from vineyards (S. Jadhav pers. comm.).
column49: The area from where Puntius fraseri is recorded is threatened by organic pollution, agricultural pollution, and introduced fishes (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Puntius fraseri, however, site protection is suggested for conservation of this threatened species. Research is needed to understand population trends, life history, ecology and threats to this species.

column12: Puntius kannikattiensis is recently described species by Arunachalam and Johnson (2003) from Tamiraparani River, Kalakad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve, Tirunelveli district, Tamil Nadu, India.
column18: Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius kannikattiensis is assessed as Least Concern because even though the species is known only from two locations restricted in its range to less than 2000 km2, the known populations are from a protected area. However, there is a need for research on population status, life history and threats to the species.
column26: The species is endemic to the southern Western Ghats of India and is known from Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve of Tamil Nadu (Arunachalam and Johnson 2003, 2009).
column35: There is no information on the population status of this species.
column43: Puntius kannikattiensis is known from hill streams.
column49: Threats to the species are not known.
column53: No information is avilable

column12: Puntius mudumalaiensis was described by Menon and Devi (1992) from Kakkanhalla stream in Mudumalai, Tamil Nadu.
column18: Ali, A., Dahanukar, N., Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius mudumalaiensis has been recorded from only two locations. Its habitat is under threat from development activities and dams resulting in declining quality in the non-protected location. The inferred extent of occurrence is around 12,000 km_, hence it is assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Puntius mudumalaiensis is endemic to the Western Ghats, where it is known from the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary (Menon and Devi 1992, Manimekalan 1998) and the freshwater bodies of Dharmapuri District (Devi and Raghunathan 1999) of Cauvery drainage.
column35: Puntius mudumalaiensis is a rare species (Manimekalan 1998).
column43: It is likely to occur in the headwaters of rivers with clear, fast flowing water with a substrate of cobbles and gravel (R. Kumar and M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column49: The habitat in Dharmapuri is under threat due to deforestation and agricultural runoff from pineapple cultivation (Rahul Kumar and M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column53: There is no specific conservation action plan directed towards this species. The species is known from Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary. Research is essential on population trends, life history and specific threats to the species.

column12: Puntius muvattupuzhaensis was first described by Beevi and Ramachandran (2005) from the Muvattupuzha River, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius muvattupuzhaensis is a newly described species and the current knowldge of its distribution is based on the type description. Although it is restricted in its distribution, the species is assigned to Data Deficient category for want of more information.
column26: Puntius muvattupuzhaensis is so far reported from the middle and lower reaches of Muvattupuzha and Periyar rivers, Kerala, India (Beevi and Ramchandran 2005, 2009).  The distribution of this species is not completely understood as yet.
column35: There is no information on the population status of P. muvattupuzhaensis. Recent reports however indicate that the species is rare (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009).
column43: Puntius muvattupuzhaensis prefers low land reaches of rivers with sand and gravel as major substrates.
column49: Puntius muvattupuzhaensis in Periyar River is threatened by habitat deterioration as a result of untreated domestic effluents and industrial wastes (KSCSTE 2009).
column53: No known conservation actions are in place for P. muvattupuzhaensis. There is a need for research on life history and demography of the species to form the basis for future conservation and management.

column12: Puntius ophicephalus was described by Raj (1941) from Kallar, a tributary of Pampa River, a few miles south of Periyar Lake, Kerala, Travancore, India. This species was re-discovered after half a century at Mlappara inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve (Zacharias et al 1996).  This fish was placed in the genus Eechathalakenda by Menon (1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius ophicephalus is assessed as Endangered because of its limited extent of occurrence (< 4000 km2), area of occupancy (<80 km2) and number of locations (<5). There is also a continuing decline in habitat quality, and on-going threat from exotic fish species.
column26: Puntius ophicephalus is endemic to southern part of the Western Ghats Hotspot (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the rivers, Periyar (Zacharias et al. 1996, Arun 1999), Pampa (Raj 1941) and Meenachil (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2002) in Kerala.  It's range also extends to Tamil Nadu in upstream of Vaigai river (Arunachalam et al. 2004).
column31: Native: India (Kerala, Tamil Nadu - Presence Uncertain)
column35: There is no information on the population status of P. ophicephalus. The species is however considered to be rare (Zacharias et al. 1996, Thomas et al. 2002).
column43: Known from torrential streams (Arun 1999) where they occur in rocky pools (Kurup et al. 2004). Bedrock, cobble and gravel are the major substrates (Chhapgar and Manakadan 2000). P. ophicephalus is known to be an omnivore (Arun 1999).
column49: P. ophicephalus is threatened by the presence of exotic fish species in Periyar Lake-Stream system inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve. The other areas are affected by development activities resulting in decline in the quality of habitat.
column53: There is a need to generate baseline information on the distribution, life history and demography of this rare species.

column12: Puntius pookodensis was first described by Mercy and Jacob (2007) from Pookode Lake, Wayanad, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius pookodensis is endemic to the Western Ghats where it is restricted to Pookode Lake (2 km_) in Kerala. Recent records from streams and pools inside the Wyanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala need to be confirmed. Pookode Lake is under threat from anthropogenic activities, including tourism. Water regulation during different seasons may also have a negative impact on this fish. The species is therefore assessed as Critically Endangered as it has a restricted area of occupancy (2 km_), and occurs in one location. If the records from Wyanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala are confirmed to be this species then it would qualify for Endangered as the species will be found in two locations.
column26: Puntius pookodensis is endemic to the Western Ghats where it is thought be restricted to Pookode Lake (Mercy and Jacob 2007) in Kerala. It has recently been recorded from streams and pools inside the Wyanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala (A. Ali and R. Raghavan pers. comm.) but these need to be confirmed.
column35: There is no information on the population status of P. pookodensis.
column43: No information is available on the habitat and ecology of P. pookodensis.
column49: P. pookodensis is endemic to Wayanad District of Kerala, India where it occurs in the Pookode Lake, which is one of the most visited tourist destination in northern Kerala and anthropogenic impacts due to increased tourism including pollution are threats to this species (R. Raghavan and A.Ali pers.obs).
column53: No conservation actions are in place for P. pookodensis. There is a need to determine the distribution, population status, life history and ecology of the species to inform management decisions. Captive breeding techniques developed (Mercy et al. 2007). The records from Wyanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala need to be confirmed.

column12: Puntius punctatus was described by Day (1865) from the erstwhile princely state of Cochin , Kerala, India. Day (1889) later changed the generic status of the fish to Barbus. Hora, Misra and Malik (1939) synonymized Puntius punctatus to a more widely distributed species Puntius ticto. However, Silas (1939) considered P. punctatus as a valid subspecies P. ticto punctatus. Even though Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1991, 1999) considered Puntius punctatus as a synonym of Puntius ticto; Menon (1999) and Devi et al. (2007) have considered Puntius punctatus as a valid species.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius punctatus is assessed as Least Concerned solely based on the fact that the inferred extent of occurrence for this species is more than any threatened category. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that the species is very rare and the area in which the species is found is threatened by urbanization, tourism, invasive fish species and agricultural pollution.
column26: Puntius punctatus is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. It seems to be restricted to the west flowing rivers. It is found in Wyanad (Shaji and Easa 1995) and Ernakulam (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009) in Kerala and Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (Devi et al. 2005, 2007) and also in the west flowing rivers in Kanyakumari district (Johnson and Arunachalam 2009) in Tamil Nadu, India. Since the species is present in Wayanad it is possible that it could also be recorded from west flowing rivers Netravathi and Kumaradhara of Karnataka (R. Kumar pers. comm.). A report of this species from Sri Lanka (Menon 1999) needs confirmation. In addition, reports of the species from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963) may be erroneous.
column35: Puntius punctatus is a common species throughout its range.
column43: Puntius punctatus is found in streams and ponds and attains a total length of 7.5 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: No particular threats have been recorded for Puntius punctatus, however, the area where the species is found is affected by urbanization, tourism, invasive fish species and agricultural pollution (Raghavan et al. 2008).
column53: No particular conservation action plan is in place directed towards Puntius punctatus. Research is essential on population status, life history, ecology, use and trade and threats to this species.

column12: Puntius rohani is a recently described species from hill streams of Kanyakumari District, Tamil Nadu, India (Devi et al. 2010). It was earlier considered as a variety of P. filamentosus based on the genetic study (Johnson et al. 2007).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius rohani is assessed as Vulnerable because the area of occupancy of the species is less than 10 km2 and the populations are in 5 fragmented locations. Furthermore, the area from where P. rohani is reported has several potential threats including urban development, tourism, invasive species, agricultural pollution and excessive harvesting.
column26: Puntius rohani is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is at present known only from the hill streams of Kanyakumari District, Tamil Nadu, India, draining into the Arabian Sea (Devi et al. 2010).
column35: No information on the population trends is available for Puntius rohani.
column43: Puntius rohani is found in hill streams (Devi et al. 2010). Maximum size of the fish is recorded as 95 mm standard length.
column49: The area from where Puntius rohani is reported has several threats including urban development, tourism, invasive species, agricultural pollution and excessive harvesting (Knight 2010).
column53: Currently there is no conservation plan directed towards Puntius rohani. Research is needed to generate further information on lifehistory, ecology, population trends, use and trade and threats to this species.

column12: Puntius sahyadriensis was described by Silas (1953) from Yenna river, Mahabalehwar, Satara district, Maharashtra, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: P. sahyadriensis is Least Concern due to its wide distribution and lack of serious overall threats.
column26: Puntius sahyadriensis is endemic to the northern and central Western Ghats (Dahanukar et al. 2004). Known from the rivers Yenna (Silas 1953), Koyana, Krishna at Wai (Arunachalam et al. 2002, N. Dahanukar pers. comm.), from rivers Sharavati (Sreekantha et al. 2007), Thunga (Arunachalam and Muralidharan 2008), Bhadra (Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Aghanashini and Bedti (Bhat 2004), Sita (R. Kumar pers. comm.). in Karnataka.
column35: There is no information on the current population status of P. sahyadriensis, but the species is generally considered to be rare (Menon 1999).  It is very common in Satara and Tunga.
column43: Known to occur in hill streams (Menon 1999) and rivers.  Prefers shallow water pool or run.
column49: Some river systems where P. sahyadriensis are known to occur including Sharavati, Bhadra and Tunga have been impacted by pollution from both domestic and industrial sources (Shahnawaz et al. 2010, Bhat 2004) and in Krishna at Wai (N. Dahanukar pers. comm.). The collection of fingerlings and juveniles of P. sahyadriensis for the international aquarium pet trade could lead to future population declines if not regulated.  In Radhanagari Wildlife Sanctuary introduced aliens Gambusia affinis and Poecilia reticulata are major threats to this species.
column53: No conservation actions are in place. As P. sahyadriensis is an important species in the international aquarium pet trade under the name 'Maharaja Barb' or 'Khavli Barb' there is a need for managing the harvest through quotas or catch limits (R. Raghavan pers.obs.). As the species continues to be poorly known, there is a need to generate baseline data on its life history and demography, which can aid in managing harvests. Attempts also need to be made to develop captive breeding and mass scale seed production technology to ease pressure on wild collection for the pet trade.

column12: Puntius setnai was first described by Chhapgar and Sane (1992) from Sanguem and Ponda in Goa, India. Previously this species was confused with Puntius nigrofasciatus (Yazdani 1977) and Puntius narayani (Chhapgar and Sane 1980).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius setnai is currently known from only two hydro-basins with an estimated area of occupancy of around 1,600 to 2,000 km_. The species is known from only three populations which may represent three locations. Furthermore, the area in which the species is found is under pressure from tourism, urbanization and agricultural pollution. Thus, the species is assessed as Vulnerable.
column26: Puntius setnai is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is found only in west flowing rivers (Yadav 2003). It is known from Sanguem and Phonda in Goa (Chhapgar and Sane 1992, Yadav 2008) and Hoshangadi in Karnataka (Yazdani and Ghate 1994) and southern Karnataka (M. Arunachalam, pers. comm.). Even though the potential range of this fish could be large, currently it is known only from two basins with area of occupancy of around 1,600-2,000 km_.
column35: No information is known about the precise population status of Puntius setnai. The species is reported to be common in Hoshangadi, Karnataka (Yazdani and Ghate 1994), however, Menon (1999) has considered this species to be rare. This species is also rare in southern Karnataka (M. Arunachalam , pers comm.).
column43: Puntius setnai is found in shallow and clear hill streams (Yazdani and Ghate 1994, Menon 1999) with leaf litter. It attains a length of 57 mm total length (Menon 1999).
column49: The area in which Puntius setnai is found is affected by tourism, urbanization and agricultural pollution.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place to save Puntius setnai. However, site protection could be helpful. Research is essential to understand the population status, life history, ecology and threats to the species.

column12: Puntius tambraparniei was described as P. arulius tambraparniei from Tambraparini River, Tamil Nadu by Silas (1953). Pethiyagoda and Kottelat (2005) in their revision of the Puntius filamentosus complex raised it to specific status.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius tambraparniei is assessed as Endangered as it has a restricted distribution of less then 5000 km2 extent and less than 100km2 area occurring in only 3 to 5 fragmented locations. There are ongoing threats the species including habitat decline due to removal of riparian cover, sand mining and industrial and organic pollution and exploitation for the aquarium trade.
column26: Puntius tambraparniei is endemic to the Western Ghats of India. All the current records of this species (Silas 1954, Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 2005, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009, Devi et al. 2010) are from the upper and middle reaches of Tambraparniei river basin in Tirunelveli District, southern Tamil Nadu.  The range of this species, based on the hydrobasin area, is between 4000-4500 km2, however the area is highly restricted to just 1-2% of the range, of less than 100 km2.
column35: Populations of the species are known to be declining (M. Arunachalam per. comm).
column43: Found in moderate flowing streams and rivers with bed rock and sandy bottom. Attains a total length of 9.2 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: Habitat loss due to removal of riparian cover, sand mining and industrial and organic pollution are the major threats. Collection for the aquarium trade is also a potential future threat.
column53: No known conservation actions are in place. Populations inside the lower Papanasam hydroelectric project and are not exploited. Some populations are protected in the Kalakkad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve. Nevertheless, research is required on the population trends, life history and specific threats to the species.

column11: Osteochilichthys thomassi (Day, 1877),  Osteochilus thomassi (Day, 1877), Scaphiodon thomassi Day, 1877
column12: Puntius thomassi was originally described as Scaphiodon thomassi by Day (1877) from South Canara (now southwestern Karnataka), India. Hora (1942)  revised the generic status of the fish and considered it as Osteochilus (Osteochilichthys) thomassi. Pethiyagoda and Kottelat (1994) and Jayaram (2010) consider this species as Osteochilichthys thomassi, while Menon (1999) has synonimized the species to Cyprinion nashii (Menon 1999). However, the species is valid in Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011). The correct taxonomic status of this species is Osteochilichthys thomassi.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius thomassi is assessed as Least Concern solely based on the fact that the extent of occurrence of this species exceeds any threatened category and currently there are no known major threats to the species. However, research is required on population trends, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Puntius thomassi is endemic to southern India in Kavery and southern tributaries of Krishna river system. It is known from Tamil Nadu (Devi et al. 2005), Kerala (Silas 1951, Ajithkumar 1999, Thomas et al. 2002), Karnataka (David 1956, 1963, Sahanawaz and Venkatheshwarlu 2009, Sahanawaz et al. 2010), Andhra Pradesh (Jayaram 1995) and Maharashtra (Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963). Record from Maharashtra by Tonapi and Mulherkar (1963) is likely to be wrong as other workers have not recoded this species from the same locality again (Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu)
column35: Puntius thomassi is sugggested to be very common in Tungabhadrs river (Sahanawaz and Venkatheshwarlu 2009) and Krishna river above the Nagarjunasagar Dam (Jayaram 1995). However it is rare in Kerala (Thomas et al. 2002).
column43: The species prefers large hill streams and rivers. It attains a total length of 32 cm and is a fast growing speceis (Talwar and Jhingran 1991). It is omnivorous and feeds on unicellular and filamentous algae, protozoans, copepods and mollusks (Menon and Chacko 1958).
column49: The threats to this species are unknown.

column12: Puntius vittatus was described by Day (1865) from Kochi, Kerala, India. Wide distribution of this species in India, Sri Lanka and Pakistan suggests that  there is a need to evaluate whether this is a single widely distributed species or a species complex.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Puntius vittatus has been assessed as Least Concern as the species has a very wide distribution in India, Sri Lanka and Pakistan with no major threat to the global population of the species although local populations are threatened because of aquarium trade, pollution and habitat alterations. However, it is essential to evaluate whether this is a single species or a species complex.
column26: Puntius vittatus is known from India, Sri Lanka and Pakistan (Jayaram 1991). It is widely distributed in west and east flowing rivers of peninsular India and is known from Kerala (Beevi and Ramachandran 2009, Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010, Baby et al. 2010), Goa (Tilak 1972), Karnataka (Talwar and Jhingran 1991), Tamil Nadu (Daniels and Rajgopal 2004, Ramanujam and Anbarasan 2009), Maharashtra (Chandanshive et al. 2007), Kutch (Talwar and Jhingran 1991), Bihar (Talwar and Jhingran 1991), Rajasthan (Talwar and Jhingran 1991) and Uttarkhand (Atkore et al. 2011).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Chattisgarh, Goa, Gujarat, Jharkand, Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa, Pondicherry, Punjab, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh); Pakistan; Sri Lanka
column35: Rare in Uttarakhand (V. Atkore per. comm.) and Maharashtra (Jadhav per. comm.). It is however very abundant in almost all rivers of Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu (A. Ali and R. Kumar per. comm).
column43: Inhabits ponds, streams, lakes in the plains and is also found in the paddy fields (Menon 1999). Found in shallow waters, with moderate flow and submerged vegetation. They are generally seen at the edges of small pools. It attains a total length of 5 cm (Menon 1999)..
column49: In middle and low land reaches, sand and boulder mining and illegal fishing are the major threats to the species. Aquarium trade is also a potential future threat. It has been suggested that introduced alien fishes could be a threat to this species (Krishnakumar et al. 2009).
column53: No known conservation actions are in place. Captive breeding has been developed since the last century. Habitat restoration should be given priority. Research is needed on exact distribution, population trends, harvest trends, ecology and specific threats to the species.

column12: Rasbora caverii was originally described as Leuciscus caverii by Jerdon (1849) from Kaveri River at Srirangapattana, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Rasbora caverii is a widely distributed species in the southern India and Sri Lanka. There are no known major threats to the species for its entire distributional range. Hence it is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Rasbora caveri is known from India and Sri Lanka (Menon 1999, Jayaram 2010). Presence of this species in Sri Lanka has been doubeted by Talwar and Jhingran (1991). In India it is known from Kaveri river system in  Karnataka and Tamil Nadu and Tambraparni river system in Tamil Nadu (Hora 1937, Cherian et al. 2000, Devi et al. 2005, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009). It is alos known from freshwater lakes in Chennai and Mysore (Daniels and Rajagopal 2004, Prasad et al. 2009). It is also known from Kovalam, Moyar and Kattappana rivers (R. Kumar pers. comm.). Records of this species from Krishna river system at Sholapur and Pune districts in Maharashtra by Jadhav and Yadav (2009) are likely to be based on wrong identification. This is because, in their rather vague species account authors mention that there are 32 scales along the lateral line, while Rasbora caverii, based on the more detailed re-description given by Hora (1937), has 36 to 37 scales.
column31: Native: India (Karnataka, Maharashtra - Presence Uncertain, Tamil Nadu); Sri Lanka
column35: Data on population status of this species is not available, however the species is common throughout its range.
column43: It is a pelagic species found in a wide variety of habitats often in large shoals. It is found in lowland forest streams and ponds to mountain streams and it attains a total length of 7 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: Habitat alteration, pollution, agricultural runoff and unintentional fishing could pose threat to the species in some areas of its distribution. However a major widespread threat is not known.
column53: Studies are required on population trends, life history, harvest trends and threats to the species.

column12: Rasbora labiosa Mukerji, 1935 was first described  from Darna river in upper Godavari river basin, Deolali, Nasik District, Maharashtra State, India (Hora and Mukerji 1935). The species is valid as Parluciosoma labiosa in Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Menon (1999), while it is valid as Rasbora labiosa in Jayaram (1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Rasbora labiosa is distributed in Maharashtra, Karnataka and Gujrat with localized threats to some populations.  However, the species is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Rasbora labiosa is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is currently known only from Darna river in upper Godavari river basin, Deolali, Nasik District, Maharashtra State, India (Hora and Mukerji 1935, Hora and Misra 1937, Jayaram 1999, Menon 1999). Extensive surveys in the other tributaries of upper Godavari river have not reveled this species indicating that the species is restricted to Darna river (S. Jadhav, pers. comm.). The species is also recorded from Baroda (now Vadodara) in Gujarat (Ranade 1953) and Mula-Mutha River of Krishna river system (Kharat et al. 2003).  It has been collected from Uyyampalli, Mysore, Vastara, Magadi tank in Karnataka (Devi et al., in press)
column35: Exact population trends are not available for Rasbora labiosa, however, the population seems to be declining and it is rarely found in its type locality (S. Jadhav, pers. comm.).
column43: Rasbora labiosa is recorded from rivers and hill streams and it has a maximum length of 8.5 cm total length (Menon 1999). The habitat of this fish, in its type locality, is threatened by organic pollution, agricultural pollution and introduced fishes  (N. Dahanukar, pers. obo.).
column49: The area from where Rasbora labiosa is recorded is threatened by organic pollution, agricultural pollution, introduced fishes and heavy harvesting (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Rasbora labiosa, however, site protection is suggested for conservation of this threatened species. Research is needed to understand population trends, life history, ecology and threats to this species.

column11: Mystacoleucus ogilbii (Sykes, 1839),  Osteobrama ogilbii (Sykes, 1839),  Systomus ogilbii (Sykes, 1839)
column12: Rohtee ogilbii was described by Sykes (1839) from Bhima river at Pairgaon, near Pune, Maharashtra, India. There was a debate over the generic status of this species. Heckel (1843) designated a new genus Osteobrama and and changed the status of Rohtee ogilbii to Osteobrama ogilbii. The status of the fish was changed to Systomus ogilbii by Bleeker (1853). Hora (1937) changed the generic status of the fish to Mystacoleucus, however, Smith (1945) objected to this change. Currently, Rohtee ogilbii is placed in a monotypic genera Rohtee, which is restricted to the peninsular India (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999, Menon 1999).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Rohtee ogilbii is assessed as Least Concern only based on the fact that the species is wide spread in northern Western Ghats. However, it is essential to note that the populations of this species, especially in the upper Godavary, Bhima and Tungabhadra river, are threatened by urban and industrial pollution, increasing urbanization, severe deforesting leading to siltation and invasive fish like Tilapia. Mula-Mutha river population has faced rapid declines in the last ten years. If such changes are also present in other areas where the fish is distributed, the species can qualify for some threatened category.
column26: Rohtee ogilbii is endemic to the northern Western Ghats of India (Ponniah and Gopalakrishnan 2000, Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is found in several tributaries of the Krishna river system including Bhima river near Pairgaon (Sykes 1839), Mula-Mutha River (Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003), Pavana river (Chandanshive et al. 2007), Panchaganga river in Kolhapur (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956), Neera river (Dahanukar et al, manuscript in review), Krishna river near Wai (Arunachal et al. 2002), Koyna river near Patan (Jadhav et al. 2011), Krishna river near Gadwal (Rahmullah 1946) and Tungabhadra river (Bhimachar and Rau 1941, David 1956, Arunachalam 2004, Shahnawaz et al. 2010). It is also found in Godavari river (David 1963, Arunachalam 2004, Menon 2004).  Thus the species is known from three states in India namely Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh.
column35: There is no documentation on precise population status of Rohtee ogilbii. However, it is suggested to be common (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Kharat et al. 2000, Jadhav et al. 2011). Nevertheless, based on the observations of past ten years, the population seems to be declining rapidly in Mula-Mutha river of Pune (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.). But no such observations are available for other localities from where the species is recorded. So the trend cannot be generalized.
column43: Rohtee ogilbii is found in hill streams, rivers and reservoirs (Rahmullah 1946, Menon 2004). It attains a total length of 15 cm (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Menon 2004).
column49: Menon (2004) considered Rohtee ogilbii as a vulnerable species based on the reasoning that "any small habitat changes in the higher reaches of the river by man or erosion on overgrazed areas could very well affect the species and cause its extinction". Such changes are occurring in the upper reaches of Krishna and Godavary river systems. Habitats of the fish in upper Godavari, Bhima and Tungabhadra river system are severely threatened by urban and industrial pollution, increasing urbanization, severe deforestation leading to siltation and invasive fish like Tilapia, Oreochromis mossambica, (David 1956, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, N. Dahanukar, pers obs.)
column53: Currently there is no conservation action plan in place directed towards Rohtee ogilbii. Research is essential for elucidating the population status, life history, ecology, harvest patterns and threats to the species.

column11: Chela argentea Day, 1867,  Pelecus diffusus Jerdon, 1849,  Salmostoma acinaces (Valenciennes, 1844)
column12: Salmophasia acinaces was originally described as Leuciscus acinaces by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1844) from Mysore, India.
column18: Raghavan, R. & Molur, S.
column20: Salmophasia acinaces is assessed as a Least Concern solely based on the fact that the species is widespread in peninsular India with no known major threats.
column26: Salmophasia acinaces is distributed in peninsular India (Menon 1999) and it is known from Krishna river system and all the river systems south of it. Record of this species from Nepal (Shrestha 2002), Bangladesh (Ali et al. 2004), Madhya Pradesh and Chattisgarh (Chandra and Sharma 2007) or rivers north of Krishna river system need validation.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: Salmophasia acinaces is widely distributed species but there is no information about its population trends. The species is rare in Kerala (Thomas 2002).
column43: The species inhabits hill streams (Menon 1999). This species attains a length of 15 cm total length (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column49: There is no information on threats to the species.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place directed towards this species. Research is needed on population trends, harvest trends and threats to the species.

column11: Chela balookee Sykes, 1839,  Chela teekanee Sykes, 1839,  Cyprinus clupeoides Bloch, 1795,  Cyprinus cyprinoides Bloch & Schneider, 1801,  Pelecus affinis Jerdon, 1849, Salmostoma balookee (Sykes, 1839),  Salmostoma clupeoides (Bloch, 1795),  Salmostoma kardahiensis Reddiah, 1980
column12: Salmophasia balookee is a replacement name for Salmophasia clupeoides (Kottelat 1996). Bloch (1795) described Cyprinus clupeoides from India, but the name is a junior primary homonym of Cyprinus clupeoides described by Pallas (1776). As a result, Kottelat (1996) suggested replacement name for Cyprinus clupeoides Bloch and used the next junior synonym of the species which is Chela balookee described by Sykes (1839) from Deccan plateau of India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Salmophasia balookee is assessed as Least Concern solely based on the fact that the species is widely distributed in the Peninsular India and there are no known major threats to the species. However, the species is relatively rare in the southern India and the species is suspected to be lost from some parts of northern Western Ghats, probably because of heavy harvest. Further research is essential on the population status, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species.
column26: Salmophasia balookee is found only in the Peninsular India and its record from Myanmar (Day 1878) and Assam (Sen 1985) could be wrong (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Menon 1999). This species is present in Narmada, Krishna, Godavari and other river systems of southern India. The species is recorded from Madhya Pradesh (Reddiah 1980, Garg et al. 2007, Dubey 2007, Sarkar and Lakra 2007, Vyas et al. 2009), Chhattisgarh (Sarkar and Lakra 2007), Rajasthan (Sarkar and Lakra 2007, Sharma and Choudhary 2007), Gujrat (Acharya 1939, Ranade 1953), Maharashtra (Sykes 1841, Hora and Misra 1937, Fraser 1942, Setna and Kulkarni 1946, Kulkarni 1947, Kalawar and Kelkar 1956, Singh and Yazdani 1988, Arunachalam et al. 2002, Jadhav et al. 2011), Andhra Pradesh (Chandrasekhar 2004), Karnataka (Rao and Seshachar 1927, David 1956), Tamil Nadu (Rajan 1955, Arunachalam and Sankaranarayanan 1999, Martin et al. 2000, Arunachalam et al. 2001, Daniels and Rajagopal 2004, Devi et al. 2007, Johnson and Arunachalam 2009, Ramanujam and Anbarasan 2009) and Kerala (Silas 1951, Thomas et al. 2002).
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: Population status of Salmophasia balookee is not known. However, the species has not been recorded from Mula-Mutha rivers after Fraser (1942) and Wagh and Ghate (2003) have suggested that the species is lost from these rivers. The species is rare in Kerala (Thaomas et al. 2002), Hyderabad (Chandrasekhar 2004) and Kalakkad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve in Tamil Nadu (Arunachalam and Sankaranarayanan 1999). The species is also rare in Koyna river (Jadhav et al. 2011) but relatively common in Nira river in Maharashtra (Dahanukar et al, manuscript in review). However, a general trend in the population cannot be predicted for the entire range.
column43: Salmophasia balookee is found in upper drainage of large rivers (Menon 1999). It is also found in lakes and reservoirs (Kulkarni 1947, Devi et al. 2007). It attains a total length of 15 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: Specific threats to Salmophasia balookee are not known but the species is a preferred food fish and heavy harvesting could be a threat to the species.
column53: Specific conservation action plan directed towards Salmophasia balookee is not currently available. Research is needed on the population trends, ecology, harvest trends and threats to the species. The species is known from one protected site at Kalakad Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve (Arunachalam and Sankaranarayanan 1999).

column11: Chela boopis Day, 1874,  Oxygaster boopis (Day, 1874),  Salmostoma boopis (Day, 1874)
column12: Salmophasia boopis was originally described as Chela boopis by Day (1874) from South Canara, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Salmophasia boopis is a widespread species present throughout the Western Ghats of India. It is common in most of its range and currently there is no known wide spread threat to the species. The species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Salmophasia boopis is endemic to the Western Ghats of India (Dahanukar et al. 2004). It is not found north of Krishna river system and its obscure record from Madhya Pradesh by Sarkar and Lakra (2007) needs validation. The species is recorded from Western Ghats of Maharashtra (Annandale 1919, Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Yazdani and Singh 1990, Arunachalam 2002, Kharat et al. 2000, 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, Chandanshive et al. 2007, Jadhav and Yadav 2009, Jadhav et al. 2011), Goa (Tilak 1972), Karnataka (Bhat 2004, Sreekantha 2008, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Shahnawaz et al. 2010), Kerala (Shaji and Easa 1995, 1996, Ajithkumar et al. 1999, Thomas et al. 2000, Ajithkumar et al. 2001, Bijukumar and Sushama 2001, Thomas et al. 2002) and Tamil Nadu (Arunachalam 2000, Martin et al. 2000).
column31: Native: India (Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu)
column35: No information is available on exact population trends in Salmophasia boopis. However, the species is fairly common in most of its range (Kharat et al. 2000, Thomas et al. 2002, Shahnawaz and Venkateshwarlu 2009, Jadhav et al. 2011).
column43: Salmophasia boopis is often found in upper reaches of the rivers (Menon 1999) and the middle reashes (R. Kumar pers. comm.). It is also found in lakes (Fraser 1942, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963) and reservoirs (Yazdani and Singh 1990). It attains a total length of 12 cm (Menon 1999). No information is available on habitat trends for this fish.
column49: No specific information is available on threats to Salmophasia boopis.
column53: No specific action plan is in place directed towards Salmophasia boopis. Research is essential on the population trends, harvest trends and threats to the species.

column11: Cyprinus novacula Valenciennes, 1840,  Salmostoma longicauda Srithar & Jayaram, 1990,  Salmostoma novacula (Valenciennes, 1840)
column12: Salmophasia novacula was described by Valanciennes (1842) from erstwhile Madras, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Salmophasia novacula is assessed as Least Concern due to its wide distribution and apparent lack of threats.
column26: Salmophasia novacula is known to occur in Krishna and Godavari drainages in Karnataka and Maharashtra (Jayaram 1999, Chandrashekhariah et al. 2000, Heda 2009) the Mula and Mutha rivers (Wagh and Ghate 2003) and Pavana River in Maharashtra (Chandanshive et al. 2007) and in Tamil Nadu (Remadevi and Indra 2000).
column35: There is no information on the population status of S. novacula. This species is however known to have become rare in the Krishna and Godavari rivers in Karnataka (Chandrasekhariah et al. 2000).  It is very common in the heavily polluted Mula-Mutha rivers in Pune (Kharat et al. 2000).
column43: Inhabits upper drainages of rivers and reservoirs (Menon 1999).
column49: No information is available on the threats to S. novacula.
column53: There is a need to determine the current distribution, population and life history traits of this poorly known species.

column12: Salmophasia untrahi was originally described as Chela untrahi by Day (1869) from Mahanuddi (Mahanadi), Orissa, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Salmophasia untrahi is assessed as Least Concern due to its wide distribution and lack of threats. However the taxonomic validity of populations outside of Orissa need validation as Menon (1999) suspects it to be restricted to Orissa while subsequently many researchers report it from all over peninsular India.
column26: Salmophasia untrahi is known from Mahanadi in Orissa (Day 1869), Cauvery and Coleroon in Tamil Nadu (Day 1889), Eastern Ghats of India (Devi and Indra 2003), Chhattisgarh (Sarkar and Lakra 2007), Hyderabad in Andhra Pradesh (Chandrasekhar 2004), Bhadra river in Karnataka (Kiran and Puttaiah 2005, Venkateshwarlu and Somashekar 2005) and Solapur in Maharashtra (Jadhav and Yadav 2009). Menon (1999) has suggested that the species is restricted to Mahanadi in Orissa but no rationale is provided.
column31: Native: India (Andhra Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Orissa, Tamil Nadu)
column35: No information is available on the population status and population trends of Salmophasia untrahi. However, Chandrasekhar (2004) has stated that the species is uncommon in Hyderabad.
column43: Salmophasia untrahi is found in lower reaches of rivers (Menon 1999). It is also found in lakes (Venkateshwarlu and Somashekar 2005). The species attains a total length of 20 cm (Menon 1999). The life span of the fish is about 1-2 years (Kiran and Puttaiah 2005). No information is available on the habitat decline for this species.
column49: No information is available on threats to Salmophasia untrahi.
column53: No specific conservation action plan is in place for Salmophasia untrahi. Research is needed on the exact distribution, population status and threats to the species.

column12: Schismatorhynchos nukta was originally described as Cyprinus nukta by Sykes (1839) from Indrayani river near Mahalunge, Maharashtra, India. Day (1872) changed the generic status of the fish to Labeo, while Hora (1942) changed the generic status of the fish to Schismatorhynchos.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Schismatorhynchos nukta is assessed as Endangered because it is becoming a very rare species and its population is declining drastically by more than 50% in the last 10 years. It is also suspected to be locally extinct from some parts of its known distribution including its type locality. Furthermore, if the current trends in habitat loss due to deforestation, urbanization and pollution and harvesting of the fish continue, it is predicted that the population of this already rare species could decrease with at least 60%. Even though this prediction is not based on the quantitative data the figure is an under representation based on the knowledge shared by local fishermen and personal observations.
column26: Schismatorhynchos nukta is endemic to the peninsular India and is found in Krishna and Kaveri river systems. It is found in Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. In Maharashtra it is recorded from Indrayani river near Mahalunge (Sykes 1841), Mula-Mutha River near Kharadegaon (Fraser 1942), Wadgaon on Bhima river (Suter 1944), Ujni Wetland (Yazdani and Singh 1990, Surwade and Khillare 2010), Neera river near Veer dam (Ghate et al. 2002),  Krishna river near Wai (S.S. Kharat, Mandar Paingankar and Neelesh Dahanukar, Unpublished), Koyna river near Patan (Jadhav et al. 2011), Panchaganga river in Kolhapur (Kalawar and Kelkar 1956) and Sangli (Jayaram 1995). In Karnata it is known from Bhadra river at Bhadravati (David 1956), Tunga river at Hariharpur (Chacko and Kuriyan 1948), Bagalkot (Jayaram 1995) and Doora lake (Prasad et al. 2009). In Andhra Pradesh it is known from Lingalagattu at Sri Sailam and Manthralayam (Jayaram 1995). In Tamil Nadu it is known from Moyar river at Thengumarada (Manimekalan and Singh 1997). The extent of occurrence of this species seems to be declining as the species is considered locally extinct from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Kharat et al. 2003). The species has not been reported from its type locality in Indrayani river even after serious efforts (Yazdani and Mahabal 1976). The record of this species from Nepal (Shrestha 2002) needs taxonomic confirmation.
column35: Exact population structure of Schismatorhynchos nukta is not known but the species is rare (Menon 2004, Jayaram 1995, Ghate et al. 2002, Prasad et al. 2009, Jadhav et al. 2011, Neelesh Dahanukar pers. obs.). The only record which states that the species is abundant is by Surwade and Khillare (2010) from Ujni wetland, Pune, Maharashtra. The species is suggested to be locally extinct from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Kharat et al. 2003). The species was also not recorded from its type locality in Indrayani river (Yazdani and Mahabal 1976; N. Dahanukar pers. obs.). The population of the species is rapidly declining in the areas where it is currently found (personal communication with the local fishermen from Western Ghats of Maharashtra). Even though quantitative estimates are not available for the population changes, it is predicted that the population of this species will decline by more than 60% if the current trends in habitat loss due to deforestation, urbanization and pollution, impact of introduced carps and harvesting of the fish continue.  It is rare in Tambiraparani and Bhadra rivers (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.) and market surveys and questionnaire surveys with local fishermen indicate the species to be declining rapidly (N. Dahanukar and M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column43: Schismatorhynchos nukta is found in rapid streams and rivers with sand and boulder bed (Menon 2004). It is also  found in reservoirs (Yazdani and Singh 1990). It attains a total length of 30 cm (Menon 2004). The habitat of  this species is threatened by urbanization, industrialization, organic and inorganic pollution and deforestation (David 1956, Ghate et al. 2002, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003).
column49: The population of Schismatorhynchos nukta is declining and it could be attributed to several possible threats to the species. Heavy harvest could be a possible threat because this fish is often caught and sold in local markets especially during the Monsoon season when the species is migrating upstream for breeding (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.). The habitat of  this species is threatened by urbanization, industrialization, organic and inorganic pollution and deforestation (David 1956, Ghate et al. 2002, Kharat et al. 2003, Wagh and Ghate 2003, N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column53: Currently no protective measures are in place to conserve Schismatorhynchos nukta. Site/area protection, check on the harvesting and public awareness could be possible first steps for conserving the species. Research is needed to understand the population status, life history, ecology, harvest and threats to the species.

column12: Menon (1992) described Tor kulkarnii from Darna river, a tributary of upper Godavari river in Deolali, Nashik, Maharashtra. Menon (1992) considered this species as a dwarf cognate of Tor khudree, however, Jayaram (1999, 2005, 2010) considered T. kulkarnii as a synonym of T. khudree. Even though T. kulkarnii is considered as valid species (Menon 1999, 2004, Nautiyal et al. 2008) this species is remarkably similar to T. khudree and the observed differences could only be population variations rather than species variations. Therefore, taxonomic status of T. kulkarnii is questionable. The types examined indicate Tor kulkarnii to be a distinct species (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.), however, since Tor exhibits a high degree of phenotypic plasticity, a good comparative and molecular study of types of both the species is urgently required.  Tor khudree is also recorded from the type locality of T. kulkarnii (S. Jadhav pers. obs.).
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Tor kulkarnii is considered a distinct species until further studies confirm otherwise.  Since it has been documented only from the type locality, the habitat is under severe threat from various anthropogenic factors as well as the threat to all the Tor species from over exploitation.  The species is assessed as Endangered as it is restricted to a single location in less than 20 km2 area and less than 2000 km2 extent with continuing decline in the quality of habitat.
column26: Tor kulkarnii is endemic to northern Western Ghats and currently it is known only from its type locality in Darna river, Deolali, Nashik District, Maharashtra (Menon 1992, 1999, 2004). The point locality map shown in Menon (2004, fig. 11) shows some locations in the upper Krishna River but this is a mistake as the author mentions in the text that the species is confined to its type locality.
column35: There is no information on the population status of Tor kulkarnii but it is rare (Menon 1999, 2004). The species has never been recorded after its first description based on four specimens (Menon 2004).
column43: Tor kulkarnii is recorded from clear fast flowing streams with rocky bed and it attains a standard length of 20.8 cm (Menon 1999).
column49: The type locality of Tor kulkarnii is threatened by organic pollution, heavy harvesting, urbanization and introduced fishes (N. Dahanukar, pers. obs.).
column53: No particular conservation action plan is in place directed towards Tor kulkarnii, however, Menon (2004) has recommended that a sanctuary should be set up in one of the streams of the Darna river in Deolali to protect this rare species. Research on taxonomy, population status, life history, ecology, harvest trends and threats is required.

column12: Tor malabaricus was described by Jerdon (1849) as Barbus malabaricus from the mountain streams of Malabar India. Menon (1992) synonymised this species with Tor khudree while Indra (1993) considered it as a valid sub species. Recent genetic work has confirmed the validity of T. malabaricus as a seperate species using RAPD technique (Silas et al. 2005), and mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences (A Gopalakrishnan pers.comm.). M. Arunachalam (pers.comm.) suspects all Tor khudree recorded from Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu are T. malabaricus, except for three populations in Chalakkudy, Cauvery and Krishna basins.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Rahul, K., Johnson, J.A. & Molur, S.
column20: Tor malabaricus is widely distributed, but the entire population is under several anthropogenic threats resulting in more than 50% decline in populations in the last 10 years and the trend continuing into the future.  Hence it is assessed as Endangered.
column26: Tor malabaricus is recorded from rivers Balamore, Kanyakumari, Tamil Nadu and Kallada, Kerala (Silas et al. 2005); and Tambraparini river (as T. khudree malabaricus) (Arunachalam et al. 2000).  Other records include Netravathi (Anekal and Tingale), Tunga (Ganapathykatte, Sringeri and Suliya) (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).  In Chalakudy it coexists with T. khudree (A. Gopalakrishnan pers. comm.).
column35: There is no information on the population of T. malabaricus in Maharashtra.  It's common only in temple sanctuaries in Karnataka.  The species is rare in other stretches of the streams on either side of the temple sanctuaries.  In general, the species is uncommon (M. Arunachalam and K.R. Devi pers. comm.). The species has declined rapidly from all three states seen in surveys conducted since 1996.  In earlier years the number of specimens caught from each of the localities were around 10-15, but in recent years the numbers caught have reduced to almost nil.  Most of the areas are devoid of this species and they have not been observed (M. Arunachalam pers.comm.).
column43: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of T. malabaricus. Arunachalam et al. (2000) recorded that T. khudree malabaricus prefers deep pools in streams with rocky substrates, where they feed on allochthonous plant materials and debris.
column49: Habitats of T. malabaricus in Tambraparini river are known to be under threat from siltation, alteration in flow and resultant drying up of pools in summer and destructive fishing practices (Arunachalam et al. 2000). In most river systems where the species occurs it is subjected to severe continuing decline in habitats and habitat quality due to anthropogenic affects such as urbanization, pollution, siltation, deforestation, and other causative factors (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.).
column53: No conservation actions are in place. There is a need to identify micro level distribution patterns and subsequently study aspects of life history and population of this species. Temple authorities and communities need to be made aware of the conservation needs in the river systems (V. Atkore pers. comm.).

column12: Pseudolaguvia austrina is a recently described species by Radhakrishnan, Sureshkumar and Ng (2010) from Kunthi River (a tributary of the Bharathapuzha  River) at Mannarkkad, Kerala, India.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Rahul, K., Carpenter, K.E. & Molur, S.
column20: Pseudolaguvia austrina is assessed as Data Deficient since it is a recently described species and there is a need to generate baseline data on the distribution, ecology and threats to the species. However, if the species is found to be restricted only to the current distribution then it will qualify for Endangered category if there are threats to the species and/or to the habitat.
column26: Pseudolaguvia austrina is endemic to the southern Western Ghats and currently it is known only from its type locality in the Kunthi River (tributary of the Bharathapuzha River) at Mannarkkad, Kerala in India (Radhakrishnan, Sureshkumar and Ng 2010). Note that the publication mentions latitude longitude for the type locality as  11°21' N and 76°53' E, but the correct latitude longitude is 10°59' 20.39'' N and 76°26' 33.51'' E (K.V. Radhakrishnan pers. comm.). The Bharathapuza River drains the western face of the Western Ghats and debouches into the Lakshadweep Sea. Based on the current information the species is found in the hydrobasin with area 1000 km2, However it is expected to be found in adjoining basins as well. So the EOO for the species is around 5000 km2 with only one location. Nevertheless, this information may get updated with further studies on the distribution of the species.
column35: No information is available on the population status of this species.
column43: Pseudolaguvia  austrina  has been collected from riffle-pool type habitat and clayey area with clumps of leaf litter. It was collected from small  crevices  of  a  sand  barrier built across the river with a moderate water depth (ca. 15 cm), current velocity of 0.25-0.40 m/s, dissolved oxygen 7-8ppm and a pH of 7.5-8.0 (Radhakrishnan, Sureshkumar and Ng 2010).
column49: Threats to the species are unknown.
column53: There is a need to generate baseline data on the distribution, population status, habitat and ecology and threats to the species.
column59: IUCN. 2011. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species (ver. 2011.1). Available at: http://www.iucnredlist.org. (Accessed: 16 June 2011).; Radhakrishnan, K.V., Sureshkumar, S. and Ng, H.H. 2010. column11: Acentrogobius scrutarius Whitley, 1955, Drombus whitleyi Fowler, 1931,  Gobius atripinnis Fowler, 1934,  Gobius caledonicus Sauvage, 1880,  Gobius darnleyensis Alleyne & Macleay, 1877,  Gobius filamentosus Sauvage, 1883,  Gobius fuscus Rüppell, 1830,  Gobius marginalis De Vis, 1884,  Gobius nebulopunctatus Valenciennes, 1837,  Gobius nigripinnis Alleyne & Macleay, 1877,  Gobius obscurus Peters, 1855,  Gobius poecilichthys Jordan & Snyder, 1901,  Gobius punctillatus Rüppell, 1830
column12: Bathygobius fuscus was originally described as Gobius fuscus by Rüppell (1830) from Red Sea.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Bathygobius fuscus is a widely distributed species with no known major threat. Hence it is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Bathygobius fuscus is a widely distributed species in tropical seas, brackish water and freshwater. It is found in the Red Sea, Indo-West Pacific: East Africa, Madagascar and Mascarenes east to Maldives, all costal states of India, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Sri Lanka, Wake Atoll, Marquesas Islands and Gambier Islands, north to South Korea and southern Japan, south to Western Australia, Queensland (Australia), New Caledonia, Norfolk Island and Tonga (Tilak 1972, Jones et al. 1981, Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Rao et al. 2000, Eschmeyer and Fricke 2011).
column31: Native: Australia; Bangladesh; China; Fiji; Hong Kong; India (Andaman Is., Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Gujarat, Karnataka, Kerala, Laccadive Is., Maharashtra, Nicobar Is., Orissa, Pondicherry, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal); Indonesia; Japan; Korea, Republic of; Myanmar; Papua New Guinea; Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand; Viet Nam
column35: Bathygobius fuscus is relatively common. In Australia the fish contributed to 1.63% of the total catch (Depczynski and Bellwood 2004).
column43: This is primarily a marine species occasionally entering freshwaters. It is found mainly in the creeks (Rao et al. 2000) and it prefers habitats with sand and rubble, soft coral and open reefs (Depczynski and Bellwood 2004). It is a detritus feeder (Depczynski and Bellwood 2003).
column49: There are no known major threats to the species.
column53: No conservation action plan is in place directed towards Bathygobius fuscus. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

column12: Sicyopterus griseus was described by Day (1877) from Canara, India.
column18: Madhusoodana Kurup, B., Ali, A., Abraham, R. & Cox, N.A.
column20: Sicyopterus griseus is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, it occurs in some protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
column26: Sicyopterus griseus is known from southern India (Froese and Pauly 2009). Recorded from the rivers Neyyar, Pamba, Periyar, Chalakudy, Kuttiadi, Valapatnam, Chandragiri, Mahe, Kuppam, Cheenkannipuzha, Irutty and Chaliyar (Chhapgar and Mankadan 2000, Shaji and Easa 2003, Biju 2005) and Bharathapuzha (Bijukumar and Sushama 2000); Tungabhadra (Shaji and Easa 2003) and from South Canara, Madras, Sri Lanka (Jayaram 1999)  and the Eastern Ghats (Rema Devi and Indra 2003). However its record from Sri Lanka is uncertain (Pethiyagoda  1991).
column31: Native: India (Karnataka - Presence Uncertain, Kerala) Presence uncertain: Sri Lanka
column35: There is no information on the population of S. griseus. It is quite common in Chaliyar, Chalakudy, and the Iritty rivers (India).
column43: Common in streams where the flow is somewhat moderate. Streams typically have a substrate of boulders. Predominantly inhabits freshwater, migrating up to torrential streams. Probably breeds in freshwater (Menon 1999). Also known from estuaries and brackish waters (Talwar and Jhingaran 1991, Bijukumar and Sushama 2000).
column49: Since S. griseus is known to occur in low and midland areas of most rivers in Kerala, as well as some estuaries, which are undergoing decline in their habitats due to pollution, sand mining, destructive fishing and construction of barrages and check dams, there is ever reason to believe that this species may be affected.
column53: There is a need to generate baseline information on this species including its population status, ecology and threats to inform conservation actions. It is found in some protected areas.

column11: Anthias lineatus Bloch, 1793,  Coius gudgutia Hamilton, 1822,  Lutjanus hasta Bloch, 1790,  Lutjanus microstomus Lacepède, 1802,  Lutjanus orientalis Lacepède, 1802,  Pomadasys hasta (Bloch, 1790),  Pristipoma chrysobalion Cuvier, 1830,  Pristipoma manadense Günther, 1872,  Pristipoma nageb Rüppell, 1838,  Sciaena argentea Forsskål, 1775,  Sciaena nageb Bonnaterre, 1788,  Sciaena nageb Forsskål, 1775,  Sparus trilineatus Shaw, 1803
column12: Pomadasys argenteus was originally described as Sciaena argentea by Forsskål (1775) from Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, Red Sea.
column18: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.
column20: Pomadasys argenteus is a widespread species with no known major threat to the global population. Hence it is Least Concern.
column26: Pomadasys argenteus is distributed in Indo-West Pacific, from Red Sea to Gulf of Aden to India to Bangladesh to the Philippines, north to southern Japan, and south to northern Australia, New Caledonia, Oman and Kuwait (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, al Sakaff and Esseen1999, Bijukumar and Sushama 2000, Almatar et al. 2004, Rahman and Akhter 2009, Froese and Pauley 2011).
column31: Native: Australia; Bangladesh; China; Hong Kong; India (Andaman Is., Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Gujarat, Karnataka, Kerala, Laccadive Is., Maharashtra, Nicobar Is., Orissa, Pondicherry, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal); Indonesia; Kuwait; Maldives; Myanmar; Oman; Saudi Arabia; Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand; Turkey
column35: Pomadasys argenteus is common throughout its range.
column43: This species inhabits freshwater, brackish and marine habitats. It breeds between mid May to early October and female spawns about six times in one season (Almatar et al. 2004).
column49: There are no known major threats to the species.
column53: No specific conservation action plans are in place for this species.

column11: Hemiramphus gorakhpurensis Srivastava, 1967,  Hemiramphus limbatus Valenciennes, 1847,  Hemiramphus tridentifer Cantor, 1849,  Hemirhamphus sinensis Günther, 1866,  Hyporhamphus sinensis (Günther, 1866)
column12: Hyporhamphus limbatus was originally described as Hemiramphus limbatus by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1847) from Malabar coast of India.
column20: Hyporhamphus limbatus is common and widespread species throughout its range with no known major threats. Hence it is assessed as Least Concern.
column26: Although Hyporhamphus limbatus was originally described from India, its range extends from the Persian Gulf to China along the mainland coast of Asia (Collette and Su 1986). In Asia, it is known from India, Sril Lanka, Myanmar, Thiland and China (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Ramanujam and Anbarasan 2007, Ajith Kumar and Amarshinghe 2008)  It is replaced in the East Indies, Borneo and Philippines by the closely related Hyporhamphus neglectus and around northern Australia and southern New Guinea by Hyporhamphus neglectissimus (Collette and Su 1986). In India the species in known from the coastal states and also from the strictly freshwater areas of Orissa (Collette and Su 1986) and Maharashtra (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.). Its distribution in the Mula-Mutha river, Bhima river, Ghad river and Ujani wetland (Surwade and Khillare 2010, N. Dahanukar pers. obs.) is likely a recent introduction of this species since 2008 as it was not found from these areas before 2008 (Yazdani and Singh 1990, Kharat et al. 2003).
column31: Native: Bangladesh; Cambodia; China; India (Andaman Is., Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Gujarat, Karnataka, Kerala, Laccadive Is., Maharashtra, Orissa, Pondicherry, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal); Malaysia; Myanmar; Pakistan; Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand; Viet Nam
column35: This is a very common species in India. Its population in Pune and its outskirts is likely to be an introduced population since 2008 (N. Dahanukar pers. obs.).
column43: A coastal species, frequently enters estuaries and even strictly freshwater. Encountered in the Mekong River as far upstream as Stung Treng (Rainboth 1996) and also found in the Great Lake (Tone lap) and in the Tone lap River, Cambodia (Lim et al. 1999) and in two floodplain lakes of the Ichhamiti River, India (Mondal and Kaviraj 2009). Found at surface levels of tidal freshwaters and brackish estuaries (Rainboth 1996). Feeds mainly on insects (Rainboth 1996, Lim et al. 1999). Reaches a maximum size of 168 mm SL and matures at a relatively small size, by 103 mm for males, 93 mm for females (Collette and Su 1986). It breeds twice in a year (Talwar and Jhingran 1991).
column49: There are no known threats to this species.
column53: No conservation efforts directed towards this species exists.
